headline: Market Place; Fund Diversity In Managers
abstract: LEAD: MOST money managers believe in diversifying their investments, but George F. Keane, president of the Common Fund, which oversees $2.1 billion in endowment assets, carries that principle one step further. He believes in a diversified portfolio of managers.

headline: WAITE RETURNS TO LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: Terry Waite, envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, arrived in Beirut today and said he had spoken with one of his contacts within an hour of his arrival on a new bid to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

headline: PAN AM HAS BIG LOSS FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
abstract: LEAD: The Pan American Corporation yesterday reported substantial losses in the fourth quarter and all of 1986 but securities analysts found hopeful signs.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 15, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: TRADE VS. NATIONAL SECURITY; Managing the Flow of Vital Technology
abstract: LEAD: THE Reagan Administration, like each of the eight previous administrations, professes a free-trade and open investment philosophy that it often must violate in practice. Most recently, concerns about national security have motivated several exceptions in high-technology industries. For example, both the Commerce Department and the Defense Department cited national security as the basis of their informal opposition to Japan Fujitsu Ltd.

headline: JEWISH GROUP ACCEPTS NEW EXPORTS TO SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: An American advocacy group on Soviet Jewry has told the Government that it will not contest the decision on Thursday to allow exports of gas and oil technology to the Soviet Union.

headline: INVENTORIES OFF IN DECEMBER
abstract: LEAD: Business sales, aided by a year-end spurt of car buying, jumped 2.9 percent in December and inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the largest decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JANUARY 1, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Grenfell Forms Executive Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., parent of Britain's top investment bank, said today that it had set up an executive committee to manage the company.

headline: A DOW-DOLLAR LINK IS SEEN BY EXPERTS
abstract: LEAD: The surge in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year - not counting Friday's wild gyrations - has been accompanied by a decline in the value of the dollar. There is, many experts believe, a strong link between the two.

headline: Nippon Phone Shares Trading
abstract: LEAD: After long anticipation, shares of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone began changing hands on Japanese stock exchanges today, trading at about 1.6 million yen a share, or $10,460.93.

headline: PART II: INTERVENTIONS UPON HUMAN PROCREATION
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday:

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Sales Up 3.8% At City Stores
abstract: LEAD: December sales among several of New York's biggest stores rose by an average of 3.8 percent in the city and 5.8 percent in the metropolitan area from the period a year ago, a spot-check found.

abstract: LEAD: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday:

headline: OWENS SETS STUDY OF HIGHER BID
abstract: LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors would consider ''in the near future'' an improved $3.6 billion buyout offer received Monday from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

headline: 4-MONTH DISRUPTION OF ECUADOR OIL
abstract: LEAD: Ecuador's suspension of crude oil shipments will last at least four months because of the earthquake Thursday that ruptured the country's main oil pipeline, a senior Energy Ministry official said tonight.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said that until March 31 it would offer buyers of 1986 Renault Alliance and Encore models and 1987 Alliance and GTA models a choice of free air-conditioning or automatic transmission. It also said it would give a $500 rebate to buyers of cars without those options.

headline: TOOL ORDERS ROSE 8.2% IN JANUARY
abstract: LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 8.2 percent in January from the slightly improved levels of December, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

headline: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 26, 1987:           Monday        American President Co   Kennametal Inc        Armstrong World Indus   Kentucky Utilities        Black & Decker   Koppers Co        Consol Freightways   Lubrizol Corp        Foster Wheeler   NWA Inc        Heck's Inc   Stone Container        Howell Corp   Wells Fargo M & E Tr        TUESDAY        Ball Corp   Interstate Pwr        Becor Western Inc   Interstate Securs        Becton Dickinson & Co   Johnson Controls        Black Hills Corp   NUI Corp        Borden Inc   Newmont Mining Corp        CILCORP Inc   Norwest Corp        Crompton & Knowles   Rollins Inc        Eaton

headline: A Classic Battle Over Frontier Models
abstract: LEAD: When Philippe de Villiers, Secretary of State for Culture in France's conservative Government, opened a new collection in the Invalides war museum in Paris this year, there was only one thing wrong.

headline: Israelis Who Met With P.L.O. Deny Aid-to-Terrorists Charge
abstract: LEAD: Four Israeli leftists who met with members of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Rumania in November pleaded not guilty today to breaking a law banning unauthorized contacts with ''terrorist organizations.''

headline: 7 Skiers Killed in Avalanche In Wilds of British Columbia
abstract: LEAD: Seven members of a ski party were killed by an avalanche today in the remote mountains near here, authorities said.

headline: LATIN PEACE PROPOSAL GAINS, BUT IS FACING STIFF HURDLES
abstract: LEAD: A Costa Rican plan to bring peace to Central America appears to be getting increasingly serious consideration in the region. But several Central American officials say the plan faces difficult negotiations.

headline: REMAKING THE AMERICAN C.E.O.
abstract: LEAD: THE turmoil in corporate America is forcing the nation's business leaders to undertake the most radical reassessment of their practices and beliefs since the end of World War II. But out of this soul-searching, a new set of management precepts is emerging, with profound impact on individual companies and the country as a whole.

headline: HONG KONG'S WORST SLUM SEEMS PLEASED TO FACE ITS DOOM
abstract: LEAD: In the bowels of this city's worst slum, people walk about on paths that seem like tunnels. The buildings are so close together that the sky is just a thin crack in the blackness, 15 stories above a jumble of contorted alleys and dripping pipes.

headline: Pretoria Bans Meetings By Educational Group
abstract: LEAD: The Government banned an unofficial education group today from holding meetings to discuss its alternative program for black schools.

headline: I.B.M. PLANS STANDARDS STEP
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the International Business Machines Corporation confirmed yesterday that the company is developing standards that eventually will permit software to run on machines ranging from I.B.M.

headline: GREY WINS COLOR TILE
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising has been named to handle the broadcast advertising for Color Tile Inc., of Fort Worth, which operates a nationwide chain of home decorating retailer outlets. Billings could come to $10 million. There are 680 company-owned stores in the chain, which had been doing all of its advertising in-house.

headline: JAPAN WAGES UP 3.1%
abstract: LEAD: The average monthly wage of a Japanese worker rose 3.1 percent in 1986, the Labor Ministry reported today. The increase, adjusted for inflation, was the highest in 13 years.

headline: Big Board Weathers The Storm
abstract: LEAD: Yesterday's record stock market activity left brokers breathless - and eagerly hoping for more.

headline: Pact on Yugoslav Debt
abstract: LEAD: Yugoslavia signed an agreement with the United States today for the refinancing of $220 million of official debt due between May 1986 and the end of 1988, the official Tanjug news agency said. The agreement, signed in Washington, means Yugoslavia can ''resume the regular fulfillment of obligations toward Governments of 16 industrial countries'' under a multilateral accord signed in Paris last May, the agency said.

headline: JOINT VENTURES, RUSSIAN STYLE
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet trade official today disclosed more details of the Soviet Union's plan to offer highly unusual operating independence and tax breaks as inducements to encourage American and other foreign companies to enter into joint business ventures with Soviet industries.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: LEAD: An automatic control system for twin-engine aircraft was patented for NASA. If one engine fails, the other is enabled to compensate for the loss of power. Patent 4,648,569 was awarded to Eric C. Stewart, an aerospace engineer at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va. Both patents are available for licensing.

headline: Monetary Policy Stayed Steady in Mid-December
abstract: LEAD: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve left monetary policy unchanged at a meeting in mid-December, according to minutes of the session released today.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE RETHINKING ITS DREAMS
abstract: LEAD: In an airless, fly-infested ward of Maputo's Central Hospital, a small girl sits silent and naked in the heat, dabbing at a sore behind her ear.

headline: NEW PRESSES SPUR DETROIT PRODUCTIVITY
abstract: LEAD: ABOUT half-a-dozen men stand around anxiously eyeing their watches as three enormous sets of stamping dies slide out of the press line and another group of dies advances on a conveyor to take their place. As a problem with automated transfer arms causes the minutes to tick on, brows knit in frustration.

headline: JARUZELSKI BEGINS OFFICIAL VISIT TO ROME
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today began his first official visit to the West since he imposed martial law in Poland five years ago.

headline: BRAZIL SITUATION SPURS ACTION ON OTHERS' DEBTS
abstract: LEAD: Galvanized by Brazil's economic crisis, international banks and Western governments took steps this week to prevent the situation from snowballing throughout Latin America's debtor countries.

headline: A.M.C. ABSORPTION BY CHRYSLER SEEN
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation plans to absorb and dismantle the American Motors Corporation by the end of the year if its proposed buyout of the ailing auto maker is completed on schedule, the trade journal Automotive News reported. Chrysler agreed last week to purchase Renault's 46.1 percent interest in A.M.C.

headline: Patents; Nominations Asked For the Hall of Fame
abstract: LEAD: A call has been issued for nominations to the National Inventors Hall of Fame for 1988. They must be submitted by July 1. Induction ceremonies will be held next February, with selection based on American patents.

headline: KODIAK OUTDOOR BOOTS TO MESSNER, VETERE
abstract: LEAD: There was a minor celebration yesterday at Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, which reached its six-month anniversary and got its sixth client.

headline: REAGAN PLANS TO ASK CONGRESS TO RESTORE CONTRIBUTION TO U.N.
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that he will ask Congress to restore millions of dollars in financial cuts that pushed the United Nations close to bankruptcy, United Nations and American officials said today.

headline: UNDER MARXISM, ETHIOPIA'S CHRISTIANS ABIDE
abstract: LEAD: Holy Cross Square has been renamed Revolution Square and is now graced with a billboard hailing Communism's trinity: Marx, Engels and Lenin.

headline: VATICAN SAYS THE ENCOUNTERS WILL NOT AFFECT DIPLOMACY
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican today described John Cardinal O'Connor's meetings with Israeli Government leaders as ''acts of courtesy'' and said the encounters would not have a direct effect on the Holy See's relations with Israel.

headline: Detectors That Talk to the Front Desk
abstract: LEAD: RESEARCH on smoke detectors, as with most fire safety research, has focused on the issue of speeding up the warning time, giving guests a chance to get out and firefighters a chance to get in before dense smoke and toxic gases make approaching the fire hazardous or even impossible.

headline: Investor Profiles: Changing Strategies Under the New Law
abstract: LEAD: Now that revisions in the nation's tax code have become law, taxpayers are being forced to examine new and varied investment strategies. Here, three groups of investors discuss how their planning has been affected, and what changes they will make as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.  DIVERSIFYING INVESTMEN

abstract: LEAD: MOST money managers believe in diversifying their investments, but George F. Keane, president of the Common Fund, which oversees $2.1 billion in endowment assets, carries that principle one step further. He believes in a diversified portfolio of managers.

abstract: LEAD: Terry Waite, envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, arrived in Beirut today and said he had spoken with one of his contacts within an hour of his arrival on a new bid to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

Most recently, concerns about national security have motivated several exceptions in high-technology industries. For example, both the Commerce Department and the Defense Department cited national security as the basis of their informal opposition to Japan Fujitsu Ltd.

abstract: LEAD: An American advocacy group on Soviet Jewry has told the Government that it will not contest the decision on Thursday to allow exports of gas and oil technology to the Soviet Union.

abstract: LEAD: Business sales, aided by a year-end spurt of car buying, jumped 2.9 percent in December and inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the largest decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said today.

abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Grenfell Forms Executive Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., parent of Britain's top investment bank, said today that it had set up an executive committee to manage the company.

headline: A DOW-DOLLAR LINK IS SEEN BY EXPERTS
abstract: LEAD: The surge in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year - not counting Friday's wild gyrations - has been accompanied by a decline in the value of the dollar. There is, many experts believe, a strong link between the two.

headline: An Opium Warlord's News Conference Spurs Burma and Thailand to Battle Him
abstract: LEAD: An opium warlord whose narcotics trafficking supports an armed rebellion against Burma is reported to be under separate military attacks from Burmese and Thai forces.

headline: 3 Told to Shun Pollard Panel
abstract: LEAD: A lawyer for three Israelis in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had advised them not to testify before a Government commission examining the affair. David Libai, the lawyer, said he told Yosef Yagur, former science counsel at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, Ilan Ravid, former science attache at the embassy, and Irit Erb, a secretary, not to appear because anything they said could be used against them later.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: LEAD: IN the year just ended, more patents were granted than in 1985 and the process took less time. But 45 percent of the recipients were foreigners, including 13,644 Japanese.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: Money Network; Papers in North's Safe Point to Aid for Contras
abstract: LEAD: The Tower Commission found documents in the safe of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North suggesting that tens of millions of dollars were provided to the Nicaragua rebels and others through a private network of corporations and nonprofit organizations that Colonel North helped organize.

headline: SHULTZ IS UNDER FIRE FOR ASSERTING LIBRIA HAS MADE GAINS ON RIGHTS
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who returned from a six-nation tour of Africa late Wednesday, has become embroiled in criticism over his assertion that Liberia has made progress in human rights.

headline: Ad Revenues Up 10.2%
abstract: LEAD: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau reported yesterday that ad revenues of the nation's daily newspapers were up 10.2 percent in October from the same month in 1985, to $2.5 billion, despite a drop in national advertising revenues. Within that, retail advertising rose 10.4 percent, to $1.34 billion, and classified climbed 16.4 percent, to $845 million.

headline: Schools Boycotted in Spain
abstract: LEAD: Students in Spain's high schools boycotted classes today to protest police action during a student march last week in which 25 people were injured, officials said. Several thousand teen-agers rallied in Puerta del Sol Square here and poured red dye in fountains. The students demanded the resignation of Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo.

headline: A SCANDAL RUBS NATION'S RAW NERVES
abstract: LEAD: When word of the scandal seeped out, some said it might rock the republic. Others, more ponderously, mused on its implications for Turkey's long and unresolved quest for modernity.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Asamera Inc., Calgary, Alberta, which is engaged in petroleum exploration, production, refining, marketing and mining, said it had abandoned its plan to sell a Denver refinery and associated assets to Conoco Inc.

headline: GREEN PARTY OUSTED FROM SHARE OF POWER IN FRANKFURT REGION
abstract: LEAD: A 14-month-old coalition between the Social Democratic Party and the Greens in Hesse collapsed today when a Cabinet member from the environmentalist party, the first to hold such an office in West Germany, was dismissed by the state's Premier.

headline: PATENTS; ODORLESS LITTER BOX
abstract: LEAD: An odorless animal litter box called Fresh FeLiner, patented this week by Patrick Yananton, a microbiologist in Point Pleasant, N.J., is being manufactured and sold under license by the Colgate-Palmolive Company. According to patent No. 4,640,225, the box contains an absorbent pad with a protected screen and a moisture-impermeable liner.

headline: Wagner/English Gains On Shifts to Freelance
abstract: LEAD: McCaffrey & McCall recently dismissed five of its in-house TV producers because, David B. McCall, chairman, said, by going to freelance people the agency hopes to avail itself of producers in all of the various advertising categories.

headline: FINANCIAL JOUSTING AT THE FED
abstract: LEAD: As eight stretch limousines waited outside the main entrance to the Federal Reserve Board's Eccles Building here today, some of the nation's most prominent bankers and Wall Street financiers jousted with board members over whether or not one of the nation's most basic banking laws should be breached.

headline: S.E.C. Subpoenas Drexel Customer
abstract: LEAD: A subpoena to one of the largest ''junk bond'' customers of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is a highlight of the Securities and Exchange Commission's broadening inquiry into takeover abuses by issuers and buyers of these high-yield, high-risk instruments, lawyers close to the investigation said today.

headline: Profits Have a Place in Philanthropy
abstract: LEAD: AS THE 200th birthday of the Constitution approaches, questions are being raised about a marketing technique - cause-related marketing - that increasingly is becoming a major means of bankrolling such public celebrations. There are fears that this marketing approach could co-opt nonprofit institutions and dilute corporations' traditional philanthropic commitment.

headline: Volkswagen Plans New U.S. Import
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen U.S., a unit of Volkswagen A.G. of West Germany, said it planned to begin selling low-cost compact cars made in Brazil in the United States market. The new car, called the Fox, carries a price tag of $5,690 for a two-door model and $6,490 for the four-door Fox-GL, with a wagon due in the spring, company executives said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, whose interests include casinos, said its executive vice president and chief financial officer, Donald B. Romans, had decided to take early retirement to pursue other interests but would remain as a financial consultant. Paul J. Johnson will succeed him as chief financial officer.

headline: Sri Lankan Offensive
abstract: LEAD: Eight rebels were killed in an offensive in the Tamil stronghold of Jaffna today, the Government said. A Government statement said security forces cleared the area around a military camp so that helicopters could land without coming under fire from the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the dominant guerrilla group fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in the north and east.

headline: S.E.C. STUDIES TRE TRADING
abstract: LEAD: As part of its broad investigation into the takeover practices of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and other firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into the circumstances surrounding the acquisition last year of the TRE Corporation, sources close to the investigation confirmed yesterday.

headline: U.S. DECISION IS NEAR ON ENDING POLISH SANCTIONS
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will decide in the next two weeks whether to restore trade benefits to Poland that were suspended in 1982 in response to the outlawing of the Solidarity movement, according to high-ranking Administration officials.

headline: Australian Trade Deficit
abstract: LEAD: Australia's Bureau of Statistics said today that the nation's trade deficit narrowed to $750 million (Australian), or about $514 million (American), in February, from $1.23 billion (Australian) the previous month. The Australian dollar jumped on the news, rising to nearly 68.6 cents in American currency, close to its highest level in eight months.

headline: VATICAN, ITS DEFICIT GROWING, ORDERS 1987 SPENDING FREEZE
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican, pressed by a swelling budget deficit, has ordered a spending freeze for 1987, church officials said today.

headline: Battling Imports
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  Mr. Pearlman's article gave the exact picture of what is happening to the brush industry.

headline: CHILE WILL END STATE OF SIEGE
abstract: LEAD: President Augusto Pinochet said today that a state of siege, imposed hours after an attempt on his life in September, would not be renewed when it expired early next month.

headline: A.T.&T. Spending
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to spend about $2.5 billion in 1987 to expand its digital long-distance telephone network. Industry analysts said the announced expansion was a direct response to the aggressive marketing tactics of US Sprint. A.T.&T. has 11,000 miles of fiber optic lines in service and plans to build another 24,000 miles by 1989, when the company would offer digital service to 350 cities.

headline: Daughter of Mandela Held Briefly by Police
abstract: LEAD: The security police briefly detained the daughter of the jailed African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela today, reportedly after finding a pistol in the family's home in Soweto.

headline: BROTHER OF SUSPECTED HIJACKER ARRESTED
abstract: LEAD: West Germany has arrested the brother of a Lebanese terrorist suspect whose freedom is being sought by militants believed to be holding two West German hostages in Lebanon, according to various sources.

headline: ALLEGIS? THAT'S THE OLD UAL
abstract: LEAD: Unisys and Navistar, meet Allegis, the newest addition to corporate lexicon.

headline: Israel's Envoy in U.S. Expects to Leave Soon
abstract: LEAD: Meir Rosenne, Israel's Ambassador to the United States since July 1983, has said he expects to end his term by this summer.

headline: France Raises Rates in Bid to Aid Franc
abstract: LEAD: France raised interest rates again today in an effort to stave off a devaluation of the franc.

headline: DOW JUMPS ANOTHER 18.98, TO 2,276.43
abstract: LEAD: The stock market advanced further into uncharted territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average scoring another big gain that moved it closer to the 2,300 level.

headline: SOVIET LIFTING VEIL ON CAMPS OF STALIN ERA
abstract: LEAD: Passengers who scan the snow-covered foothills on their descent into the Magadan airport can see abandoned clearings sketched in the larch and poplar forests. They are quite probably relics of the Kolyma labor camps, where prisoners of the Stalin era were housed between their shifts at hard labor.

headline: U.S. Officers in Panama Study Guerrilla War
abstract: LEAD: A new research team at the United States military headquarters here is seeking ways for United States and Latin American forces to win small wars against leftist insurgents in this region.

headline: British Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: LEAD: Britain registered a balance-of-payments surplus equivalent to $601.6 million in February, the biggest current account surplus in 14 months, the Trade and Industry Department announced today.

headline: MORE ARE STUDIED
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has pardoned 140 prisoners convicted of subversive activities, and a comparable number of cases are being reviewed, the Government said today.

headline: SURVIVOR OF DEATH CAMP INDENTIFIES ACCUSED GUARD AT TRIAL IN ISRAEL
abstract: LEAD: Forty-four years after escaping from the Treblinka death camp, Pinhas Epstein stood in court today to accuse the man he said was the executioner of countless Jews.

headline: British-Dutch Truck Venture
abstract: LEAD: Britain's troubled state-owned Leyland Trucks, once a takeover target of the General Motors Corporation, will be combined with the Dutch company DAF under a joint venture announced today.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Kenneth I. Roffe has been promoted to executive vice president and chief executive officer of Lowe Marschalk, Cleveland.

headline: Poland Bank Note Plan
abstract: LEAD: After five consecutive years of double-digit inflation, the National Bank of Poland has announced plans to start printing 10,000-zloty bank notes, double the denomination of the largest bank note now circulated, the official Polish press agency, P.A.P., said today. Earlier this month, the Government said prices rose by 18 percent last year, compared with a 15 percent inflation rate in 1985.

headline: GUINNESS SCANDAL ROILS BRITAIN
abstract: LEAD: The Guinness affair is a scandal of the sort that the British public finds irresistible: the high and mighty brought low by underhanded dealings and common greed. But the impact of the scandal is being felt far beyond the executive suites of the giant brewing company and the other concerns that helped in manipulating

headline: Yugoslavia Refinancing
abstract: LEAD: Yugoslavia's Deputy Prime Minister, Janez Zemljaric, said today that his nation wants to refinance $2 billion of its total debt of $19.7 billion, the official Tanjug news agency reported. Mr. Zemljaric was quoted as saying Yugoslavia expected a ''definite measure of understanding'' from 16 Western creditor countries it will meet on March 30.

headline: A.M.C. Warranties
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation said it had extended its engine and transmission warranties on 1987 Renault cars to six years or 60,000 miles, from five years or 50,000 miles. A.M.C. also extended rust protection to six years or 100,000 miles. The powertrain warranty is identical to those announced by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.

headline: PAN AM'S PEOPLE
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: M.A. Hanna Plans Charge in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The M. A. Hanna Company, a leading producer of iron ore, based in Cleveland, said it would take a charge of more than $100 million against fourth-quarter earnings, causing a loss for the period.

headline: Official Urges Oil Tax Break
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has been urged to propose a large tax break for oil companies, an Administration official said today.

headline: Treasury Issues Up Modestly
abstract: LEAD: Spurred by a sharp drop in short-term interest rates and some weaker than expected economic statistics, prices of Treasury notes and bond rose modestly yesterday. In doing so, they recouped some of their declines of earlier in the week.

headline: RATES UP A BIT ON U.S. ISSUES
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as steep declines in the dollar discouraged buying by speculators and investors.

headline: Mortgage Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan Association is offering $75 million of 7 1/2 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1992 at a price of 99.84, to yield 7.54 percent, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds, rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service, are backed by Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation mortgage participation certificates worth 130 percent to 140 percent of the bonds.

headline: Brazil's Battle Aainst Banks
abstract: LEAD: WHILE the Carnival festivities were going on in Rio, Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, and its central bank governor, Francisco Gros, flew to Washington last week to seek the help of American and international financial officials. They got tea and sympathy but no promises of more money unless they came up with a plan for bringing their country's raging inflation under control.

headline: Home Shopping Game on CBS
abstract: LEAD: Home Shopping Network Inc. said it would start broadcasting in June a half-hour program on all four television stations owned and operated by CBS. The program, called ''The Home Shopping Game Show,'' will be broadcast five times a week on CBS stations in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Philadelphia.

headline: BEIRUT MILITIAMEN MOVE ON ISRAELIS
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of Moslem militia fighters who left West Beirut last month after the arrival of Syrian troops have moved to southern Lebanon to fight against Israel, according to members of the police force and reports in the press here.

headline: Davis Extends Resorts Offer
abstract: LEAD: The KSZ Company, which is backed by Marvin Davis, the Denver billionaire, has extended its surprise $200 million offer for Resorts International Inc., the casino and real estate company, a KSZ spokesman said yesterday.

headline: Storm Shuts Some Markets
abstract: LEAD: Most commodities exchanges in New York closed early yesterday because of the snowstorm in the New York area. The New York Mercantile

headline: Advertising; A Mobile Pizza Hut Campaign
abstract: LEAD: AS a method of communicating what it considers its myriad strongpoints synergistically and within a single advertising campaign, Pizza Hut, the largest chain in the fastest-growing facet of the restaurant business, has borrowed a concept from Charles Kuralt of CBS-TV and has taken to the road.

headline: AN ALBUM OF HTE DOOMED: THE ART OF AUSCHWITZ
abstract: LEAD: Compared with the volumes of reminiscence and commentary that have been written about Auschwitz, the drawings, paintings and graffiti daubed and scratched on the walls of the death camp by its inmates are enigmatic and incomplete. And yet these marks, which an American photographer has systematically searched out and recorded, are among the few enduring expressions that prisoners and victims left of their suffering.

headline: SEOUL ELECTION PROCESS STIRRING POLITICAL CRISIS
abstract: LEAD: Many South Koreans are losing hope that their country can avert a political crisis in its search for a new way to select its national leader.

headline: THE WAR ON DRUGS BEGINS
abstract: LEAD: THE nation's advertising and media communities and many of their suppliers have been working for months on a gigantic, unprecedented advertising campaign to unsell illegal drugs. Yesterday, they disclosed their plans as the campaign was about to break in donated time and space on TV, radio, billboards, newspapers and magazines.

headline: REAGAN NOMINATES A TOP ADVISER TO BE AMBASSADOR TO SOVIET UNION
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan today nominated Jack F. Matlock Jr., one of his top advisers on East-West affairs and a Russian-language scholar, to be Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

headline: A.T.&T. Sees 'Chaos and Gridlock'
abstract: LEAD: The nation's regional telephone holding companies yesterday lauded a proposal by the Department of Justice that would permit them to enter a variety of businesses from which they are now barred.

headline: MOSCOW KIN AWAIT WORD ON DISSIDENT
abstract: LEAD: The family of the Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun said today that he was reportedly still in Chistopol prison in the Tatar republic, despite the assurance of a Soviet official on American television Sunday that he had been freed.

headline: EX-CHINESE LEADER IS SAID TO BE AILING
abstract: LEAD: Hu Yaobang, who resigned in disgrace as the chief of China's Communist Party three weeks ago, is hospitalized here, according to a Chinese source.

headline: G.&W. Sees Rise in Profit
abstract: LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc. told securities analysts yesterday that an ''exceptional performance'' by its motion picture operations would result in earnings for the first quarter of 1987 of about $1.10 a share, double the 55 cents a share reported a year ago. The estimates were said to be substantially higher than expected.

headline: Storms Sweep Mongolia
abstract: LEAD: Storms cut a swath of destruction across Mongolia last week, killing people and livestock, the official press agency Tass reported today. Tass, which did not give casualty figures, said the storms hit hardest in the steppes of the vast, thinly populated nation.

headline: ARAMCO TO PAY SAUDIS $18 A BARREL
abstract: LEAD: The group of four large American oil companies operating in Saudi Arabia said yesterday that it had agreed to long-term contracts to buy oil at $18 a barrel.

headline: SENATE FILIBUSTER CONTINUES OVER BILL TO BLOCK AID TO CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Democratic leadership failed today in a second effort to cut off a Republican filibuster that is preventing debate on a bill to block further military aid to the rebels in Nicaragua.

headline: LAST-MINUTE MANEUVERS CAN REDUCE TAX BILLS
abstract: LEAD: This time of year, as April 15 draws closer, is when the motivation to find ways to trim income tax bills is greatest, though the options available for legally outwitting the tax collector are the smallest.

headline: Medical Goods Look Profitable
abstract: LEAD: Numerous companies in the medical supplies industry have good prospects, according to an analysis by the Value Line Investment Survey.

headline: NUNN SAYS U.S. SHOULD DECLASSIFY NEGOTIATING RECORD ON ABM PACT
abstract: LEAD: Senator Sam Nunn said today that the Reagan Administration should declassify the negotiating record on the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty so the public could evaluate the Administration's assertion that the agreement would allow ''Star Wars'' testing.

headline: In Their Own Words: How the Iran-Contra Affair Took Shape
abstract: LEAD: Appendix B of the Tower Commission report, ''The Iran/Contra Affair: A Narrative,'' provides an extensive collection of documents and testimony by the participants in the arms initiative. Here are excerpts from documents cited in the appendix, including transcripts of committee interviews and messages transmitted through the White House computer system.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Allied Van Lines Inc., Chicago, appointed Peter Mazzetti president.

headline: Ford's Plans For Escort
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to continue building its Escort subcompact in the United States, according to a report in The Detroit News today.

headline: DISNEY TO ACQUIRE LOS ANGELES STATION
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire KHJ-TV, the independent television station in Los Angeles owned by RKO General Inc., a subsidiary of Gencorp Inc.

headline: Fiat Profits Rise 12.5%
abstract: LEAD: Fiat, Italy's leading industrial group, said today that its estimated operating profits rose 12.5 percent last year. Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, commenting on Fiat's performance in his annual letter to shareholders, said the operating profit rose to 2.55 trillion lire, or $1.75 billion, in 1986.

headline: Alpine Associates
abstract: LEAD: Alpine Associates, a brokerage based in Cresskill, N.J., said that it had acquired a 5.87 percent stake in the Leaseway Transportation Corporation, the car-hauling and truck-leasing concern based in Beachwood, Ohio. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alpine said that between Dec.

headline: GLOBAL ISSUES: BAKER'S VIEWS
abstract: LEAD: THE United States ran a record deficit in merchandise trade of $170 billion last year. And the broadest measure of the trade deficit, the balance of payments on current account, hit an all-time high of $140 billion. Many economists, who consider the dollar still overvalued in these circumstances, are asking why the United States agreed at the Paris ''Group of

headline: The Dow
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  Before the hosannas over the Dow Jones index get out of hand (''Tracing the Ups and Downs of the 20th Century Through the Eyes of Wall Street,'' Jan. 18), it is useful to view the matter with a bit of historical perspective. Herewith what might have been and what has been:              Dow's           Actual      Dow's           High   C.P.I.

headline: DYNAMICS TAKES A CESSNA WRITE-OFF
abstract: LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's leading military contractors, said yesterday that it was writing off about $420 million of the $680 million it paid last year for the Cessna Aircraft Company.

headline: PRESIDENT TERMED UNREADY TO YIELD ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
abstract: LEAD: One of President Reagan's most trusted advisers, former Senator Paul Laxalt, said today that he did not think Mr. Reagan was yet prepared to condemn the reasoning that led to the Iran arms deal.

headline: IRAN IS SAID TO BE SOLIDIFYING FOOTHOLD GAINED INSIDE IRAQ
abstract: LEAD: Iranian troops appear to be solidifying their foothold near the Iraqi city of Basra, gaining new patches of territory with Iraqi forces unable to dislodge them, according to United States officials.

headline: NOW LAWYERS ARE HOLLYWOOD SUPERSTARS
abstract: LEAD: AT the top of the MCA black tower, in the office recently vacated by Frank Price, Thomas Philip Pollock is hunched over a pastrami sandwich and a Diet Coke. As the new overlord of Universal movies, Mr. Pollock is at the peak of the Hollywood hierarchy. But his appointment is more than just another executive move in an industry where people change jobs as often as movie stars change cars.

headline: Tandon Job Cuts
abstract: LEAD: The Tandon Corporation said it would eliminate 175 jobs at its southern California facilities as part of its cost-cutting program and the consolidation of its production facilities in Singapore. The eliminations, which will take place over the next six to eight weeks, will pare the company's staff to about 500 employees, Ranjit Sitlani, a Tandon spokesman, said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year    In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago                          Previous   Year        In Percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago        PRIME RATE   7.50   7.50   9.50        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   5.90   6.20   7.93        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.44   5.42   7.17        6-MO.

headline: Short-Term Rates Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as bond traders' concerns about Federal Reserve Board policy intentions and next week's $29 billion Treasury refunding overshadowed interpretations and reinterpretations of the latest trade deficit figures.

headline: HAITIANS MARK THEIR FIRST YEAR WITHOUT DUVALIER
abstract: LEAD: Haitians quietly observed the first anniversary of the ouster of Jean-Claude Duvalier today with the head of the provisional Government appealing for unity and support for efforts to bring the impoverished nation to full democracy.

headline: Insurer Shows Off New Spots
abstract: LEAD: THE Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee, which almost by accident discovered the thrill of big-time advertising during the 1972 Olympics, is cutting its 1987 budget back a million dollars so it can make its splash during next year's Olympics that much bigger.

headline: CONTRAS ARE FOCUS IN 7 INVESTIGATIONS
abstract: LEAD: Several Federal agencies are pressing at least seven criminal investigations of the Nicaraguan rebels and their American backers, even as President Reagan is urging Congress to provide new aid for the contras.

headline: MORE G.M. CARS TO GET AIR BAGS
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's biggest auto maker, plans to put driver's-side airbags on 500,000 cars in 1990 and on nearly three million cars during 1992 production, G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, said. The announcement followed a similar one by the Ford Motor Company a month ago.

headline: PATENTS; VIRUS MADE FOR STUDY IF AIDS
abstract: LEAD: TWO staff members of the National Cancer Institute were granted a patent this week for a method of producing a virus that causes AIDS - acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The process creates large quantities of the virus for use in research.

headline: U.S. Budget Deficit Down
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government ran a $12.08 billion budget deficit last month, down 18 percent from the $14.66 billion deficit a year ago, the Treasury Department said today.

headline: Ex-Belgian Premier Is Guilty
abstract: LEAD: The Brussels appeals court today ruled that former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants, given a three-year suspended jail sentence in June 1986 for tax fraud and using forged documents, was also guilty of forgery.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * American Express Bank Ltd. elected Marc S. Schoenfeld senior vice president.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: LEAD: The Rexham Corporation, a maker of packaging materials and machinery, said it had received an unsolicited offer of $43 a share in cash and preferred stock from Nortek Inc., a Providence, R.I., manufacturer of building materials.

headline: SYRIANS ON PATROL IN EFFORT TO KEEP WEST BEIRUT PEACE
abstract: LEAD: Syrian troops went into action today within 24 hours of their arrival in Beirut, trading gunfire with militiamen and setting up checkpoints in an attempt to stop the fighting here.

headline: TEACHING COMPUTERS TO EMULATE BACH
abstract: LEAD: CAN a personal computer be classified as a musical instrument?

headline: Irish Guerrilla Leader's Wife Slain in Attack on Her Home
abstract: LEAD: Two gunmen burst into the home of a jailed Irish republican guerrilla leader tonight, killing the man's wife as she was bathing her two children, the police said.

headline: INSIDER-LAW ACTION ASKED
abstract: LEAD: A Senate subcommittee asked representatives of the American Bar Association today to propose new laws banning the practice of trading on confidential corporate information.

headline: CAPTIVE SAUDI DIPLOMAT FREED IN BEIRUT
abstract: LEAD: A Saudi diplomat kidnapped in West Beirut 66 days ago was freed today, 24 hours after a pro-Iranian organization said it would delay a death sentence for a French hostage for one week.

headline: DEDUCTION SEEKERS FIND BENEFITS AND BARRICADES
abstract: LEAD: Over the next few weeks, millions of Americans will see the fruits of their year-end maneuverings to take full advantage of the transition from the old tax system to the new one. But for some, the savings may be less than expected.

headline: WHEN A STAFF IS CUT
abstract: LEAD: CHANGE and transition are common enough words but they have special meaning for human resource experts. Last week William Bridges, president of Pontes Associates of Mill Valley, Calif., management consultants, spoke here on the topic before a meeting held by J.J. Gallagher Associates, an outplacement firm, for managers of some of its client companies.

headline: Kawasaki Steel Sets Job Cuts
abstract: LEAD: The Kawasaki Steel Corporation plans to reduce its work force by 5,000, bringing it down to 21,000 workers, local news reports said on Saturday.

headline: British Paper Adding Sting to Death Notices
abstract: LEAD: Death's sting has a new meaning now that The Times of London is including candid descriptions of human peccadilloes in its obituaries.

headline: Consolidated Selects Chief
abstract: LEAD: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company, a big producer and distributor of natural gas, said yesterday that George A. Davidson Jr. would become chairman and chief executive in May.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Charter Medical Corp. filed $50 million of noncallable debentures due in 2007 via Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: C.I.A. SAID TO SEND WEAPONS VIA ZAIRE TO ANGOLA REBELS
abstract: LEAD: In a highly secret operation, the Central Intelligence Agency has used an abandoned air base here to airlift arms to guerrillas in Angola, diplomatic and business sources say.

headline: Bombing in Managua
abstract: LEAD: Explosive charges damaged an electrical tower in Managua early today, and the Government said United States-backed contra rebels were responsible. It was believed to be the first time the Government had acknowledged a contra ground attack in the capital.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation is offering $300 million of 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: PROFITS ARE MIXED FOR TWO SUBSIDIARIES OF G.M.
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's computer services subsidiary, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, had sharply higher fourth-quarter profits, but earnings for the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, also a subsidiary of G.M., declined, the auto maker said today.

headline: BRAZIL TALKING TO NATIONS, NOT BANKS, ON DEBT
abstract: LEAD: In what is seen as a major change of strategy, Brazil has decided to go over the heads of foreign creditor banks and seek a long-term solution to its debt crisis in direct negotiations with governments of the United States and other industrial nations.

headline: Xerox Divesting In South Africa
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation's London affiliate, Rank Xerox Ltd., said it would sell its South African subsidiary to a South African electrical and electronics company for an undisclosed sum. Rank Xerox South Africa Ltd. will be sold to Fintech, a member of the Altron Group, Xerox said.

headline: GATES ISSUES A DEFENSE OF RECORD WITH C.I.A.
abstract: LEAD: Robert M. Gates, the Acting Director of Central Intelligence, has issued a wide-ranging defense of his record in the Iran-contra affair, denying suggestions that he ignored or covered up evidence of improprieties.

headline: DISMANTLING THE STALIN MYTH: NEW EFFORT UNDER GORBACHEV
abstract: LEAD: After a silence of more than 20 years, Stalin's crimes and his legacy have once again become the subject of public debate in the Soviet Union.

headline: Toyota Distributor To DFSD
abstract: LEAD: DFS DORLAND WORLDWIDE, a Saatchi & Saatchi company that is already the agency for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. and a number of its dealer associations, has now picked up Mid-Atlantic Toyota Distributors, based in Glen Burnie, Md. Billings are expected to be around $10 million, and the agency will open an office in

headline: MOSCOW HINTS AT AFGHANISTAN TROOP CUT
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze returned to Moscow from Kabul today amid indications that the Soviet Union would soon announce a withdrawal of some of its troops from Afghanistan.

headline: Trade Bank Chief Looks To Far East for Growth
abstract: LEAD: World Trade Bank N.A. has named John F. King chairman and chief executive of the Los Angeles-based merchant and commercial banking organization. The bank is controlled by a group of investors that includes former Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon, Roy Doumani, Larry B. Thrall and Gerald L.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Ohio Mattress Company is offering about $166 million of debt and equity through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company.

headline: Britain Sentences 4 in Mafia
abstract: LEAD: A Sicilian accused of heading the Mafia's London operations and three of his associates were given jail terms of from 22 to 25 years today after being convicted of importing heroin. The leader, Francesco Di Carlo, and the three others were arrested after customs officials found 132 pounds of the drug in May 1985.

headline: MOODY'S STUDY OF FORD RATING
abstract: LEAD: The rating of nearly $23 billion of outstanding long-term debt issued by the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Credit Company is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

headline: Citibank Pact On Manila
abstract: LEAD: Citibank N.A., which was purportedly blocking a Philippines debt rescheduling, has agreed to terms outlined by other foreign banks, banking sources said today.

headline: OPEC PANEL SESSION IS OFF
abstract: LEAD: OPEC has postponed a meeting of one of its committees because some oil ministers feared that colleagues not on the panel might attend anyway and effectively make it a full session of the organization, OPEC sources said today. A full meeting now could unsettle the jittery oil market.

headline: SYRIANS, SEEKING ORDER, WIPE OFF GRAFFITI LEFT BY MILITIAS IN BEIRUT
abstract: LEAD: City workers, aided by teen-agers and supervised by Syrian soldiers, wiped political slogans off walls today and took down street signs and photographs that rival militias had put up throughout West Beirut.

headline: Contra Political Chief Will Quit Triumvirate
abstract: LEAD: Arturo Jose Cruz, a key political leader of the Nicaraguan rebels, has confirmed that he is resigning because of dissatisfaction with other rebel leaders.

headline: Market Place; Some Bears Stick to Guns
abstract: LEAD: JANUARY'S sizzling rally in stocks has dispatched most market bears into hibernation - for a while, at least. ''Money managers who were sitting with cash late last year now are jumping in to buy,'' said Theodore Halligan, an institutional salesman for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood. ''They figure they can't afford to miss an up market like this one.

headline: SEOUL MAKES IT EASY TO SAY GOODBYE
abstract: LEAD: With the same singleminded drive that transformed South Korea's economy in little more than a generation, the Government here is pressing an ambitious program to groom aspiring emigrants for life overseas.

headline: Pepsico Rise of 30.6%
abstract: LEAD: Pepsico Inc., citing lower tax rates and fewer shares outstanding, said yesterday that earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter rose 30.6 percent on a 35.1 increase in sales.

headline: AMID THREATS AND WAR, ISLAM'S CHIEFS SEEK UNITY
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the Moslem world gathered here today for an Islamic organization ''unity'' meeting that was overshadowed by a war, virtually within earshot, between two of the organization's most powerful members.

headline: San Antonio Bond Sale Gets Warm Reception
abstract: LEAD: A $160 million competitive bond sale by San Antonio was well received by investors yesterday, when the issue of tax-exempt revenue bonds was priced through an underwriting group led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The revenue bonds issued by the city's utility system are one of the highest rated in the country.

headline: THATCHER, IN SOVIET, LINKS ARMS PACT TO RIGHTS
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived in Moscow today with a message that progress on East-West arms control depended on Soviet observance of human rights.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE TOWER COMMISSION'S REPORT  APPENDIX B
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the report of the President's Special Review Board, which was made public yesterday in Washington:

headline: BEIJING PROPAGANDA AIDE OUT
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party's propaganda chief, a proponent of liberalization, has been dismissed, the Foreign Ministry said today.

headline: European Farm Talks
abstract: LEAD: Farm ministers of the European Community opened their first substantial debate today on a proposed freeze of guaranteed farm product prices for 1987. The bloc's executive commission is seeking to hold down prices to reduce the community's large farm surpluses.

headline: Embassy in Soviet Reassigns Marines for Currency Crimes
abstract: LEAD: Several Marine guards were reassigned from their postings at the American Embassy here after an internal investigation indicated they had been involved in illegal currency transactions, Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman said today.

headline: A SHEARSON SALE MAY BE IN WORKS
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company has been planning to sell a significant minority stake in its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. securities brokerage subsidiary to the public, or to a foreign financial concern, in a step that could sharply increase Shearson's capital, sources close to the companies said yesterday.

headline: Bonn Drops Bribe Case Against an Ex-Official
abstract: LEAD: A prosecutor today asked a court today to acquit Otto Lambsdorff, a former Economics Minister and a senior figure in the Free Democratic Party, of charges he accepted $50,000 between 1977 and 1980 from the Flick concern in return for granting lucrative tax waivers.

headline: GORBACHEV OFFER: 2 OTHER ARMS HINTS
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to sign an agreement eliminating Soviet and American medium-range missiles in Europe offers tantalizing hints of movement on two other arms-control fronts, according to Western diplomats here.

headline: A.T.&T. BONUSES
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which is offering bonuses to managers at its debt-ridden Information Systems division, has revised the scope of the bonuses. It said that 32,000 managers would receive bonuses totaling at least $16 million. The company had said last week that 24,000 managers would get bonuses totaling more than $12 million.

headline: WEST BEIRUT FIGHT KILLS AT LEAST 24
abstract: LEAD: Shiite Moslem militiamen fought an alliance of Druse and Communist gunmen for a third day today in the fiercest factional fighting in West Beirut in three years.

headline: American Medical Rejects Pesch Bid
abstract: LEAD: American Medical International Inc., the big West Coast hospital chain, said yesterday that it had ''no interest in pursuing'' a $1.74 billion takeover bid from LeRoy A. Pesch, a Chicago physician.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * J. Bildner & Sons, a Boston-based food marketer, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.

headline: GROUP OWNS 5.9% OF PUROLATOR
abstract: LEAD: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York investment firm, and its affiliates said they had purchased a 5.9 percent stake in the Purolator Courier Corporation. The Purolator board has accepted a $268 million leveraged buyout proposal from a management group led by E.F. Hutton LBO Inc. But last week, a director of the air-freight concern, which is based in Basking Ridge, N

headline: A YEAR AFTER CHAOS, SHAMIR IS VOTED PARTY CHIEF
abstract: LEAD: A year after its convention broke up in chaos and fistfights, the right-wing Herut Party reconvened today and elected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as its chairman.

headline: Begin Won't Meet Carter
abstract: LEAD: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin today turned down a request by former President Jimmy Carter to meet in Jerusalem on the anniversary of the signing of the Israel-Egypt peace treaty, Yechiel Kadishai, a spokesman for Mr. Begin, said. He said Mr. Begin did not give a reason for declining.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD: In percent           Passbook Savings   5.50        At savings institutions               Tax-Exempt Bonds   6.57        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   5.45        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.41        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   9.86        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average

headline: U.S. TO REPLACE TOP NATO COMMANDER
abstract: LEAD: Defense Department officials said today that General Bernard W. Rogers would retire in June as Supreme Allied Commander of NATO forces in Europe and would be replaced by General John R. Galvin, now commander of United States forces in Latin America.

headline: U.S Eases Net-Worth Rule to Help Thrift Units
abstract: LEAD: Responding to heavy pressure from Congress, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced a new policy that would permit beleaguered thrift institutions, particularly in the depressed Southwest, to continue operating, even if their net worth falls to almost zero.

headline: Iran Reports Civilian Deaths as Iraqis Raid Cities
abstract: LEAD: Iraq said its warplanes bombed the Iranian capital, Teheran, and nine other cities today. Iran disputed the report of a bombing of Teheran but confirmed Iraqi raids on eight other cities and reported civilians were killed or wounded in them.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: Capitol Hill; Panels' Plans: Subpoenas and Immunity Will Be Used to Invigorate Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the special Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra arms case said today that they would use important tools such as subpoena power that were not available to the Tower commission to expand on the commission's findings.

headline: Ready For Geneva
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union was willing to sign ''without delay'' an agreement to eliminate Soviet and American medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe within five years.

headline: SERENADING THE LOST LAMBS OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
abstract: LEAD: Adam Hanuszkiewicz, who was dismissed five years ago as director of Poland's national theater because of his activities in the Solidarity period, has just been invited to the Ministry of Culture for talks about a new job. Films blocked by censors since 1981 are being released, and some artists and writers who shunned Government contact after martial law was declared are being asked to take tea with Gen.

headline: Dow Falls by 10.13; Dollar Drop Cited
abstract: LEAD: Trading volume was light yesterday on Wall Street and stock prices drifted lower after a sharp drop in the dollar's value brought on new fears that the Federal Reserve's ability to cut interest rates might be hampered.

headline: MUTTERING ABOUT SUHARTO, BUT IT'S NEVER IN PUBLIC
abstract: LEAD: When President Suharto announced last fall that he would seek a fifth term in office in 1988, he focused attention on a question that cannot be publicly debated here: How long can - or should - he stay in power?

headline: BENIFICIAL WILL SELL SIX INSURANCE UNITS
abstract: LEAD: The Beneficial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell six insurance operations, including the American Centennial Insurance Company, to the management of American Centennial.

headline: U.S. CHIP MAKERS PLAN CONSORTIUM
abstract: LEAD: United States manufacturers of computer chips, battered by financial losses and competition from Japan, are laying the groundwork for an ambitious cooperative venture in a bid to regain the lead in microelectronics technology.

headline: ISRAEL SETTING UP SPY CASE INQUIRY
abstract: LEAD: After an eight-hour debate, the Israeli Cabinet announced today that it was setting up a two-member ''investigation commission'' on the Israeli espionage operation in Washington.

headline: MAN FOUND HANGED IN A TRANSVAAL POLICE CELL
abstract: LEAD: A young man jailed under South Africa's emergency laws was found hanged in a police cell in the Transvaal early today, the police said.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Presidency; At a Crossroads
abstract: LEAD: The presidency of Ronald Reagan, who only a few months ago commanded the widest popularity of any postwar chief executive, reached what may well be its decisive moment with the issuance of the report of his review board today. At a time when the

headline: TARIFFS SEEN LOSING SUPPORT
abstract: LEAD: The public's support for tariffs and other trade barriers has measurably declined, a nationwide poll has found.

headline: P.L.O. IS BOLSTERED BY KUWAITI MONEY
abstract: LEAD: A new influx of Arab money will bolster the Palestine Liberation Organization's political base in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, in a move seen here as undercutting King Hussein of Jordan.

headline: Lavi Proposal Criticized
abstract: LEAD: Deputy Under Secretary of Defense Dov Zakheim arrived here today hoping to persuade Israel to ground its American-funded Lavi warplane project in favor of less-expensive aircraft. In an interview in Washington, he said he would suggest several alternatives to the Lavi, a single-engine fighter resembling an American F-16.

headline: Tough British Takeover Rules
abstract: LEAD: In response to the scandal over the manipulation of Guinness's stock price, Britain's Takeover Panel has drastically strengthened the rules governing corporate mergers to increase disclosures of share trading during takeover bids.

headline: SHULTZ PLANS TRIP TO SOVIET IN APRIL, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will go to Moscow in mid-April to hold talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, the White House announced today.

headline: Advertising; PEOPLE
abstract: LEAD: Kenneth A. Glaser has been appointed senior vice president, director of business development at Muller Jordan Weiss.

headline: OBSTACLES SEEN IN MANILA DEBT PLAN
abstract: LEAD: The innovative plan by the Philippines to service its foreign debt in the form of notes that are essentially i.o.u.'s has raised a host of issues -accounting, economic, and political -that threaten to doom the plan even before it gets started, financial experts said over the weekend.

headline: Local Bacterium Makes Good
abstract: LEAD: In their quest for a new antibiotic, researchers at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research sifted through soil samples taken from around the world. They tested millions of bacteria, looking for just the right one to combat serious hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and septicemia, caused by gram-negative organisms.

headline: The U.N. Today: Jan. 14, 1987
abstract: LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Status of Women -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: South Korea Seizes 13 And Tries to Stop Rally
abstract: LEAD: The Government moved against its opponents on two fronts today, announcing the arrests of 13 purported campus revolutionaries and later seeking to block an indoor rally by the mainstream opposition.

headline: U.S. HAS ACQUIRED SOVIET T-72 TANKS
abstract: LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency has obtained several Soviet T-72 tanks, which are the mainstay of the extensive Soviet armored force, Government officials said today.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Chattem Inc. to Tracy-Locke, Dallas, for its Corn Silk cosmetics.

headline: Wheeling Names A New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Lloyd C. Lubensky was named chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation late yesterday, succeeding George A. Ferris. Mr. Ferris, who was named chairman only two months ago, resigned not only that post but his positions as director, vice-chairman, and chief executive. The steel company is in bankruptcy preceedings.

headline: YUGOSLAV WARNS AGAINST STRIKES
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Branko Mikulic, facing widespread strikes and rising political dissent, was quoted today as saying the army would be used if necessary to defend the country's Communist political system.

headline: Fuming
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  Shouldn't we fault the Federal Government for speaking with a forked tongue where tobacco consumption is concerned? On the one hand, the Surgeon General cautions against use of the weed; on the other, Washington continues its generous subsidies to tobacco growers.  THOMAS G.

headline: Blast Kills Swedish Woman
abstract: LEAD: An explosion abroad the British tanker O. T. Gerth in the Seine River estuary today killed a Swedish woman in the crew and injured eight other crew members. A fire tug moved in and put out the fire.

headline: Emerson Gets Thom McAn
abstract: LEAD: Emerson Lane Fortuna, a six-year-old Boston firm, has stepped up to the Thom McAn Shoe Company account. The agency said the budget is $10 million.

headline: GORBACHEV SAID TO SUPPORT TALKS DESPITE HIS DOUBTS ABOUT REAGAN
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told a group of former American officials this week that he wanted to press ahead with arms control talks but was uncertain whether President Reagan retained sufficient political strength to negotiate, one of the Americans said today.

headline: RELIGIOUS TENSIONS IN EGYPT CLAIM A LIFE
abstract: LEAD: A woman was killed and scores of people have been arrested in renewed fighting between Moslems and Coptic Christians, the police said today.

headline: Cattle Prices Advance While Pork Declines
abstract: LEAD: Cattle futures prices advanced yesterday despite lower wholesale beef prices. Pork declined, with some pork belly deliveries suffering limit losses.

headline: Losses at 2 Texas Banks
abstract: LEAD: Two of Texas's largest banks today reported losses in the fourth quarter, and a third reported a decline in profits. All three are involved in pending mergers.

headline: Canadian Tire Bid By CTC Blocked
abstract: LEAD: Government regulators blocked a takeover bid worth $270 million, or about $198 million in United States currency, for the Canadian Tire Corporation, Canada's largest automotive and hardware retail chain, by a group of Canadian Tire store operators. A ruling by the Ontario and Quebec securities commissions stopped the store dealers, represented by CTC Dealer Holdings Ltd., from acquiring 49 percent of Canadian Tire's common shares at a price of $160.24, or about $117.76 American, each.

headline: Backing Draws S.&P. Triple-A
abstract: LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation says it will give a triple-A rating to bonds insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, a new entity owned by four of the five members of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association.

headline: STOCK RECORDS SET IN FACE OF SCANDAL
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices soared to another record yesterday as Wall Street shrugged off the anxiety generated by its latest insider-trading scandal.

headline: I.R.S. OFFERS EASIER FORM, THE W-4A
abstract: LEAD: Bowing to complaints, the Internal Revenue Service today presented a simpler, shorter and more colorful W-4 withholding form. Officials hope taxpayers find the new form less forbidding than the earlier version.

headline: PLANT USE SHOWS GAIN
abstract: LEAD: The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities in December climbed to the highest level since last February, the Federal Reserve Board said today. The report is another sign of a recovery in the nation's manufacturing sector.

headline: Taylor-Gordon Getting Coca-Cola Watch Task
abstract: LEAD: Coca-Cola Watch, a division of Swatch Watch USA, at 608 Fifth Avenue, which did its own advertising, has decided to move its nearly $1 million budget next door to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, at 604.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Lotus Development Corporation, Cambridge, Mass., a microcomputer software company, to Leonard Monahan Saabye, Providence, R.I.

headline: Technology Ban Report Is Criticized
abstract: LEAD: A senior Pentagon official assailed today a report that said efforts to keep high technology from Soviet-bloc countries had cost thousands of Americans jobs and billions of dollars in lost trade without greatly improving national security.

headline: S.&P. Reduces Ratings Of 6 Banking Concerns
abstract: LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that primarily because of the continuing debt crisis in developing nations, it had lowered its debt ratings of several major bank holding companies - the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical New York Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Irving Bank

headline: SEOUL GIVES SHULTZ A DEMOCRACY VOW
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was reported today to have won assurances from President Chun Doo Hwan that he would seek a compromise with the opposition on what form an elected government would take.

headline: PATENTS; Spurring Ingenuity In Children
abstract: LEAD: A NATIONWIDE program designed to stimulate inventiveness in American school-age children will start on Feb. 5 with a three-day conference here for 600 teachers. Sponsored by the United States Patent Model Foundation, the program, ''Invent America!,'' is expected to involve 85,000 elementary schools throughout the country.

headline: COST IS $1.5 BILLION
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the American Motors Corporation for about $1.5 billion.

headline: Reagan Likely to Lift Polish Sanctions Soon
abstract: LEAD: An Administration official said today that President Reagan was expected to lift trade sanctions against Poland and might announce his decision this week.

headline: REAGAN TO SPEAK TO INVESTIGATORS
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will submit to questioning Monday by his special commission that is examining the National Security Council in light of the Iran-contra affair, the White House announced today.

headline: United Financial Officer
abstract: LEAD: Frank R. Jarc, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Wilson Foods Corporation, will join United Airlines as senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective Feb. 2. Mr. Jarc, 44 years old, worked for Gould Inc. before joining Wilson, which is based in Oklahoma City.

headline: 'Gray Market' Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has upheld a ruling that permits ''gray market'' trading. The ruling, which involved a suit filed on behalf of Cal Circuit Abco of Woodland Hills, Calif., held that buying foreign goods cheaply overseas and reselling them in the United States without concealing their origin does not violate the trademark rights of an American subsidiary of the manufacturer.

headline: Swiss Account Holders Challenge Iran Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: At least eight parties linked to Swiss bank accounts in the American investigation of the Iran affair have appealed a Swiss decision to give legal assistance to the United States, Swiss authorities said today.

headline: Trump Condominium Account Lost by Beber
abstract: LEAD: Beber Siberstein & Partners of Miami, which lost the Helmsley Hotel business because it also took on the Trump Plaza, now abuilding in Palm Beach, Fla., has now also lost that Trump condominium.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP A SCANT 0.1%
abstract: LEAD: Producer prices rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent last month, with lower prices for food and automobiles largely offsetting fresh rises in energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.

headline: FLOOR PRICE PROPOSED
abstract: LEAD: A plan to provide greater energy security -first proposed by the Ford Administration in the mid-1970's - was revived before a Congressional committee today by James R. Schlesinger, who served as Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration.

headline: DEFENSE RIDICULES ISRAELI TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: The defense at the trial of a man accused of being a Nazi death-camp murderer denounced the proceeding today as a a ''show trial'' reminiscent of Soviet propaganda court cases.

headline: Paying Up-Front For Aerospace Projects
abstract: LEAD: THE outlook for the economy in 1987 looks all-too-familiar: another sluggish year with worries about too much debt and too little growth to drive the unemployment rate much below today's 6.9 percent.

headline: Dow Off 8.68, to 2,258.66; Loss for Week Is 21.57
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell yesterday in lighter trading volume, as Wall Street seemed to become nervous about the ''triple witching hour'' a week in advance.

headline: WHO'S THE HEIR APPARANT? IT'S NOT YET APPARENT
abstract: LEAD: In the half-dozen city restaurants where the bureaucratic and political elite have breakfast the talk these mornings is of little else but the selection of Mexico's next President.

headline: No Progress Seen In Airbus Talks
abstract: LEAD: Talks between American and European officials over subsidies for Airbus Industrie, the European airliner manufacturing consortium, made no progress today in what threatens to become a major trade dispute, the officials said. At the same time, Airbus announced in Paris that it had its best January ever, receiving orders worth $5 billion.

headline: G.M. CHIEF SEES PROFIT GAIN SOON
abstract: LEAD: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that his company's cost-cutting efforts would start to improve earnings this year, but many analysts doubt that big short-term gains are likely.

headline: CABOT ADVERTISING WINS HEALTH PLAN ACCOUNT
abstract: LEAD: The Harvard Community Health Plan of Brookline, Mass., had Rizzo, Simons, Cohn of Boston as its ad agency. Then it merged with the Multi Group Health Plan, which also had an agency, Mintz & Hoke of Avon, Conn.

headline: NEW ENVOY TO PUSH U.S. ROLE IN MEXICO DRUG FIGHT
abstract: LEAD: The new American Ambassador to Mexico plans to substantially revamp United States participation in a program with the Mexican Government to combat narcotics production, according to his advisers.

headline: Advertising; Caroline Jones Back In Business
abstract: LEAD: ARDENT observers of the adver-tising scene read last November that Caroline Jones was leaving Mingo-Jones Advertising and would be starting her own agency. Then all was quiet.  Yesterday at a press conference at the Pierre, she announced not only that there was a new agency in town but also that a minority owner of Caroline Jones Advertising would be Lorimar-Telepictures, a publicly held company that is a leading producer of TV programming and also owns Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt and U

headline: INDIA SEEKING AID ON BEIRUT CAPTIVE
abstract: LEAD: Indian officials have appealed to Syria and Iran for help in freeing an Indian professor who is among the foreigners kidnapped in Beirut, a nephew of the professor said today.

headline: British Ponder Some Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The British Government may revoke the licenses of selected Japanese banks and securities companies to operate in London if progress is not made toward opening Japan's markets to foreigners, according to Government sources.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Six: October 1986 Sale of 500 U.S. TOW Missiles and Various Hawk Missle System Spare Parts
abstract: LEAD: STEP 1: Iranian representatives (the Second Channel) deposit $7 million into Lake Resources account on September 26  [ 1 ]  to cover purchase of 500 TOW's and additional HAWK spares. STEP 2: Lake Resources transfers $2.037 to the C.I.A. Swiss account. Because of a communications failure between North and Secord, the deposit is made to a closed account.

headline: Night Trading Is Proposed
abstract: LEAD: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to open the first evening trading session for a United States-based exchange. The plan, approved by the 22-member board, would allow the Chicago Board of Trade to offer exchange-based Treasury bond futures and options between 5 P.M. and 9 P.M., central time.

headline: Soviet Reservoir Is Polluted
abstract: LEAD: The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said today that the Rybinsk Reservoir on the Volga River was polluted last winter by a chemical spill. The paper said oil products and other chemicals had spilled into the reservoir from a coke-chemical plant producing ammonia, phenol and benzene. Residents of the steel center of

headline: HECK'S FILES FOR PROTECTION
abstract: LEAD: Heck's Inc., a large regional discount store chain that has been struggling with losses, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

headline: Inventories Fell 0.2% in November
abstract: LEAD: Business inventories, which had shot up in October, edged down two-tenths of 1 percent in November, while total business sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: The Great Conciliator: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
abstract: LEAD: Howard H. Baker had always said that when the President asks you to do something, it's hard to say no.

headline: I.B.M. to Ship Computers Early
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would begin shipping its new midrange computers, the system 9370, two months earlier than planned. Two models of the new computers - known in the industry as ''VAX killers'' because they are aimed at the Digital Equipment Corporation's VAX line - will be available in July.

headline: MEXICO'S LARGEST UNIVERSITY EMBROILED IN FEES CONTROVERSY
abstract: LEAD: For the last week, an unusual series of discussions has been taking place at the National Autonomous University. Student leaders and university officials have been meeting in an effort to overcome an impasse over the university's plans to increase fees and strengthen academic standards.
