headline: Market Place; Rediscovering A.M.C.'s Stock
abstract: LEAD: THE American Motors Corporation, everyone agrees, has been having difficulty selling cars lately. During the latest 10-day reporting period in mid-February, A.M.C., the nation's fifth-largest auto manufacturer, disclosed that it had sold only 725 cars.

headline: FRANCE PLAYS DOWN LATEST LIBYAN AIR RAID IN SOUTHERN CHAD
abstract: LEAD: France today played down the importance of a Libyan air attack in southern Chad on Wednesday, indicating that it was planning no immediate retaliation.

headline: SIHANOUK'S SON JOINS FATHER'S FIGHT
abstract: LEAD: Eight years ago this month, when the Vietnamese Army marched into Phnom Penh and overthrew Pol Pot, Prince Norodom Ranariddh was living the untroubled life of a university lecturer in France.

headline: ARRESTS INDICATE GET-TOUGH VIEW OF OFFICE CRIME
abstract: LEAD: The abrupt arrest of three prominent figures on Wall Street indicates that the Government now feels it has the upper hand against insider trading abuses, having gathered enough evidence to bring charges against important individuals whether they cooperate or not.

headline: F.S.L.I.C. AID GAINS IN SENATE
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Banking Committee, as part of a wide-ranging banking measure, voted this evening to provide $7.5 billion for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation over the next two years.

headline: Ousted Soviet Official Faces Corruption Inquiry, Tass Says
abstract: LEAD: An ousted Politburo member will be investigated by Communist leaders in Kazakhstan to determine possible links to corruption and other abuses in the republic, Tass, the official press agency reported today.

headline: Texas Businessman Nominated for Fed
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan, confirming widely circulated reports, announced yesterday that he would name Edward W. Kelley, Jr., a Houston businessman, to the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: WHY I.R.A.'S MAYU NO LONGER PAY OFF
abstract: LEAD: Below are answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.  Q.

headline: BUSINESS AND THE LAW;
abstract: LEAD: TO a 25-year-old, third-year law student about to embark on a career at one of New York's top firms this fall, the prospect of making $80,000 in the first year at work is nothing short of exhilarating.

headline: Texas Port Bonds Taxable, Insured
abstract: LEAD: The Port of Houston yesterday offered nearly $31 million of taxable bonds through Masterson & Company in the first taxable municipal bond issue to be insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation. The bonds, which are rated triple-A, were issued in taxable form because more than 10 percent of the issue is to finance private business facilities at the port.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD: Good News for Little Guys?

headline: Choice of Baker Welcomed in Congress
abstract: LEAD: Republican and Democratic leaders today praised the appointment of the former Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., as President Reagan's new chief of staff.

headline: Kodak Charge Of $225 Million
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would take a larger-than-expected charge of $225 million against 1986 earnings to reflect costs associated with its work force reduction program.

headline: Soviet and Sudan Sign 3-Year Trade Accord
abstract: LEAD: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 21 (AP) -

headline: UNICORP REDUCES STAKE IN PUROLATOR
abstract: LEAD: The Unicorp Canada Corporation has lowered its stake in the Purolator Courier Corporation to 3.4 percent, from 12.6 percent, ending its attempt to influence the air-freight concern. When Unicorp acquired its Purolator stake last fall, the Toronto-based diversified gas utility said that it did not intend to be a ''passive investor.

headline: German Blast Toll Up to 9
abstract: LEAD: The death toll from the gas explosion and fire at a luxury hotel at this winter sports resort on Saturday has risen to nine with the death of a badly burned youth, the police said today. They said two of the 10 other people injured in the disaster at the Hotel Riessersee were still in critical condition.

headline: IRAN PANELS PLAN LIMITED IMMUNITY
abstract: LEAD: Moving to obtain more information about the Reagan Administration's actions to help the rebel forces in Nicaragua, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair plan to grant limited immunity from prosecution to a former White House official and to a key figure in the private supply network that aided the insurgents, people familiar with the committees' operations said today.

headline: A.M.C. Delays Chrysler Action
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation said today its board had reviewed the Chrysler Corporation's merger proposal but had taken no action on it.

headline: BARYSHNIKOV BARS MOSCOW VISIT NOW
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov said yesterday that he will not take part in a three-day conference on science and the arts that begins Saturday in Moscow.

headline: AQUINO, IN AREA OF A REVOLT, BRIEFLY MEETS REBEL OFFICIAL
abstract: LEAD: Under heavy military protection, President Corazon C. Aquino flew briefly today to this city, which for the last week has been the center of the heaviest Moslem fighting in years.

headline: Kodak Will Sell Fox Retail Labs
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said it plans to sell the retail labs of Fox Photo, the photofinishing company it bought three months ago for $95.5 million. But Kodak will retain Fox's 20 wholesale photofinishing labs, which are among the biggest users of Kodak color paper.

headline: MANILA AND REBELS REACH AGREEMENT ON TALKS
abstract: LEAD: Government and Communist negotiators agreed today on a general ''framework'' for peace talks that appeared to open the way for a possible resolution of their deadlock over an agenda.

headline: Figure in Palme Inquiry Leaves Stockholm Job
abstract: LEAD: Hans Holmer, the man who for a year led the unsuccessful hunt for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme, has resigned as Stockholm's police chief, saying that the investigation had turned into a shambles.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Harper & Row Publishers Inc. said its board had approved a recapitalization plan providing for the creation of a new class B common stock having 10 votes a share.

headline: Vatican Announces Pope's Latin Itinerary
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to meet with the Chilean leader, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, and then celebrate Palm Sunday in Argentina during his spring visit to South America, the Vatican announced today.

headline: PRUDENTIAL INVEST IN SHAMROCK
abstract: LEAD: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation announced a complex recapitalization plan today, including a large investment by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, in an 11th-hour effort to block an unfriendly takeover attempt by an investor group led by T. Boone Pickens.

headline: U.S. TO DECIDE PHONE OF FUTURE
abstract: LEAD: The future of American telecommunications is now on the drawing boards with a new state-of-the-art telephone network that the Federal Government plans to be using by 1990.

headline: Citicorp Offer On Cyclops Bid
abstract: LEAD: A Citicorp unit said today that it would drop its bid to buy the Cyclops Corporation if a rival bidder, Dixons Group P.L.C., would sell it Cyclops's industrial division for $124.4 million. Citicorp Capital Investors

headline: JERSEY'S SELLOFF STARTS MARKET'S FALL
abstract: LEAD: With the State of New Jersey unloading shares in companies that do business with South Africa and some program traders trying to get out of the line of fire before Friday's ''triple witching hour,'' stock prices fell sharply at the opening yesterday and never fully recovered.

headline: Albania Schedules Elections
abstract: LEAD: Albania will hold parliamentary elections on Feb. 1, with Ramiz Alia, the Albanian leader, running in the constitutency of his predecessor, Enver Hoxha, the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug said today. The last Albanian parliamentary elections were in November 1982.

headline: Inflation Slowed in '86
abstract: LEAD: The average increase in consumer prices in 24 industrialized Western countries last year was the lowest in 22 years, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. It said on Friday that prices rose an average 2.8 percent in 1986 for the smallest increase since a 2.4 percent advance in 1964.

headline: WEST GERMAN VOTE: VICTORY FOR A WEAKENED KOHL
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl won an unsatisfying victory Sunday in parliamentary elections that many politicians say could make the next four years at the helm of a center-right coalition much more arduous than the last four.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The TV Coverage; How the Story of the Commission Report Played on the Networks
abstract: LEAD: By one significant measure - how the story played on television - the Tower Commission's report was big, but not bigger than ''The Cosby Show.''

headline: Jakarta Gymnastics By Any Other Name
abstract: LEAD: President Suharto of Indonesia has put an end to the controversy over the use of Chinese fitness techniques by ordering that the exercises be given Indonesian names, The Jakarta Post reported today.

headline: GRACE'S UNCERTAIN SUCCESSION
abstract: LEAD: It is the stuff of business lore: the battle for the executive suite. At W. R. Grace & Company, three men are pitted against each other, fighting to be the next chief executive.

headline: Finance Group Lobbies For More Deregulation
abstract: LEAD: A lobbying group made up of some of the nation's largest financial concerns said today that it would push for widespread deregulation of the financial industry.

headline: MILOVAN DJILAS GETS PASSPORT, FIRST SINCE TRAVEL BAN IN 1969
abstract: LEAD: The Government has given its most prominent dissident, Milovan Djilas, permission to travel abroad.

headline: American General Cuts Pogo Stake
abstract: LEAD: The American General Corporation has lowered its stake in the Pogo Producing Company, the Houston-based oil and gas exploration company, to the equivalent of 7.1 percent, or 1.39 million shares, from 13.1 percent.

headline: NEW MCI STRATEGY: DEREGULATE A.T.&T.
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation yesterday called for full deregulation of its chief long-distance competitor, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has been forced by the Government to cut its rates drastically.

headline: 10,000 Jews Expected To Leave Soviet in '87
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet official said today that he expected 10,000 to 12,000 Jews to emigrate this year, more than 10 times the number of those allowed to emigrate in 1986.

headline: Europe Inflation Up
abstract: LEAD: Inflation in the European Community, which fell in the fourth quarter to its lowest rate in 25 years, rose in February, figures from the community's statistics office, Eurostat, showed today.

headline: Reaction in Washington
abstract: LEAD: An American trade official said today that he did not expect the production cutbacks announced by Japan to have much effect on the coming White House decision on whether to impose sanctions against the Japanese.

headline: New Executive Lineup Follows Pandick Buyout
abstract: LEAD: A new management lineup, with Anthony K. Moulton as chief executive, is emerging at Pandick Inc., the New York-based financial printing company, after the completion of a management buyout this week.

headline: Japan Bond Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese Ministry of Finance has approved a plan to increase the participation of foreign banks and securities firms in 10-year government bond sales. In Japan, the 10-year bonds are allocated among banks and securities firms rather than sold through competitive bidding. Although the foreign allocation remains small, it was a step to placate American Government officials and securities dealers who have complained that they are denied access to the Japanese market while Japanese firms compete freely in the American market.

headline: Approval Sought For Bacterial Tests
abstract: LEAD: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. has applied once again to conduct a field test of genetically altered bacteria intended to protect plants from frost damage. Advanced Genetic Sciences said that it had submitted two proposed sites in California: one near Brentwood, about 30 miles east of Oakland, and the other near Hollister, about 50 miles south of San Jose.

headline: HAITIAN ASSEMBLY WORKS TO DRAFT A DEMOCRACY
abstract: LEAD: When elections were held last fall to create an assembly to write a new constitution for Haiti, the prevailing sentiments were indifference and skepticism, and very few people voted.

headline: New Xerox Copier
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced a mid-volume copier that offers features normally available only on the company's largest copiers and can use them without sacrificing speed. The machine, which makes 62 copies a minute, uses a microprocessor as powerful as five personal computers. The 1065 sells for $23,095 and will be available by May.

headline: Media Company Interests Davis
abstract: LEAD: Marvin Davis, who made his fortune in the oil business and then bought and sold the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation is now interested in acquiring Lexington Broadcasting Services, a barter syndication company, according to an executive at Grey Advertising, which controls a large block of Lexington's stock.

headline: Taft Shares Up $9, to $136
abstract: LEAD: The stock of the Taft Broadcasting Company rose sharply yesterday on reports that two major shareholders were holding talks on the future of the company.

headline: Smoking
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  Frederick Thayer  [ Letters, Jan. 18 ]  says that when the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that environmental tobacco smoke is a danger to non-smokers, the public should suspect a conspiracy. A more normal reaction would be to have increased confidence in the assertion that passive smoking is a major health hazard.

headline: WANT TO SWIM, OR MAYBE SHOP? TRY A SKI RESORT
abstract: LEAD: THE first snow of the winter is on the ground and the wind is howling outside as the staff of the Bolton Valley ski area gathers for a meeting. The talk is of Bolton Valley's new gourmet restaurant, of improvements to the health club, of the finishing touches on the just-completed 65-unit hotel/condominium, of the child care center schedule, of its four new boutiques.

headline: GROUP SEEKS TO FREEZE $2 FEE ON PHONE ACCESS
abstract: LEAD: A coalition of consumer groups and their supporters in Congress have started a campaign to freeze the $2 service charge imposed on millions of telephone subscribers each month for access to their local telephone company.

headline: CURB ASKED ON FOREIGN TAKEOVERS
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration will consider policies to block foreign takeovers of companies in security-sensitive industries, officials said today.

headline: India Replies To Carbide
abstract: LEAD: The Indian Government charged today that the Union Carbide Corporation was aware of a potential disaster before the gas leak disaster at Bhopal, but failed to design its plant there to safeguard against it.

headline: 2 Renominated To Bank Board
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has renominated Lawrence White and Lee Henkel for positions on the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates Federally insured savings and loan associations. The nominations were announced Friday.

headline: Captors Drop Deadline; Beirut Bomb Kills 17
abstract: LEAD: Kidnappers holding four Western hostages reiterated that they would kill their captives at midnight tonight unless 400 Arab prisoners were freed by Israel, then, as the deadline passed, announced that it had been extended ''until further notice.''

headline: A.M.C. MAY PRODUCE ANOTHER CHRYSLER LINE
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation are apparently close to a deal for A.M.C. to produce a second line of Chrysler cars at its assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis. But labor and financing difficulties may still block the project, officials of both companies have said.

headline: FALLEN DEAL MAKER REGARDED AS TOP CORPORATE PROTECTOR
abstract: LEAD: Often enough in recent years, whenever a corporation came under a takeover attack, its executives were on the telephone with Martin A. Siegel. In the process, the 38-year-old whiz kid made a reputatiion as an adroit protector of corporations, and made himself a fortune. Yesterday, his prestige, and much of the fortune, was gone.

headline: DOW NEARS 2,300 WITH 12.64 RISE
abstract: LEAD: The ''triple witching hour'' loomed large over the stock market yesterday, but the pressure eased enough to permit the Dow Jones industrial average to close within a point of 2,300.

headline: PATENTS; GAUGING REACTOR COOLANT
abstract: LEAD: A GAUGE that monitors the level of coolant in nuclear power reactors was patented this week by five inventors in the Pennsylvania State University's nuclear engineering department. It is intended to prevent accidents caused by the loss of cooling water, as occurred at the Three Mile Island nuclear generating station in

headline: Beirut Magazine Predicts a Release of Waite
abstract: LEAD: The magazine that first reported that the United States had secretly sold arms to Iran said today that the Anglican emissary Terry Waite was in captivity but would be freed next week.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Fletcher Corp., Indianapolis, said its acquistion by Banc One Corp. had been completed.

headline: CONTRA CHEIF SAYS NORTH ARRANGED FOR PAYMENTS
abstract: LEAD: A top contra official, Arturo Cruz, said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had questioned him twice in recent months about the role Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North played in arranging a $7,000 monthly allowance for Mr. Cruz for most of last year.

headline: Article 116287 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Waste Management Inc. today began a tender offer valued at $270 million for the Chemlawn Corporation, which provides lawn care services.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Vice President; Bush Insists the Intention Was Not Arms for Hostages
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he agreed it would be ''wrong'' for the United States to trade arms to Iran for the release of American hostages, but insisted the Adminstration had no such intention.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Contras  INQUIRY FINDS REAGAN AND CHIEF ADVISERS RESPONSIBLE FOR 'CHAOS' IN IRAN ARMS DEALS  White House Cast Wide Net In Seeking Aid for Contras; A Web of Maneuvers
abstract: LEAD: In its effort to organize private aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, the White House solicited help from - and by some accounts threatened - several countries heavily dependent on American financial and political support, the Tower Commission report disclosed today.

headline: ROSTENKOWSKI BARS TAX ON SECURITIES TRANSFERS
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said Saturday that his committee would not consider this year a proposal for a transfer tax on the purchase and sale of securities.

headline: GORBACHEV'S PLANS IMPRESS FORMER U.S. OFFICIALS
abstract: LEAD: Former American officials who met last week with Mikhail S. Gorbachev said yesterday that they believed that his efforts to change Soviet society would have far-reaching effects.

headline: MARK REVALUATION SOUGHT BY FRANCE
abstract: LEAD: France demanded again today that West Germany bear the cost of ending the speculation crisis that erupted on international currency markets last week as the French franc declined and the West German mark soared in value.

headline: BEIRUT SOURCES SAY ISRAEL TALKS WITH KIDNAPPERS
abstract: LEAD: Arab diplomats and local radio stations said today that behind-the-scenes contacts were under way to work out a deal that would involve the release of four kidnapped professors and an Israeli Air Force navigator in exchange for 400 Arab prisoners held by Israel.

headline: Yeshiva Trading Cards: Rabbis but No Red Sox
abstract: LEAD: The boys from the yeshiva come to Shmiel Shnitzer's store after a long day of delving into the sacred writings with the sort of keenness American boys devote to memorizing batting averages.

headline: FISHER GUIDE
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said its Fisher Guide division plans a gradual phase-out of operations at the Detroit Fort Street plant to be completed by the end of the 1989 model year. It said efforts would be made to cushion the impact of the closing on the plant's 2,057 employees. The 1.5-million-square-foot plant builds a variety of car parts, such as foam arm rests, door trim panels and instrument panels.

headline: PATENTS; An Improved System For Oil Exploration
abstract: LEAD: An improved computer-linked nuclear magnetic logging system was patented this week for the Chevron Oil Field Research Company at La Habra, Calif. Seven patents were granted for the tools to be used in well bores to explore oil formation underground.

headline: NEW GARDEN: CORNUCOPIA OF THE PAST
abstract: LEAD: News of the Promised Land seems best rooted in something old, such as the disclosure this week that this land of milk and honey is running short of honey and has begun importing it.

headline: U.S. PLAYS DOWN SPLIT IN CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: The State Department contended today that the Nicaraguan rebel alliance was undergoing ''growing pains,'' but it denied suggestions that divisions among its leaders threatened its existence.

headline: Tokyo Acts To Prevent Chip Curbs
abstract: LEAD: Japanese trade officials today announced measures aimed at warding off American sanctions against Japanese semiconductor manufacturers. The officials also hinted that Japan would retaliate if sanctions were imposed anyway.

headline: Federated Unit Official To Lead Lazarus Stores
abstract: LEAD: John D. Miller should be a hero to personnel executives, who often do not get to the top in the department store business. Mr. Miller has made it all the way to chief executive, and yesterday he did it again.

headline: Eban Plans Pollard Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Abba Eban, chairman of the Security and Foreign Affairs Committee in the Israeli Parliament, today promised an inquiry into the Jonathan Jay Pollard espionage case after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir refused to answer questions before the committee. Mr. Pollard, a 32-year-old American, was sentenced to life in prison last week in the United States for spying for Israel.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Atwood Richards Inc., a barter company, named Robert E. Levitan senior vice president, product remarketing and trading.

headline: Household Finance Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Household Finance Corporation is offering $150 million of 7 1/2 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 99.725, to yield 7.549 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Izvestia Invites a Californian To Defend Himself in a Suit
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government daily Izvestia today invited Raphael Gregorian, a California businessman, to defend himself in a defamation suit it is bringing after he won a libel award in the United States. Izvestia said Mr. Gregorian had until Jan. 12 to submit evidence.

headline: Hamill Quits as Editor Of Mexico City Paper
abstract: LEAD: Pete Hamill, the American journalist, has resigned as editor of Mexico's only English-language newspaper, a post he took less than three months ago, after a dispute with the newspaper's publisher over what Mr. Hamill said was an effort to make the coverage biased.

headline: NORFOLK BID BACKED AT PIEDMONT
abstract: LEAD: Piedmont Aviation Inc., the parent of Piedmont Airlines, announced yesterday that it had received takeover offers from two companies and that a committee of its board members had recommended approval of a $65-a-share all-cash bid by the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

headline: 2 SEEN AS LIKELY TO FILL FEDERAL RESERVE SEATS
abstract: LEAD: Leif H. Olsen, formerly the top economist at Citibank, and Edward W. Kelley, an investment adviser from Texas, seem likely to fill the two current vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board, Government and business sources said today.

headline: Bethlehem Gain
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that as a result of improved operating results it would report a profit for the fourth quarter instead of the operating loss it had expected. Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, said a $130 million investment tax-credit refund would be recorded in 1987, instead of in the fourth quarter of last year.

headline: Market Place; Beneficiaries Of Stock Surge
abstract: LEAD: LARGE-CAPITALIZATION issues - drugs, papers and oils, among others - figure prominently on the expanding list of stocks scoring new 52-week highs on the New York Stock Exchange. But the market's broad advance also saw new highs set last week by components of the long-depressed oil-service industry, as well as by stocks in such ''niche'' sectors as check printers, funeral-related businesses and New Jersey home builders.

headline: Robins Deadline
abstract: LEAD: Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. has given the A. H. Robins Company three weeks to submit a reorganization plan, saying he has unhappy with what he called the lack of cooperation from lawyers involved in the 16-month-old bankruptcy proceeding. Judge Merhige said Monday that he had had ''less cooperation in this case than any other case in 20 years'' on the bench.

headline: NEW ICN DRUG PUTS CHIEF IN SPOTLIGHT
abstract: LEAD: In the 26 years since Milan Panic founded ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., the company has gone from obscurity to the limelight and Mr. Panic has acquired a reputation as a good promoter. Some would say too good.

headline: Flying Tiger's Counsel Is Unruffled by Turmoil
abstract: LEAD: As general counsel of Flying Tiger Line Inc., Lawrence M. Nagin has had few chances recently to ruminate about the fortunes of the air cargo industry. Flying Tiger, the world's largest air cargo carrier, narrowly avoided liquidation a few weeks ago by negotiating substantial wage concessions from its pilots and announcing a major cost-cutting program.

headline: EASTERN AIMS TO CUT LABOR COSTS BY 35%
abstract: LEAD: The president of Eastern Air Lines Inc., Phil Bakes, set a goal yesterday to cut labor costs by $490 million this year as part of a plan to make the carrier profitable.

headline: WALL STREET'S DEFENSIVE LINE
abstract: LEAD: The Government's widening investigation into corruption on Wall Street has pitted Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers against the largest brigade of white-collar criminal lawyers ever assembled.

headline: High Technology
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  For over 35 years we have closely watched the short- and long-term effects of marketing American technology abroad, mainly through licensing (''The U.S. Giveaway,'' Dec. 7). More than any other nation we have generously offered our technology to outsiders. As a result, the entire world has been able to advance the automation of assembly line manufacturing, as well as the handling and processing of material.

headline: Trump Moving Castle Account
abstract: LEAD: The Trump Organization has switched the advertising responsibility for Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino to Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK from McCann-Erickson.

headline: Finance Plan For Europe
abstract: LEAD: The president of the European Community commission, Jacques Delors, today proposed the most radical changes in the group's financing since it was created 30 years ago.

headline: Super Helmets
abstract: LEAD: The Gipper may have played with a leather hat, but when the Giants butt heads with the Broncos Sunday in Super Bowl XXI their craniums will be protected with polycarbonate plastic shells lined with foam padding and honeycombed with hollow channels that can be inflated with air for a skull-hugging custom fit, or with antifreeze to absorb shocks and distribute the impact.

headline: Macao's Way of Life Gets a Grace Period
abstract: LEAD: Residents of this Portuguese colony on the south China coast will be able to travel freely, elect local leaders, and continue their way of life for 50 years after Macao returns to Chinese control in 1999, according to the text of the agreement between Portugal and China on the enclave's future.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Mark D. Goldstein promoted to president of the Washington office of Earle Palmer Brown Inc., Bethesda, Md.

headline: Bid to Increase Fairchild Stake
abstract: LEAD: A Fairchild Industries Inc. shareholder group said today that it was considering buying up just under half of the company's stock because management had been unsuccessful in enhancing shareholder values.

headline: NEW REPORT OF SAUDI MONEY FOR CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane told Congress that Saudi Arabia had contributed millions of dollars for the Nicaraguan rebels, increasing to at least $40 million the amount gathered for the rebels that now cannot be accounted for, sources familiar with the Congressional investigation said today.

headline: DAYS INNS' FEISTY CHIEF TAKES ON MOTEL GIANT
abstract: LEAD: When he's not overseeing his small empire of moderately priced hotels and motels, Henry R. Silverman, 46, peruses his competitors' financial statements. Just the other day, he was sifting through the latest proxy statement from the Holiday Corporation, the industry giant, when he noticed that the company's planned restructuring would leave it with a negative net worth close to $1 billion.

headline: Japan Investment in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Japan ranked third in direct investment in the United States during a 12-year period beginning in 1974, a trade organization said in a report released today. The Japan External Trade Organization said Japan made 1,154 direct investments, or 14.2 percent of the total, in the United States from 1974 through 1985.

headline: THE A.M. STATIONS GO FOR A FACELIFT
abstract: LEAD: THE AM band has been the ugly member of the radio family since FM sprouted in the 1950's. FM sounded better; it had better programming; and its signal was clear enough to remain stable on most radios.

headline: MERRILL, I.B.M. END VENTURE
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that they would end their once-promising venture in computerizing the financial services industry.

headline: SALES OF U.S. CARS UP BY 6.7%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars increased 6.7 percent in the last 10 days of February, despite a decline in sales by the General Motors Corporation, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: TEST LIMIT TREATIES SENT TO SENATE
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan asked the Senate today to approve two 1970's treaties that limit the size of underground nuclear explosions. But he said the unratified treaties would go into effect only if the Soviet Union agreed to additional verification measures.

headline: HARPER BOARD PICKS ADVISORY PANEL
abstract: LEAD: The board of Harper & Row has appointed a committee of outside directors to study alternatives to the two takeover offers it received last week, the company said yesterday.

headline: Wunderman to Handle New Optima Card
abstract: LEAD: Now that American Express has revealed the existence of its new Optima card, it is possible to reveal that its agency for the introduction is Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the Young & Rubicam direct-marketing specialty agency.

headline: Yields Are Set By Fannie Mae
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.5 billion of debentures equally divided between four-year and 10-year maturities, through various securities dealers.

headline: Inco's President to Add Chief Executive's Post
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Phillips says he has already seen the worst three years in the history of the nickel industry. In the view of Mr. Phillips, who was named yesterday as chief executive of Inco Ltd., the world's largest nickel producer, the prospects are brighter as long as the company pares operating expenses and expands its non-nickel activity.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 2, 1987:                  MONDAY               Albertson's Inc   First Mississippi Corp        Cincinnati Bell   Foxboro Co               TUESDAY               Engelhard Corp   Pillsbury Co        MCA Inc   Premier Industrial        Mickelberry Corp               WEDNESDAY               Alaska Air Group   Louisville Gas & Elec        Fieldcrest Cannon   Stanley Works        Geico Corp   USF & G Corp               THURSDAY               Atlantic City Elec   Green Mountain Pwr        Brown Group Inc   Humana Inc        Centel Corp   Washington Natl Corp        Collins Foods Intl               FRIDAY               Chubb CorpSierra Pacific Resources Intl

headline: ARGENTINA TO FREEZE PAY, PRICES
abstract: LEAD: The Argentine Government announced a four-month freeze on prices and salaries tonight, saying it needed a ''more serene climate'' in which to carry out structural changes in the economy.

headline: PIEDMONT ACCEPTS USAIR BID
abstract: LEAD: The USAir Group announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Piedmont Aviation Inc. for $1.59 billion, ending a three-week-old contest for control of one of the fastest-growing and most profitable carriers in the deregulated airline industry.

headline: Revlon Group, Germaine Monteil
abstract: LEAD: The Revlon Group is negotiating to acquire Germaine Monteil, a small, privately owned cosmetics company, and has expressed an interest in buying parts of Charles of the Ritz. Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion house, said earlier this week that it might sell some of the businesses of Charles of the Ritz, including that company's cosmetics line.

headline: ISRAEL CITES NEW DATA IN U.N. NAZI FILES
abstract: LEAD: United Nations war-crimes files that have been examined by Israel hold a ''treasure trove of new information'' on the Nazis that ''could change our understanding of that era,'' Israel's chief delegate to the world body said today.

headline: Bayer Named In AIDS Suit
abstract: LEAD: Bayer A.G., the giant West German chemical company, said today that it had been sued over its sale of hemophilia drugs that may have been infected with the AIDS virus.

headline: WASHINGTON RAIDERS: Herbert and Robert Haft; The Dynasty Behind Dart's Expanding Empire
abstract: LEAD: ''MY father always has to be building something,'' says Robert Haft.

headline: Toyota Is Hurt By Strong Yen
abstract: LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company's sales and earnings fell in the first half of its fiscal year for the first time since the mid-1970's, the company said today. In the six months ended Dec. 31, sales were down 4.6 percent and net income was down 44.4 percent.

headline: U.S. SAYS N.S.C. WILL FACE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: The National Security Council will undergo major changes under Frank C. Carlucci, the new national security adviser, including a virtual prohibition against covert operations, a senior White House official said today.

headline: NO POLICY RETREAT, CHINA TELLS SHULTZ
abstract: LEAD: Chinese leaders told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that they had no intention of retreating from their economic opening to the West or their adoption of some elements of a free-market economy.

headline: ENIGMATIC HARD-LINER: NAJIB
abstract: LEAD: So mysterious is Afghanistan's leader that there is not even agreement about the rendering of his name.

headline: FLEET FACES CONNECTICUT DIVESTITURE
abstract: LEAD: One day after announcing a $1.3 billion merger with the Norstar Bancorporation of Albany, the Fleet Financial Group said yesterday that it might have to sell its banking operation in Connecticut because of that state's banking law.

headline: A MINISTER, A PORTFOLIO AND JOKES
abstract: LEAD: Wearing a mortarboard with a comic yellow tassel, Hans-Dietrich Genscher told a fictional anecdote about his appearance before the Bonn parliamentary committee that investigated payoffs by the giant Flick concern.

headline: U.S. SEEKS MORE INFORMATION FROM SWISS ON THE IRAN AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: The United States Justice Department is seeking information about bank accounts and transactions involving an expanding list of people and companies that may have been involved in the Iran-contra arms transfers, Swiss officials said today.

headline: BEIRUT ISLAMIC GROUP AGAIN WARNS OF U.S. ATTACK
abstract: LEAD: A Moslem group holding two Americans hostage here announced today that it had ordered its members on full alert in anticipation of an American troop landing, and an Armenian underground faction threatened to end a four-month-old truce with France.

headline: Wickes Wants A Reverse Split
abstract: LEAD: The Wickes Companies said today that it would ask shareholders to approve a reverse stock split of its 239 million common shares outstanding on a 1-for-5 basis.

headline: SENATE REPORT ON IRAN ARMS SALES: ROLE OF ISRAEL IS HIGHLIGHTED
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Intelligence Committee's report on Iran has raised new questions about the role played by Israel in persuading President Reagan to violate his own dual policies of never paying ransom to terrorists for the release of hostages and of not supplying arms to Iran.

headline: USX SEEN PLANNING SELL-OFFS
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation is considering the sale of some, if not all, of the businesses that make up its diversified products group as the initial part of its long-awaited restructuring, Wall Street and industry sources believe.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., promoted Michael I. Roth to executive vice president.

headline: Did He Drop Protege Or Was He Forced?
abstract: LEAD: The abrupt ouster of Hu Yaobang, China's Communist Party chief, raises the question whether the move was engineered by Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, or was forced on Mr. Deng by increasingly powerful hard-liners in the party.

headline: MARKET FOR BANK BONDS HALTS AGAIN IN LONDON
abstract: LEAD: A multibillion-dollar market in bank bonds ground to a halt today as sellers found that there were no willing buyers for their securities. The trading collapse left some of the world's largest banks and financial institutions stuck with large quantities of unsellable bonds, dealers said.

headline: 2 OTHERS REFINERS DROP
abstract: LEAD: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, yesterday reported an 18 percent earnings drop in the fourth quarter despite firming prices and nearly $500 million of special gains.

headline: Brokerage Stake In Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: The New York brokerage Spear, Leeds & Kellogg has purchased a 7.1 percent stake, or 136,000 preferred shares, in Allegheny International Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Spear, Leeds said it had bought the shares ''in the ordinary course of its trading activities.''

headline: PHILIPPINE ARMY CHIEF SAYS TROOPS OVERREACTED
abstract: LEAD: As the Philippine Government braced for more violence in the 10 days before a vote on a proposed constitution, the armed forces Chief of Staff said today that his troops overreacted when they fired into a crowd of protesters Thursday.

headline: 1,000 CHINESE IN U.S. ENDORSE A PROTEST
abstract: LEAD: As many as a thousand Chinese nationals studying in American colleges and universities have now endorsed an open letter to the leadership in Beijing voicing concern over the removal of Hu Yaobang as the Communist Party leader and the disciplining of Chinese intellectuals.

headline: GORBACHEV PRESSES FOR VOTE WITH CHOICE OF CANDIDATES
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that experiments would be conducted this year in what he called democratic elections in Communist Party cells, local government bodies and and factory managements.

headline: G.M. Announces Improved Warranty
abstract: LEAD: In an apparent effort to increase its sales and improve its image for workmanship, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would extend the warranty on major mechanical components from three years and 36,000 miles to six years and 60,000 miles on all of its 1987 cars built in North America.

headline: ECONOMIC EXPANSION SEEN FOR '87
abstract: LEAD: Almost in spite of itself, the United States economy will continue to expand in 1987, marking the fifth year of unbroken growth, according to forecasts by the Reagan Administration, the Federal Reserve Board and private economists.

headline: Textile Bill Is Sought
abstract: LEAD: Congressional supporters of the textile industry said today that they are planning a new effort to legislate import curbs designed to build a broader coalition than last year, when a Presidential veto of textile quotas was nearly overriden.

headline: Bolivia Acts Against Strikes, Arresting 20 Labor Leaders
abstract: LEAD: Authorities arrested 20 trade union leaders and theatened tough action against a wave of strikes sweeping the country, Interior Minister Fernando Berthelemy said today.

headline: Market Place; Price Dip Soon Seen for Stocks
abstract: LEAD: WHENEVER stocks move sharply in one direction or another for a sustained period, the eyes of Wall Street inevitably turn to the giants of the market, the institutional investors, for a reading of what to expect next.

headline: 11 NORTH KOREAN BOAT PEOPLE PUT JAPAN IN MIDDLE OF SQUABBLE
abstract: LEAD: Eleven North Koreans aboard a ship that developed engine trouble and drifted into Japanese waters more than a week ago have created an unusual diplomatic triangle that resists a swift solution.

headline: ACROSS ICE, IN A 26-WHEEL RIG: CANADA'S INTREPID TRUCKERS
abstract: LEAD: At 10:30 A.M. the other day, the sun hauled itself above the horizon, a vaporous orange ball barely visible through the mists. Ahead, the road ran runway straight, featureless save for jagged fissures marking ''pressure ridges'' in the blue-green ice.

headline: BIG PRICE INCREASES SHAKE BRAZILIANS
abstract: LEAD: After what one local economist called ''a hiatus of generalized happiness,'' Brazilians appear to be rapidly losing faith in the anti-inflation program decreed by the Government last February.

headline: Dollar Gains Strength As Short-Sellers Buy
abstract: LEAD: The dollar strengthened further in New York yesterday after closing slightly firmer overseas earlier in the day.

headline: PATENTS; Adapter for Fluorescent Lamps
abstract: LEAD: AN adapter permitting the use of compact fluorescent lamps in ordinary incandescent light bulb sockets was patented this week for the North American Philips Corporation. A subsidiary is manufacturing the adapters and the lamps.

headline: PROXMIRE'S BANKING CHALLENGE
abstract: LEAD: An aggressive banking bill introduced by the Senate Banking Committee chairman, William Proxmire, has suddenly bogged down so badly that the Wisconsin Democrat has had to weaken two divisive provisions just prior to a committee vote scheduled for this week. Those two titles would have closed the ''nonbank bank'' loophole and would have given banks broad new securities underwriting powers.

headline: 51 Dead and 84 Missing
abstract: LEAD: The Belgian authorities said today that 408 of 543 aboard a British ferryboat had been rescued after she capsized outside this harbor on Friday.

headline: ISRAEL OPENS CASE IN DEATH CAMP TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: The man accused of being an attendant at the Treblinka death camp entered a courtroom here today with a wave, a big smile and a booming ''Good morning!'' spoken in Hebrew: ''Boker Tov!''

headline: PRICES OF NOTES AND BONDS DIP
abstract: LEAD: Prices of notes and bonds fell slightly yesterday as trading activity remained light.

headline: ARAB ARMS SALES DRAW LESS PROTEST
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration's proposed arms sales to Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations this year are meeting less opposition than usual from supporters of Israel, partly because of the cloud cast over Israeli-American relations by the Pollard spy case and the Israeli role in the Iran-contra affair.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: 350 ARE SAFE, MANY TRAPPED; 48 REPORTED DEAD
abstract: LEAD: A British ferry with more than 500 people aboard capsized Friday night shortly after leaving the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, and the vessel's owners said 48 people were dead and more than 200 missing.

headline: Accord on 'USX'
abstract: LEAD: The USX Telecenters Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would change its name after an out-of-court cash settlement with the giant USX Corporation, formerly known as the United States Steel Corporation. USX Telecenters, a telephone retailing franchiser that had trademark rights to its name, had filed suit against the giant steelmaker in July after learning it had switched its name to USX.

headline: Four Wheeler Magazine Tries Out 5 New Titles
abstract: LEAD: Penthouse's Four Wheeler magazine, with a circulation exceeding 220,000, will publish five additional one-shot titles for newsstand sale this year. If the books prove popular, they will have their publishing frequency increased. They are the 4x4 Answer Book, Trucksports USA, Monster Trucks IV, All W/D Car Guide and Light Truck Buyer's Guide.

headline: Vatican and Hungary Appoint New Primate
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican and the Hungarian Government announced today that Archbishop Laszlo Paskai of Kalocsa had been named the new Primate of Hungary.

headline: Route 1's Missing Riders: Office Workers
abstract: LEAD: THE SPRAWL of office parks, research centers, convention hotels and the like along U.S. Route 1 between Trenton and

headline: ABRAMS UNDER FIRE AT SENATE HEARING
abstract: LEAD: Elliott Abrams came to testify before a Senate committee today on a new peace plan for Central America but became embroiled in questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair and charges that he hounded a respected diplomat out of the Foreign Service.

headline: FIRST CHICAGO TO BUY DELAWARE BANK
abstract: LEAD: Increasing its stake in the credit-card business, the First Chicago Corporation said today that it would buy the Beneficial National Bank in Wilmington, Del., from the Beneficial Corporation for $247 million.

headline: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: THE DOW IN PERSPECTIVE  TRACING THE UPS AND DOWNS OF THE 20th CENTURY THROUGH THE EYES OF WALL STREET; Most Experts Are Saying the Surge Will Continue
abstract: LEAD: It may be fun to look back at the Dow's history, but that's no way to make money.

headline: ANCIENT AND MODERN POMPEII DO BATTLE OVER NEW HIGHWAY
abstract: LEAD: Mount Vesuvius did such a good job of burying Pompeii in A.D. 79 that only now has anyone thought of doing it again.

headline: Nicaragua Derides the Tower Report
abstract: LEAD: A Sandinista Government spokesman said today that he believed the Tower Commission's report was intended more to protect the United States Presidency than to find the full truth behind the Iran-contra dealings.

headline: Hambrecht Offers A Mutual Fund
abstract: LEAD: Hambrecht & Quist Inc. said it had begun its first mutual fund, H&Q Healthcare Investors. The closed-end fund will focus on emerging-growth companies and will be at least 80 percent invested in industries such as biotechnology, diagnostics, health care services, pharmaceuticals and medical products.

headline: THE QUIRKY BEHAVIOR OF BONDS
abstract: LEAD: Rarely has the credit market behaved more perversely than it did late last week. On Thursday, bond prices fell when they should have benefited from a steep 7.5 percent decline in durable goods orders for January. Then on Friday, bond prices rose despite sharp rises in the trade deficit and Consumer Price Index figures for January.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: The Personal Finance column on Dec. 21 incorrectly described the early withdrawal penalty from an Individual Retirement Account. The penalty for early withdrawals remains 10 percent. The penalty for early withdrawals from tax-deferred annuity contracts, which was 5 percent, doubled to 10 percent on Jan.

headline: Citicorp, Dai-Ichi Seen Close to Alliance
abstract: LEAD: While the report of an agreement between Citicorp and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Ltd. remained unconfirmed over the weekend, the heads of consumer banking for the big international banks in New York - and some top Japanese bankers based here - said they had been hearing that the two banks were close to forming a strategic alliance.

headline: Japan Rejects Fake Reeboks
abstract: LEAD: Japanese customs authorities, faced with a flood of counterfeit Reebok sneakers from South Korea, have turned away 100,000 pairs since last summer, company and Government officials said.

headline: IN INDIA, ECONOMIC GAINS AND NEW PERILS
abstract: LEAD: After two years of widely applauded liberalization measures, India's economy has achieved solid growth - but it has also run into problems that threaten to undercut the recent gains.

headline: U.S. Denounces Trial of Czech Jazz Section
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration today denounced a Czechoslovak court's conviction of five advocates of cultural freedom as a contrived and unjust effort to stifle freedoms that Czechoslovakia agreed to uphold in a 1975 human rights agreement.

headline: HEUBLEIN TO BUY ALMADEN VINEYARDS
abstract: LEAD: Heublein Inc., a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Inc., said today that it had agreed to acquire Almaden Vineyards Inc. from the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

headline: ROCKWELL REPURCHASE
abstract: LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said on Friday that its board had authorized an extension of the company's $500 million stock repurchase program by an additional $500 million. Since the beginning of the repurchase program in March 1986, Rockwell said, it has bought 10.4 million shares for $461 million.

headline: LOOKING BEYOND THE 'AW-SHUCKS' ACT
abstract: LEAD: T BOONE Pickens is a skillful corporate raider who has had a high old time flinging rocks at corporate management and painting himself as an aw-shucks, down-home fella who just wants to help out the little shareholders on the block. He rides around in his corporate jet taking pot shots at the ''bad guys'' for riding around in corporate jets.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Continental Airlines Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million of senior notes due 1997 through Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: Durables Report Lifts Bonds
abstract: LEAD: An unexpectedly sharp decline in durable goods orders for January lifted prices of fixed-income securities yesterday in active trading. The 7.5 percent decline was seven times greater than what participants in the credit market had expected.

headline: FOR BLACK-RULED COUNTRIES, SOUTH AFRICA IS BOTH LIFELINE AND MORTAL THREAT
abstract: LEAD: The gunfire and the burning tires may be out of sight and hearing, but the upheavals in South Africa send menacing shock waves far beyond its northern borders.

headline: Scramble for Canada Brokers
abstract: LEAD: Three months before the Canadian securities industry is to be opened wider to foreign ownership, brokers in the Bay Street financial district are reporting a rush of merger and acquisition talks involving some of the largest American and Canadian financial firms and a number of Canada's biggest banks.

headline: Michigan Executive Takes Lilco Posts
abstract: LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company has named Russell C. Youngdahl president and chief operating officer, filling posts that have been vacant for several years.

headline: IN A CITY OF CALAMITIES, 300,000 LIVE ON THE STREETS
abstract: LEAD: It was a typical scene in Calcutta. Over an open fire on a noisy traffic island a woman was cooking lunch while her children, naked or in rags, pushed each other waiting for something to eat.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''When you add it all up, the economy isn't booming, and it's not busting based on these numbers. It's just muddling along.''  - Edward E. Yardeni, chief economist, Prudential-Bache, on the durable goods report.

headline: Hill Holliday Connors Gets 3 Gillette Products
abstract: LEAD: Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos in Boston has been named agency for three brands from Gillette's Personal Products division: Good News Toiletries, which had been at Young & Rubicam; Aapri, a facial scrub formerly at N. W. Ayer, and Deep Magic Cleansing Lotions, which Gillette hopes to revive.

headline: G.M. Talks Collapse
abstract: LEAD: The negotiations between the Hungarian truck maker Raba Eto and the General Motors Corporation for a barter deal have collapsed, Budapest radio said. Under the plan, Hungary would have imported Opel cars from G.M. A Budapest newspaper quoted a Raba executive as saying that G.M. asked too much for the Opels and offered too little for Raba goods.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:                 Previous   Year        In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   7.50   7.50   9.50        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.50   n.a.   8.34        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.56   n.a.   7.07        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.55   n.a.   7.13        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.02   n.a.   8.93        30-YR.

headline: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 21, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  International 2-5, 28  Labor unrest in Yugoslavia has erupted recently. Since the beginning of March, workers have been walking off their jobs to protest stern new wage restraints at a time when prices of most necessities are being raised. Page 1  Poland's labor federation protested expected price increases, declaring them unacceptable to Polish workers, and calling for an end to policies of continuously raising prices of food, services and consumer goods.

headline: An Acquittal For Shearson
abstract: LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. has been acquitted on charges that it failed to file currency-transaction reports. But the eight women and four men on the Federal jury Wednesday convicted a former Shearson broker, Herbert Cantley, of conspiracy.

headline: Beirut Fighting Defies New Cease-Fire Effort
abstract: LEAD: There was more heavy fighting in West Beirut today as regular Syrian and Lebanese soldiers took up positions at main intersections to try to enforce a cease-fire.

headline: MAN WITH SOVIET MEAT SECRETS CAN EMIGRATE
abstract: LEAD: Lev Blitshtein, the man who was said to know too much about meat storage in the Soviet Union, has learned that he can leave to join his family in the United States.

headline: PRICE ACQUIRES TSS-SEEDMAN
abstract: LEAD: The Price Company, the nation's largest chain of warehouse stores, said it had acquired the TSS-Seedman department-store chain, and will open its first Price Club on Long Island in July. While the total purchase price was not disclosed, Price, which is based in San Diego, will make an initial payment of $50 million, with the full sum to be based on the results of the acquired company.

headline: RJR Nabisco Debentures
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. is offering $500 million of 8 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 97 3/8 to yield 8.62 percent through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

headline: SENATORS SPLIT ON WHITE HOUSE POLICY OF SOLICITING CASH FOR CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: As details increase on how the Reagan Administration solicited money from foreign governments to help the Nicaraguan rebels and other anti-Communist insurgent groups around the world, leading senators remain divided over the propriety and wisdom of the unorthodox policy.

headline: Combustion To Get Accuray
abstract: LEAD: Combustion Engineering Inc., a diversified technology company, said today that it had won a bidding war and had agreed to acquire the Accuray Corporation for $45 a share, or $213 million. Accuray, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes computer-aided sensors and measuring devices for pulp and paper manufacturers.

headline: AFTER 20 YEARS, BOOK ON STALIN REACHES PRINT IN SOVIET UNION
abstract: LEAD: A novel chronicling Stalin's terror, ''Children of the Arbat,'' has been excerpted in a Soviet weekly magazine 20 years after its author first tried to bring his painful subject to a Soviet audience.

headline: Allegheny Tells Of Rejected Bid
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. disclosed that it had turned down a higher takeover offer from an unnamed bidder before accepting a leveraged buyout led by a unit of the First Boston Corporation. It said the offer was rejected because the bidder had refused to pay a $7 million ''termination payment'' to First

headline: PATENTS; Monitoring Production Of Power in Reactor
abstract: LEAD: One of the nuclear reactor inventions patented this week was devised for the Department of Energy. It concerns production of nuclear fuel pellets that contain plutonium, a binder and a lubricant. Patent 4,637,900 was granted to James R. Frederickson of Richland, Wash., under a contract with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of

headline: Canada's Reserves Soar
abstract: LEAD: Canada's official foreign currency reserves, used to protect the Canadian dollar, soared to the highest level in nearly 13 years in January, the Finance Department said today. The figure rose by nearly $2 billion (American), to $6.07 billion.

headline: VATICAN'S MORAL MISSION  Reproduction Report Seen as Opportunity To Influence Government in Making Laws
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican's document on human reproduction exploits what some church officials consider an unparalleled opportunity to influence governments before they enact laws on controversial medical innovations.

headline: Tentative Approval For USAir-P.S.A.
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department has tentatively approved USAir Group's proposed $400 million acquisition of Pacific Southwest Airlines. The agency, which has final authority over airline mergers, said it had concluded that the transaction would not harm competition and would be consistent with the public interest.

headline: Serious Economic Damage
abstract: LEAD: The Ecuadorean earthquake has caused serious economic damage to a country that was already suffering from the effects of the drop in the world price of oil.

headline: ETHOPIA TALE: FAMINE GOES, ORPHANS STAY
abstract: LEAD: Embeti, about 3 years old, stopped chattering with her rag doll and looked up curiously at two visitors hovering overhead.

headline: G.M. Said to Study Plant Closings
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is considering closing as many as 20 or more auto parts plants in an effort to become more competitive, The Detroit Free Press reported, quoting an anonymous source. It said the plants would be phased out over two to three years. A G.M. spokesman, John Mueller, told the newspaper he knew of no plans to close any of the automaker's parts plants.

headline: Swissair Orders 6 MD-11's
abstract: LEAD: Swissair dealt a blow to Europe's Airbus consortium today by announcing a $780 million order for six MD-11 long-haul passenger aircraft made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

headline: Official Resigns At Southland
abstract: LEAD: Joe C. Thompson 3d, the youngest of the three brothers who head the Southland Corporation in Dallas, has resigned as senior executive vice president of the company in order to operate a local liquor store chain. Mr. Thompson, who is 45 years old, was in charge of Southland's Retail Stores Group.

headline: Troika of Directors To Run Wheeling
abstract: LEAD: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's board, after days of meetings, announced yesterday that it had named a troika of directors to run the company while the position of chairman remains vacant.

headline: EASING OF CURBS ON BELL UNITS FOUGHT
abstract: LEAD: A coalition of major communications trade groups said today that they would oppose Reagan Administration efforts to let the regional Bell Telephone companies offer long-distance and electronic information services and manufacture telephone equipment.

headline: Caterpillar to Take $109 Million Charge
abstract: LEAD: Caterpillar Inc. said today that it would report a pretax charge of $109 million against fourth-quarter earnings resulting from the proposed closing of three plants that would idle about 3,000 workers in Iowa, Oregon and Scotland.

headline: VANUATU SEEKS AID AFTER HURRICANE
abstract: LEAD: Vanuatu appealed for more overseas aid Friday to rebuild its economy and to help feed and house 10,000 people left homeless after a hurricane hit the small South Pacific nation on Feb. 7.

headline: PUROLATOR DISSIDENT OPPOSED TO 'GRABS'
abstract: LEAD: Dorsey R. Gardner is an investment adviser with only two clients. But they are big clients - the Fidelity Group of Funds in Boston and Fidelity International in Bermuda.

headline: KAHANE'S FREE MAILINGS ARE BARRED
abstract: LEAD: Rabbi Meir Kahane was stripped of his mailing privilege in the Israeli Parliament today after his fellow legislators decided that he had abused it by mailing letters to Arabs urging them to leave Israel or face ''war.''

headline: ALLIS-CHALMERS TO SPLIT OPERATIONS
abstract: LEAD: The Allis- Chalmers Corporation said it planned to split its worldwide operations into two separate companies. It said the realignment was part of its efforts to become more competitive in international markets.

headline: CANADA ALLOWS RESUMPTION OF SEAL HUNTING FROM SHIPS
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Government has approved resuming large-scale seal hunting from ships off the country's east coast, prompting an outcry from animal welfare groups whose protests virtually ended seal hunting as a major industry in the region four years ago.

headline: FOR MILL TOWN'S COMEBACK, THE PLAY'S THE THING
abstract: LEAD: ''Brush up your Shakespeare,'' two singing gangsters advised the other night on center stage in this careworn northern city. ''Just declaim a few lines from O-thel-la and they'll think you're a helluva fella.''

headline: WEINBERGER TRYING TO REASSURE TURKS ON U.S. ARMS HELP
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met Turkish leaders today to try to convince them that the Reagan Administration wanted to reverse major reductions in military and economic aid.

headline: HOPES MINGLE WITH DESPAIR AT LAST STOP
abstract: LEAD: Christopher Dellisanty's frustrating search for his brother finally brought him and his mother, Rose, to the place they did not want to go: a government hospital where forensic experts are trying to identify charred bodies from the fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel.

headline: AIR WAR HEATS UP, BUT TEHERAN STILL BUSTLES
abstract: LEAD: The aerial war between Iran and Iraq appeared to step up today, as Iran said it had suffered more than 800 civilian casualties in Iraqi air raids on 10 cities.

headline: Gates-G.E. Battery Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Gates Corporation said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the General Electric Company's battery business. Terms were not disclosed. Gates said the purchase includes G.E. plants in Gainesville, Fla.; Juarez, Mexico, and Newcastle, England. The agreement calls for G.E. to continue marketing rechargeable batteries for the consumer market under its name.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Anheuser-Busch Co., St. Louis, said its Metal Container Corp. would build a beverage-can manufacturing plant at Chester, N.Y.

headline: Goodyear's Shares Top Tender Offer
abstract: LEAD: Shareholders of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company tendered more than 85.2 million shares under the company's offer to buy back up to 40 million common shares at $50 each, Goodyear said. The tender offer expired at midnight Friday, and because the number of shares tendered exceeded the buyback offer, some shares will not be accepted.

headline: Atlantic Air Fare Pact
abstract: LEAD: The United States and 13 of the 22 member states of the European Civil Aviation Conference have signed an accord on trans-Atlantic air fares to replace existing arrangements that expire in April. The Europeans said today that, under the new memorandum of understanding, aeronautical authorities of the signatory states will automatically approve North Atlantic fares filed by airlines within specified pricing zones.

headline: Mississippi Power Rates in Question
abstract: LEAD: The State Public Service Commission is considering the suspension of a $326.5 million rate rise it had granted to the Mississippi Power and Light Company, as well as the operating license of the Grand Gulf nuclear plant, commissioners said.

headline: U.S. IS RETALIATING WITH 100% DUTIES IN JAPAN DISPUTE
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan decided today to double the import price of some Japanese electronic products, in the first American trade retaliation against Japan in the postwar period.

headline: Departing U.S. Envoy Optimistic on Manila
abstract: LEAD: The United States Ambassador, completing a three-year posting here, says he has seen the Philippines ''trade certainty for uncertainty'' in its transition from the Marcos to the Aquino eras.

headline: Agency Approves AirCal Takeover
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department gave its final approval to American Airlines' acquisition of AirCal Inc. for $225 million, saying there is no evidence the merger would harm competition. The department had given tentative approval to the deal in February.

headline: ABDUCTORS IN BEIRUT DEMAND THAT ISRAEL FREE 400 PRISONERS
abstract: LEAD: The group that kidnapped three Americans and an Indian last week said today that it would kill them if Israel does not free 400 prisoners within a week.

headline: LTV Pension Funds Seized
abstract: LEAD: The Federal pension watchdog agency said today that it was taking control of three pension funds from the LTV Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel company, which is now in bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: WHITE HOUSE PUTTING BLAME ON HIS AIDES
abstract: LEAD: As the Iran-contra affair unfolds, the White House finds itself in the strange position of defending President Reagan with the argument that some of his most powerful aides were incompetent or deceitful.

headline: Gabon's Cabinet Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Leon Mebiane submitted the resignation of his 59-member Cabinet today to President Omar Bongo.

headline: Telecom Plus
abstract: LEAD: Telecom Plus International Inc. said it had agreed to sell several businesses to Siemens A.G. of West Germany for $165 million. In the deal, Siemens will get 65 percent of Tel Plus Communications Inc. Siemens already owned the other 35 percent of Tel Plus, which is the largest American telephone interconnect company.

headline: British Banks Cut Rates
abstract: LEAD: Two major British banks, National Westminster and Barclays, cut their base lending rates to 10 percent, from 10.5 percent. Other banks were expected to follow. The reductions follow a big drop in the Government's borrowing target, announced in the annual budget Tuesday. It was not clear whether the building societies would cut mortgage rates.

headline: Advertising; Kellogg's Drive to Fill a Gap ADVERTISING; People
abstract: LEAD: THE Kellogg Company, whose products account for more than 40 percent of the $4 billion in retail sales of cold cereals, has 25 brands that adequately cover most of the nation's demographic slots.

headline: HUGHES TIE TO BAKER HITS SNAG
abstract: LEAD: The Hughes Tool Company yesterday objected to a consent decree being worked out to settle antitrust objections to its proposed merger with the Baker International Corporation.

headline: AT THE FRONT IN THE GULF WAR: THE IRANIANS SEEM CONFIDENT
abstract: LEAD: About three miles behind the Iranian front lines, in what used to be an Iraqi stronghold, there was a traffic jam this morning.

headline: AIDS PERIL WORRIES SOVIET LEADERS
abstract: LEAD: The threat of an AIDS epidemic in the Soviet Union, publicly dismissed as a remote possibility, has privately become a matter of concern at the highest levels, Soviet officials said today.

headline: MCA TURNS HAND TO ACQUISITIONS
abstract: LEAD: For the last two decades, MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company long known as a cautious spender, was, in the words of one media executive, ''a day late and a dollar short'' when it came to acquisitions. But once-staid MCA is starting to shed its tight-fisted image.

headline: Transamerican Suit Advances Suit
abstract: LEAD: A United States bankruptcy judge ruled today that the Transamerican Natural Gas Corporation could pursue a $2 billion lawsuit filed against the Coastal Corporation to ward off a hostile takeover attempt.

headline: BUSH SAYS A HOSTAGE WAS KILLED
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Bush confirmed tonight that an American kidnapped by terrorists in Lebanon had been killed.

headline: 2 TOP SOUTH KOREAN OFFICIALS DISMISSED IN STUDENT'S DEATH
abstract: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan, acting to defuse a political crisis, dismissed his Interior Minister and his National Police Chief today after the Government's admission that the police had tortured a student to death.

headline: Airborne Freight Shares Purchased
abstract: LEAD: TNT Ltd., an Australian-based freight company, has purchased the equivalent of a 17.3 percent stake, or more than one million common shares, of the Airborne Freight Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, TNT said that it began to buy the Airborne shares soon after the

headline: British Widen Insider Study
abstract: LEAD: The British Government said today that it had received new information and was extending its investigation into purported insider trading by a senior London securities dealer.

headline: THE HIDDEN AGENDA OF THE RADICAL RIGHT
abstract: LEAD: BADGERING lawyers is becoming a national pastime. In part, that is because advocating unpopular causes, defending individual rights, opposing demands of the sometimes-insistent, often-exasperated majority are lawyers' fundamental obligations.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   7.50   7.50   9.50        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   5.98    6.01   7.66        3-MO.
