headline: IF THE PHONE WORKS, IT MUST BE THE IVORY COAST
abstract: LEAD: Teodore Codo had a simple choice.

headline: ELECTRONIC TAX FILINGS
abstract: LEAD: Almost 32 million taxpayers have already filed Federal tax returns this year, and for more than 42,000 of them the chore probably has never been easier. Those taxpayers filed their returns electronically - by computer - and most can look forward to getting a refund within three weeks or less. Those who file the conventional way, mailing a paper return, will have to wait four or five weeks and, as the April 15 deadline draws nearer, maybe even longer.

headline: COLLEGES IN SOVIET OVERHAULED TO SPUR GORBACHEV CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet leadership published a detailed blueprint today for fundamental change in higher education, saying present standards did not meet the demands of the Kremlin's economic and social initiatives.

headline: BANKAMERICA ACTS TO DERAIL PURSUER
abstract: LEAD: BankAmerica, which formally rejected First Interstate Bancorp's acquisition offer last Monday, has suddenly heightened its efforts to remain independent. BankAmerica is lobbying Government officials, enlisting its own employees and retirees in a public relations campaign and circulating documents critical of the proposed merger to get regulators to reject it.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Morton Frozen Foods division of Conagra Frozen Foods Co. to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis.

headline: THE INVOICE IS IN THE ETHER
abstract: LEAD: PERSONAL computers have been touted as the linchpins of the paperless office, still presumed, against all the evidence, to be imminent. The catalogues I receive, however, are resplendent with paper products to feed these hungry machines. Mountains of press releases are still deposited in my mail, and the tractor feed strips torn off my reams of manuscripts are recycled by my son Revell in the production of incredible quantities of everything from papier-mache to ersatz soggy woggies -modern-day, supersized spitballs so much a part of the current educational scene.

headline: GREYHOUND TO BUY G.M. UNIT
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its North American transit-bus manufacturing operations to the Greyhound Corporation for an undisclosed price.

headline: WENDY'S GOES BACK TO BASICS
abstract: LEAD: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL, threatened by the bigger burger boys above and an aggressive upstart below, has returned to the advertising basics with the man who was responsible for some of its past glory days.

headline: A CONSULTANT'S ROLE IN THE IRAN AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: In October 1985, when the Reagan Administration was forcing down a jetliner carrying the hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, it turned in desperation to a part-time consultant to reach Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy by telephone.

headline: BONDS UP IN STRONG DEMAND
abstract: LEAD: Greater-than-expected demand from speculators and solid buying by foreign investors at the Treasury's 30-year bond auction yesterday caused prices of outstanding issues to rise sharply.

headline: Pacific Leader Hospitalized
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Walter Lini of the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu was admitted today to the George Washington University Hospital with what doctors suspected was a cerebral hemorrhage, American officials said, adding that he was reported to be in stable condition and was expected to remain in the hospital for at least several days.

headline: NO LONGER A BANKER'S DREAM, THE SAUDI SYSTEM STAGNATES
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia's banks, wildly profitable a few years ago, are ensnared in a cycle of decline brought on by the fall in oil prices of recent years and by religious laws that once worked in their favor, according to bankers and Government officials.

headline: American Exchange Starts TV Campaign
abstract: LEAD: The American Stock Exchange began its first television advertising campaign yesterday, using the theme ''We Extend Your Reach.''

headline: Midcon's President Quits Gas Concern
abstract: LEAD: The Midcon Corporation, a natural gas pipeline company owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced yesterday that its president, William C. Terpstra, had resigned.

headline: Bechtel Reports Work Reductions
abstract: LEAD: Reflecting an extended downturn in heavy construction, the Bechtel Group reported that the volume of work it performed in 1986 declined to $6.5 billion, from $6.8 billion in 1985. The privately held engineering and construction company, which is based here, said it ''completed the year in the black, as it has always done in the past.

headline: GORBACHEV LOOKING TO MORE ACCORDS
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that a Soviet-American agreement on medium-range missiles could ''create an atmosphere of greater trust,'' leading to further arms control accords and a resolution of regional conflicts.

headline: RAINIER GETS 2 TAKEOVER PROPOSALS
abstract: LEAD: The Rainier Bancorporation, the second-largest bank in the state of Washington, said today that it had received takeover proposals from two large out-of-state banking companies.

headline: HIGH COURT BOLSTERS STATES' CONTROL OVER MINING
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 5-to-4 today that states have broad authority to restrict underground mining to protect the land above the mines.

headline: Philadelphia Entree For Hungry Banker
abstract: LEAD: Robert Van Buren, known as the Hungry Banker, is getting ready to swallow Continental Bancorp Inc. of Philadelphia and expand into Pennsylvania from New Jersey.

headline: BRITAIN BEGINS CRASH CAMPAIGN TO EDUCATE PUBLIC ABOUT THE SPREAD OF AIDS
abstract: LEAD: The Government has begun a large-scale campaign to teach the country that AIDS is spreading in Britain and that it is a fatal disease with no known cure.

headline: GANDHI ACTIONS STIR STRONG CRITICISM
abstract: LEAD: A flurry of personnel shifts, statements and actions by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, including some related to India's latest confrontation with Pakistan, have prompted unusually strong criticism of his performance.

headline: The U.N. Today: March 31, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: Spinoff to Settle Avondale Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The battle for control of Avondale Industries has ended with the announcement that the company will sell six subsidiaries to a new concern being formed by William F. Connell. Mr. Connell, Avondale's chairman, is expected to leave the corporation when the sale is made final in late March. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Digital Introduces Computer Series
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation, seeking to extend its recent successes over I.B.M. to the factory floor, introduced a series of industrial computers yesterday based on its VAX minicomputer designs.

headline: Banner Increases Rexnord Holdings
abstract: LEAD: Banner Industries has raised its stake in Rexnord Inc. to 18.4 percent, or 4.67 million shares, from 17.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Banner said that, after unsuccessful discussions between the two companies, a representative of Rexnord suggested that Banner submit an offer directly to the board of the

headline: CLEARINGHOUSE CREATED
abstract: LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company is offering $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, in a financing that typifies the willingness of dealers and investors to devise varieties of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: Beatification Cleared For Nun, Born a Jew
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican took the last official step today toward the beatification of a German Jew who became a Roman Catholic nun and was killed in the Auschwitz death camp. Beatification is a first step toward possible sainthood.

headline: EXPERTS QUESTION MARKET RATIONALITY
abstract: LEAD: Those who make it their business to analyze the inner workings of the nation's stock markets from a distance see an irrational tinge to the behavior of investors in the wild start for 1987.

headline: Troubled Guinness Fills 2 of Top Jobs
abstract: LEAD: Anthony Tennant, deputy chief executive of the Grand Metropolitan hotel and leisure group, is to succeed Ernest Saunders as chief executive of Guinness, the troubled British brewing giant.

headline: O'CONNOR, IN JERUSALEM, APOLOGIZES TO ISRAELIS
abstract: LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York today used the occasion of his first public ceremony in Israel to apologize to the country's people and Government for canceling meetings he had scheduled with leading Israelis.

headline: RENAULT TO FOCUS ON EUROPE
abstract: LEAD: Renault is selling its stake in American Motors as part of a recovery strategy based on redeploying its assets in Europe, Raymond Levy, the French auto maker's new president, said today.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''OPEC has put itself in a box by setting established prices that are way out of line.''  Charles T. Maxwell, of Cyrus J. Lawrence, on the problem of $18-a-barrel oil.

headline: GERMANS STAY IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: LEAD: In West Germany, Government investigators are trying to determine if submarine blueprints were sold illegally to South Africa. BASF, the chemical giant, is under pressure to stop selling computers to Pretoria that some say are used for police work. Lufthansa is being criticized for providing service to destinations that other airlines, in withdrawing from South

headline: HIGH RISE STIRS FIGHT IN YONKERS
abstract: LEAD: A planned 15-story condominium tower has yet to rise on a steeply sloping site in Yonkers overlooking the Hudson River, but it has for months been stamped on the minds of neighboring residents whose river views it would obstruct. Next week those residents will get a chance to voice their objections in court.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Feb. 18 about Kentucky Fried Chicken's decision to leave South Africa misstated the ownership of the fast-food chain. Pepsico Inc. has been the owner since last fall.

headline: South Africa Tightens Curbs on Newspapers
abstract: LEAD: The South African Police issued an order today under emergency regulations banning newspapers from publishing reports or advertisements that improve the image or defend the policies of banned organizations.

headline: TERROR SUSPECT STALKS OUT OF PARIS TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: The trial of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the Lebanese terrorism suspect, opened before a special court today, but Mr. Abdallah walked out of the proceedings after issuing a diatribe against what he called Israeli and American imperialism.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: LEAD: A yarn caddy that she calls a Happy Hooker has been invented by Christine A. Wilson of Ventura, Calif. She received patent No. 4,634,077 this week and has begun production.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN PLEASURE BOATING
abstract: LEAD: THE America's Cup challenge has brought new excitement - and new revenue - to sailing, and focused the eyes of the boating world on Australia. But the overwhelming message of the New York National Boat Show that winds up today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is that America's weekend sailors are still motorboat-mad.

headline: PAKISTAN ACCUSES AFGHANS OF JEOPARDIZING TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, said today that Afghanistan was deliberately trying to jeopardize the two nations' peace talks here by staging new bombing raids on Pakistani villages near the Afghan border.

headline: Progressive Bar To Greenfield Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Progressive Savings and Loan Association said the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had given it permission to withdraw its conditional approval of Greenfield Partners' application to take over the association. Progressive Savings, based in Alhambra, Calif., which has assets of $500 million and 10 branch offices in southern California, was put under the conservatorship of the bank board last summer.

headline: AN OFFICIAL OF NICARAGUAN REBELS ADMITS TAKING FUNDS FROM NORTH
abstract: LEAD: Alfonso Robelo, a top Nicaraguan rebel leader, said tonight that his political party and an affiliated group together received at least $100,000 in contributions in 1985 and 1986 from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide.

headline: Noncallable Debentures Of Seagram Yield 8.41%
abstract: LEAD: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent debentures due in 2007 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 8.41 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters.

headline: WALL STREET IS FACING REAPPRAISAL
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street, struggling to clear itself of the taint spread by the insider trading scandal, is facing the most thorough re-examination and perhaps overhaul of its self-regulatory system since the Depression.

headline: CONDE NAST MAGAZINES GET NEW PUBLISHERS
abstract: LEAD: Marianne Howatson, after less than a year as publisher of Travel & Leisure magazine, is leaving to become publisher of Self magazine, making her the first woman publisher at Conde Nast in the company's 75-year history.

headline: ICAHN BIDS $1.4 BILLION FOR USAIR
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, offered yesterday to buy USAir Group Inc. for $1.4 billion, but some analysts suggested that he really wanted to force the opposite: the sale of T.W.A. to USAir.

headline: TRADE PACT IS SET WITH EUROPEANS
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the European Community reached an accord today resolving a major trade conflict over American grain exports to Spain.

headline: FOR 'OLDER BOYS AND GIRLS' OF CHINA, MATCHMAKING
abstract: LEAD: Chen Gaixin is a fussy romantic.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Compaq Computer Corp., Houston, said it had cut the price on its Deskpro Model 2 to $1,699, from $2,399, and reduced the number of models of the Compaq Deskpro line.

headline: Article 907487 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government deficit surged to $28.37 billion in February, the biggest imbalance in nine months, the Treasury Department said today.

headline: Comic Touch For Carpets
abstract: LEAD: Allied Fibers will be rolling out its multimillion dollar Anso V Worry-Free carpet print and broadcast campaign in March.

headline: ISRAEL WILL CURB ARMS FOR PRETORIA
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Cabinet decided today not to sign new military sales contracts with South Africa, Cabinet officials said. They said it had acted in response to pressure from Congress and American Jews to curtail Israel's relations with Pretoria.

headline: Contra Suppliers Seen As Vowing Not to Talk
abstract: LEAD: Americans who took part last year in a purportedly private operation to supply the Nicaraguan rebels had to promise the Government not to divulge secret information they might learn, The Boston Globe reported today.

headline: Merrill Net Up Sharply In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: In a sign of the enormously profitable environment that most of Wall Street has been enjoying, Merrill Lynch & Company, the country's largest brokerage house, reported yesterday that its net earnings nearly tripled in the fourth quarter.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: FITZGERALD LEAVES IRISH PARTY POST
abstract: LEAD: Garret FitzGerald, architect of the British-Irish accord on Northern Ireland, resigned today as leader of the Fine Gael Party, a day after leaving the post of Prime Minister because his party was defeated in the general election last month.

headline: 2 Die in Marseilles Car Blast
abstract: LEAD: Two people were killed today when their car exploded in front of a school in a suburb here, sources said. The police were said to be investigating whether a bomb had been planted in the car. An incendiary device was reported found in another car parked nearby.

headline: COMPROMISE EXPECTED ON CHIP CONSORTIUM
abstract: LEAD: The nation's leading chip makers remain deeply divided over how to structure a last-ditch effort against Japan's electronics giants, but they expect a compromise to be reached tomorrow as they meet in Washington.

headline: IN BEIRUT, ONLY THE CALAMITIES CHANGE
abstract: LEAD: A Lebanese man returning to Beirut after a six-week vacation abroad found many changes in the city.

headline: Borg-Jacobs Talks Collapse
abstract: LEAD: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that it had held talks with Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, who has made a takeover attempt, but that those discussions broke down.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Donald V. Gill has been appointed executive vice president at SSC&B:Lintas USA.

headline: PATENTS; A New Cable Device To Lift Aircraft Cargoes
abstract: LEAD: Edwin Z. Gabriel, an engineering consultant in Ocean Grove, N.J., believes the hoist cable coupling device he patented this week will facilitate the loading and unloading of cargoes in helicopters and other aircraft.

headline: Italian Labor Leaders Meet With Jaruzelski
abstract: LEAD: Italian labor leaders urged Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today to allow Polish workers greater freedom in organizing trade unions.

headline: LONDON POLICE PLAN TO USE EVEN FEWER GUNS
abstract: LEAD: The London police, who have traditionally disdained the widespread use of firearms to combat criminals, have announced that they will further reduce the number of officers authorized to use guns.

headline: The U.N. Today: Feb. 13, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: G.E. TV Order Shifted to U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company said today that it would begin to make midsize color television sets at a plant in Bloomington, Ind. The sets were previously made overseas.

headline: Hewlett Co-founder Retiring From Post
abstract: LEAD: William R. Hewlett, who founded the Hewlett-Packard Company with David Packard in 1939, will retire as vice chairman effective Feb. 24, the company said yesterday. Mr. Hewlett, 73 years old, is best known for his innovative engineering and people-oriented style of management.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 5, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Ashton-Tate Charges Theft
abstract: LEAD: Ashton-Tate Inc., a computer software concern, said it had sued its former chief scientist and five others for reportedly stealing technology. The Superior Court suit contends that the six people took proprietary information from Ashton-Tate to use at their own companies.

headline: PROTECTIONISM
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: HIGH U.S. OFFICIAL ARRIVES IN POLAND
abstract: LEAD: The Deputy Secretary of State, John Whitehead, arrived here today on an official visit to determine whether the United States should keep up economic sanctions against Poland.

headline: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Reagan Flustered, Tower Reports
abstract: LEAD: Members of the Tower Commission said today that they were surprised and dismayed by President Reagan's lack of knowledge about the Iran-contra affair during their two lengthy discussions last month.

headline: TECHNOLOGY SEEN AS TOP SECTOR
abstract: LEAD: Technology companies are likely to outperform the rest of American manufacturing in 1987, the Government predicted in an annual forecast. But as in the past, it said that service industries should do much better than manufacturing.

headline: Early Effort Thwarted
abstract: LEAD: Shooting broke out today as the two United Nations trucks loaded with food approached Burj al Brajneh. Witnesses said the trucks' tires were shot out by unidentified gunmen and the vehicles were abandoned yards from their destination.

headline: UNIVERSITIES FACE A CRISIS IN ISRAEL
abstract: LEAD: Israel's universities, the reputation and achievements of which have been a source of national pride, are facing a severe financial crisis.

headline: 2 DIE IN DUBLIN APARTMENT FIRE
abstract: LEAD: Two explosions, probably caused by a gas leak, destroyed a five-story apartment building in Dublin today and killed a husband and wife, the police said.

headline: Invited Observers From NATO Watch a Polish Army Exercise
abstract: LEAD: Observers from NATO watched today as the Polish Army conducted war games, the first time in 11 years that Westerners were allowed to attend.

headline: PRETORIA REACHES PACT ON DEBT IT FROZE IN '85
abstract: LEAD: South Africa and its creditor banks have reached agreement on the repayment of the $13 billion in debt on which Pretoria halted payments in 1985, the Government announced today.

headline: Philippines Buying San Miguel Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Philippines' social security system is planning to buy 8 million shares in the San Miguel Corporation, the company's chief financial officer, Ramon Del Rosario, said. He said the Government organization was preparing to invest $40 million.

headline: U.S. URGES CUT IN DEPENDENCE ON FOREIGN OIL
abstract: LEAD: Continued dependence on Mideast oil will pose a security threat for the rest of the century or longer and Government initiatives are needed to reduce this vulnerability, according to an Administration study to be published Tuesday.

headline: BEIJING TO REVAMP LEADERSHIP IN FALL
abstract: LEAD: Zhao Ziyang will remain both Prime Minister and acting Communist Party leader only until a party congress convenes in September, Chinese officials said today.

headline: Robots Right at Home In This Region
abstract: LEAD: THE Westchester-Connecticut region, rarely identified as a center for high-technology manufacturing companies, has within its boundaries two of the world's major producers of industrial robots. One of them, Unimation Inc., was the first company in the world to produce an industrial robot - not in Japan but in Danbury,

headline: HOSTAGES' FAMILIES SAY THEIR EFFORT IS A CASUALTY OF THE IRAN ARMS AFFAIR
abstract: LEAD: When the Iran arms deal became public, Peggy Say's mail began to turn ugly.

headline: NO PLANS TO PUBLISH SOLZHENITSYN WORK, SOVIET OFFICIAL SAYS
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet spokesman said today that there were no plans to publish ''Cancer Ward,'' Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's novel about the stagnation and moral deterioration of Soviet life in the 1950's.

headline: Market Place; Thrift Stock Opportunities
abstract: LEAD: WHILE many savings and loan institutions have recently posted record earnings -mainly from taking in more interest than they pay out - in many instances stock prices have failed to reflect those gains.

headline: A.T.&T. to Develop New Unix Model
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it plans to develop with the Microsoft Corporation a new version of its Unix computer operating system for the 80386 microprocessor built by the Intel Corporation. Unix is an advanced software system that enables users to manage a variety of data through its multi-tasking and multi-user functions.

headline: New Venture Offers Catalogues for Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Catalog Retail Corporation, New Canaan, Conn., of which Jay Walker, formerly of Folio, is chairman, will begin its new business of selling catalogues in retail outlets on Feb. 1. Mr. Walker says there is a demand.  Catalogues priced from $1 to $3 will be displayed in freestanding racks. The first 1,000 racks will be in outlets of Waldenbooks and Eastern Newsstands, which operates in office buildings in three markets.

headline: M'FARLANE INQUIRY CLOSED, POLICE SAY
abstract: LEAD: Police officials said today that the drug overdose taken by Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, was apparently a suicide attempt but that they had ended their investigation because there were no grounds for criminal charges.

headline: Russian Can't Attend Wife's U.S. Funeral
abstract: LEAD: Naum Meiman, a Jewish dissident and mathematician, said today that Soviet authorities had refused to allow him to attend the funeral of his wife, Inna, who died of cancer in Washington.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday

headline: U.S. PLANS TO SPIN OFF TECHNICAL DATA SERVICE
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration is planning to spin off the Commerce Department's National Technical Information Service, a clearinghouse for both United States Government and foreign government technical information, over the complaints of many of the agency's users.

headline: CON ED TAX-EXEMPTS OFFERED TO YIELD 7 1/8%
abstract: LEAD: At a time when 7 percent yields on tax-exempt bonds are becoming hard to find, the New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation is offering $100.8 million of 7 1/8 percent bonds due in 2022 on behalf of the Consolidated Edison Company.

headline: JAPAN ASKS 10% CUT IN CHIP OUTPUT
abstract: LEAD: In an attempt to control mounting friction over semiconductor trade, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry has asked Japanese semiconductor makers to cut production of some computer memory chips by 10 percent in the first three months of this year.

headline: Piedmont Aviation Gains
abstract: LEAD: Piedmont Aviation Inc. said its fourth-quarter earnings rose 9.1 percent, to $17.5 million, or 78 cents a share, from $16 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 22.1 percent, to $509.8 million.

headline: Soviet Psychiatrist Says Son Has Been Released
abstract: LEAD: The International Association for Human Rights said here today that Ivan Koryagin, the son of a dissident Soviet psychiatrist, had been freed from labor camp, and the family had been told to apply for emigration.

headline: Ginnie Mae's President Lured Back to Nebraska
abstract: LEAD: Glenn Wilson says he has mixed feelings about going home to Nebraska after two years in Washington as president of the Government National Mortgage Association.

headline: DOW WILL SELL SOUTH AFRICA UNITS
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company will complete its withdrawal from South Africa with the sale of its chemicals and plastics marketing operations to a consortium of investors, the company said. Dow declined to release details of its sale of the marketing offices, which employ about 70 people. A Dow spokesman said the offices do $45 million to $50 million in business annually, through sales of imported chemical and plastic products in South

headline: IRANIAN MISSILES FIRED AT BASRA AND BAGHDAD
abstract: LEAD: Asserting that it had opened a ''second stage'' of its new offensive in the Persian Gulf war, Iran fired missiles today into the Iraqi cities of Baghdad and Basra.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Virginia Housing Development Authority is offering $160 million of fixed- and floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations through First Boston Corporation as sole underwriter.

headline: Article 269387 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: A former executive of the Mitsubishi Bank of California was charged today with embezzling $44.9 million from the bank and conducting almost $1 billion in fraudulent transactions to cover up the scheme.

headline: DOW FLIRTS WITH 2,000, THEN DIPS
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average zeroed in on the 2,000 mark yesterday, but the historic level proved elusive.

headline: Equality in Ads
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  ''A Grueling Struggle for Equality'' (Nov. 9) did not have to make use of 1961 classified ads to illustrate the 1960 survey statement, ''Whatever their work skills, less attractive women were rejected - even in the classified ads.'' A review of the classifieds in the Nov. 9, 1986, edition of The New York

headline: Dome Reported In Buyout Bid
abstract: LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd. and the British Petroleum Company declined to comment today on a published report that the multinational oil company was negotiating to acquire Dome, which is burdened with debt.

headline: Soviet Dissident Is Sent To Psychiatric Clinic
abstract: LEAD: A former Soviet airline navigator whose nine-year battle to leave the Soviet Union received widespread attention in the West was seized by plainclothesmen tonight and sent to a Moscow psychiatric clinic, the man's daughter said.

headline: THE ALLURE OF STOCK BUYBACKS
abstract: LEAD: The soaring stock market, which has lifted many stocks to record highs, has not cooled corporate America's love affair with that one sure-fire way to bolster share prices and please investors: the buyback.

headline: A BUYOUT OF REVLON IS STUDIED
abstract: LEAD: After insisting for months that he planned to keep the Revlon Corporation publicly owned, Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of the cosmetics concern, said yesterday that he was considering taking it private.

headline: Chief Operating Post Is Filled by GF Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The GF Corporation, a maker of steel and wood office furniture said yesterday that it had named Richard D. Major as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Police in Punjab Raid Sikh Temple Complex
abstract: LEAD: Paramilitary police forces in the Punjab entered the Sikh religion's holiest shrine today and arrested several people suspected of terrorist activities, according to news reports here.

headline: BOLIVIA COCAINE TRADE REVIVES AFTER G.I.'S GO
abstract: LEAD: At the airport, the hot wind coming off the savanna whistles among rows of small private planes that have not flown in several months, having been grounded by the authorities.

headline: MOZAMBIQUE SAYS IT BLOCKED PRETORIA AID TO REBELS
abstract: LEAD: President Joaquim A. Chissano of Mozambique asserted here today that his forces had blocked a recent attempt by rebels to obtain supplies from South Africa by sea.

headline: Gencorp's Bidders Plan RKO Selloffs
abstract: LEAD: An investor group attempting a hostile $2.2 billion takeover of Gencorp Inc. said yesterday that, if it won, it would sell all broadcasting properties owned by Gencorp's subsidiary RKO General Inc.

headline: Disposable Camera Plans
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. Inc. said separately yesterday that they planned to market disposable color cameras.

headline: Revelstoke Stores
abstract: LEAD: The Revelstoke Companies said it would sell its 52 rural building supply stores to Home Hardware Stores Ltd. for about $25 million. The final price will depend on inventory levels when Home Hardware takes over the stores, according to Revelstoke. The transaction is scheduled to close on Jan. 30. The stores being sold had 1986 sales of $59 million, the company said.

headline: ERASING THE SLUMS? THE 64-SQUARE-FOOT QUESTION
abstract: LEAD: A white canvas apron around her, Zhi Xiuying plowed a metal spatula through the thick white flakes of cabbage in the iron wok, leaving small furrows.

headline: Shultz and Shamir Ask Soviet To Ease Its Emigration Curbs
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union today to relax restrictions on emigration.

headline: Slim Pickings Elsewhere
abstract: LEAD: Outside the financial stocks, definitions of ''undervalued'' must be stretched for many names to surface. One money manager scanned his entire list for a cheap stock before coming back with a verbal shrug, ''None.'' The rare companies with low P/E multiples or large discounts from book value generally have problems that discourage analysts from recommending them.

headline: U.S. SAYS SOVIET ARMS BID OFFERS MUCH BUT HAS GAPS
abstract: LEAD: A preliminary analysis by American negotiators in Geneva says the latest Soviet proposal on medium-range arms includes some noteworthy concessions but also fails to address some important American concerns, Administration officials said today.

headline: ARMS NEGOTIATORS TO MEET IN GENEVA OVER MISSILE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have scheduled a special session in Geneva on Monday to discuss a Soviet proposal that the two nations reach a separate agreement on medium-range missiles in Europe.

headline: ONCE AGAIN, TOKYO'S IN TROUBLE OVER FINGERPRINTING OF ALIENS
abstract: LEAD: Japan has put together a new set of regulations to fingerprint and keep track of the foreigners in its midst.

headline: U.S. AIDES CONFER ON A LATIN PEACE
abstract: LEAD: Two senior United States officials met in Miami today with Costa Rica's Foreign Minister to discuss a new diplomatic initiative in Central America.

headline: Economic Scene; Preventing A Money Crisis
abstract: LEAD: EXCITEMENT in the stock market and the foreign-exchange market is reaching a fever pitch. Professional money managers are getting worried as the stock market seems to soar farther and farther away from the reality of a sluggish economy. But the pressure for performance keeps institutional investors buying stocks, anyway.

headline: Cox Enterprises Chief To Retire at Year's End
abstract: LEAD: Garner Anthony, chairman and chief executive of Cox Enterprises, a privately held media company based in Atlanta, has announced that he will retire at the end of the year.

headline: JAPANESE ACT ON CHIP FLOW
abstract: LEAD: Japan is tightening restrictions on microchip exports to countries other than the United States in an attempt to preserve an American-Japanese agreement on semiconductor trade. But Japanese chip makers say they doubt the move will work. The Ministry of International

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * BHP Finance Ltd. is issuing $75 million (Australian) of 14 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1992 at a price of 101 1/2 through Orion Royal Bank Ltd.

headline: 2 New York Stations To Accept Condom Ads
abstract: LEAD: Both the New York stations of the CBS and NBC television networks announced yesterday that effective immediately they would accept condom advertising as long as it was related to combating AIDS.

headline: INTRODUCTION
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday:  1. Biomedical Research and The Teaching of the Church

headline: GAF Chemicals Picks a President
abstract: LEAD: For Heinn F. Tomfohrde 2d, formerly the president of specialty and service businesses for the ailing Union Carbide Corporation, the world has taken a peculiar turn. Yesterday, the 51-year-old chemical engineer was named president of the GAF Chemicals Corporation, a unit of the same company that last year mounted a ferocious attempt to acquire

headline: DRAGONAIR, A GNAT THAT ROARS
abstract: LEAD: Dragonair, a 22-month-old airline that owns one plane and leases another, has a burning ambition. It wants to become a major international carrier.

headline: Jimmy Carter in Cairo On a Middle East Visit
abstract: LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he might get new information about American and other foreign hostages held in Lebanon during a visit to Syria over the weekend.

headline: SOVIET MOVES TO PAY MORE TO BETTER WORKERS
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has began a basic overhaul of its wage system aimed at halting a trend toward egalitarianism.

headline: Israelis Wound an Arab Youth Trying to Flee Arrest in Gaza
abstract: LEAD: Israeli forces shot and seriously wounded a Palestinian youth today as he tried to escape from arrest after taking part in an anti-Israeli demonstration in the occupied Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said.

headline: Markets Open Today
abstract: LEAD: Financial markets are open today, but all Government offices will be closed in observance of the holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Banks in New York and New Jersey have the option of remaining open, while all Connecticut banks will be closed.

headline: U.S. GROUP FINDS NO IMPROVEMENT IN CONTRAS' HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD
abstract: LEAD: A human rights organization issued a report today citing systematic killings by the Nicaraguan rebels and widespread human rights violations by the Nicaraguan Government.

headline: Talking Deals; Brokers Trade Themselves
abstract: LEAD: TRADING on one's fate is the ultimate form of deal-making, and there has been a lot of it in the current Wall Street scandal. Such cooperation with the Government has never taken place with such regularity in a case of white-collar crime and it has led to a rash of guilty pleas, subpoenas and a sense of unease in the financial community.

headline: Rolls-Boeing Deal
abstract: LEAD: Rolls-Royce, one of the world's largest jet engine makers, said it had agreed to install engines in a new generation of the Boeing Company's civilian aircraft. Rolls-Royce said it would put its RB 211-524 D4D engine in the Boeing B-767 family of aircraft, a successor to the B-747's that have been powered by Rolls engines.

headline: Washington Watch; A Banking Bill Rush
abstract: LEAD: The rush has already begun in Congress to pass major banking bills. Lobbyists say they cannot remember when the chairmen of the two banking committees, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, have worked so feverishly to pass early legislation.

headline: QADDAFI AND ARAFAT MEND FENCES
abstract: LEAD: Libya, joining efforts to heal a four-year-old breach in the Palestine Liberation Organization, has reconciled with the wing of the guerrilla movement that is led by Yasir Arafat.

headline: AFRICAN SEEKING U.S. HEARING ON BURUNDI KILLINGS
abstract: LEAD: For the last 15 years, an African woman has sought to focus public attention on the mass killings in Burundi in 1972, win compensation for the families of victims and rehabilitate the name of her husband, a former Cabinet minister who was executed after he was accused of being an author of an uprising that preceded the killings.

headline: NYNEX AND PACTEL GAIN; SOUTHWESTERN BELL DOWN
abstract: LEAD: The Nynex Corporation and the Pacific Telesis Group yesterday reported higher fourth-quarter profits, while earnings fell at the Southwestern Bell Corporation.

headline: EXECUTIVE AT INTEL PROMOTED TO CHIEF
abstract: LEAD: The Intel Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer chips, announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Andrew S. Grove, will become chief executive at the next shareholders meeting in April. Dr. Grove, a Hungarian immigrant and author of a popular book on management, will inherit the mantle from Gordon E.

headline: COMPUTER VENTURE CONFIRMED BY PEROT
abstract: LEAD: H. Ross Perot, founder of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, confirmed today that he had invested $20 million for a 16 percent stake and a board seat in Next Inc., the start-up company formed by Apple Computer Inc.'s co-founder, Steven P. Jobs.

headline: Champion's Net Rises 69.3%
abstract: LEAD: The Champion International Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 69.3 percent from a year earlier despite an 8.3 percent drop in sales. The manufacturer of papers, newsprint and other wood products attributed the earnings gain to improved business conditions and internal cost-cutting.

headline: SHULTZ GETS A RIVERBOAT INTRODUCTION TO CHINA
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in China this morning and spent most of his first day enveloped in the graceful tranquillity of the countryside before flying on to Beijing for a formal state banquet in the Great Hall of the People.

headline: FINANCE CHIEF RESIGNS AT VW
abstract: LEAD: Rolf Selowsky, the chief financial officer at Volkswagen A.G., resigned Saturday, the company announced.

headline: GULF WAR THREATENING THE GOOD LIFE
abstract: LEAD: It is 9 o'clock on a Saturday night at the Sultan Center, and Kuwaitis are doing one of the things they do best: consuming.

headline: Sosnoff's $28 Offer Rejected by Caesarsm
abstract: LEAD: Caesars World Inc. yesterday rejected a $28-a-share tender offer from Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor who already owns 13 percent of the company.

headline: HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE  NEW CHIEF, NEW MOOD; Choice of Baker Called Proof of Seriousness By President in Combating His Difficulties
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan's choice of former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as his new chief of staff was taken by official Washington today as the first distinct sign in months that the President is rousing himself from a kind of political torpor. Since before Christmas, Republicans, Democrats, Reagan intimates and foreign envoys have made the departure of Donald T.

headline: Talking Business with Bowers of United Airlines; Discount Fares' Recent Impact
abstract: LEAD: At the end of January, Continental and Eastern airlines cut their lowest discount fares by 40 percent on most domestic flights. The rest of the industry followed. There was a catch, however: Once a customer bought a ticket, it was nonrefundable.

headline: THE 'GOOD NEIGHBOR' OFFERS LITTLE AID, LESS TRADE
abstract: LEAD: FOR the Fathom Dive Suits Company of Orlando, Fla., President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative seemed just the right opportunity to begin manufacturing rubber wet suits on the island of St. Lucia.

headline: Henry J. Kaufman Gets Automobile Association
abstract: LEAD: The American Automobile Association in Washington has consolidated its advertising at Henry J. Kaufman & Associates, also in Washington.

headline: Business and the Law; Board Liability In Delaware
abstract: LEAD: LAST June, the state of Delaware - home to most of the nation's largest companies - passed a law allowing corporations to limit, or even eliminate, their directors' financial liability for some kinds of mistakes. Under the Delaware law, shareholders can vote to eliminate the directors' liability, except in cases of disloyalty, bad faith or intentional misconduct.

headline: Treasury Statement
abstract: LEAD: Selected data on the United States Government's spending and debt contained in the Treasury Department's monthly statement, which was released yesterday. Amounts are in millions of dollars; fiscal years run from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30.          Total Public Debt, Feb.   $2,226,109        Interest on Public Debt, Feb.

headline: REAGAN REPORTED UNABLE TO RECALL IRAN ARMS DECISION
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan is unable to say with certainty if he approved in advance the first American-sanctioned arms shipment to Iran in the fall of 1985 because he genuinely cannot remember, acording to a senior Administration official who is familiar with the President's testimony to the Tower Commission.

headline: THE U.N. TODAY: FEB. 17, 1987
abstract: LEAD: SECURITY COUNCIL  Meets at 3:30 P.M. on South Africa.  GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Scientific and Technical Subcommittee on Outer Space - 10:30 A.M and 3:00 P.M  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL  United Nations Development Program: Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: DURBAN POLICE QUELL MOB WITH BIRDSHOT
abstract: LEAD: The police fired tear gas and birdshot to disperse looters on a black beach, and a black mob attacked a train and killed an Indian youth during a New Year's Day of racial violence on the Indian Ocean coast.

headline: ASHTON-TATE PROFIT UP
abstract: LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, a software maker, said earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, grew 77 percent, to $10.6 million, or 43 cents a share, from $6 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose to $62.9 million from $41.5 million.

headline: Clabir to Pursue Bid for Atlantic
abstract: LEAD: The Clabir Corporation, a military contractor, said that it intended to pursue its efforts to acquire the Atlantic Research Corporation. Atlantic Research, which is based in Alexandria, Va., makes rocket motors and high-technology products. It has rejected Clabir's acquisition proposal.

headline: NORTEK-REXHAM
abstract: LEAD: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7.8 percent stake in the Rexham Corporation and said it might seek control of the Charlotte, N.C., packaging products concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Nortek said it had bought the Rexham shares ''with a view to acquiring a significant equity interest'' in the company, but added that any possible acquisition of the company was ''subject to future developments.

headline: Microsoft Action Against Falcon
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation said that in response to its copyright infringement action, a Federal district judge here had issued a preliminary order blocking three Taiwan companies and a California company from copying, importing, disseminating or distributing a program, Falcon MS-DOS. Microsoft said Falcon was a copy of its MS-DOS operating system for the I.B.M.

headline: Airbus Planes For All Nippon
abstract: LEAD: Airbus Industrie said yesterday that All Nippon Airways had agreed to buy 10 Airbus A320-200 aircraft, with an option for 10 more. The order could be worth about $1 billion if the options are exercised.

headline: DDB Needham Gets GTE Spacenet Account
abstract: LEAD: DDB Needham Worldwide, Washington, has won the GTE Spacenet account, which will add $2.5 million to $3 million in billings to the $50 million in GTE business already at the New York office.

headline: Global Bull Market Had Vigorous Year
abstract: LEAD: The performance of stock markets around the world startled many investment professionals in 1986, the second consecutive year of an extraordinary worldwide bull market.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: LEAD: ''As recent unfortunate events have demonstrated, we cannot be complacent about racism and bigotry.'' - President Reagan.  [ A12:5. ]

headline: Market Place; Broader Rally: Hope Growing
abstract: LEAD: FOR the first time in more than six months, portfolio managers and investment strategists see the possibility that a market rally that has been largely confined to the highly capitalized issues that make up the Dow Jones industrial average could become much more broadly based.

headline: Mexico Gives OPEC a Symbolic Lift
abstract: LEAD: Mexico will support the effort of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce world crude oil surpluses and force oil prices higher by cutting its own oil exports. The cuts seem to be largely symbolic, however, since the Government cannot afford serious reductions in foreign earnings.

headline: Patents; Image Analysis System
abstract: LEAD: Jerome H. Lemelson of Princeton, N.J., believes that the image analysis system for which he and Christian Grund were granted patent 4,653,109 this week will be useful in watching and regulating chemical production and other manufacturing operations. Work under way is scanned by television and studied by computer.

headline: Seoul Said To Seek U.S. Goods
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's top economic official said today that the dollar's 40 percent fall against the Japanese yen was spurring South Korea to shift purchases of industrial goods to the United States from Japan.

headline: Shultz Congratulates Baker From Half a World Away
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz at an American exhibition in Hong Kong. On his way to China for a six-day visit he said: ''Howard Baker is a patriot who possesses just that combination of intellect, wisdom and savvy needed at this juncture. I welcome his appointment with enthusiasm.'' (AP)

headline: REAGAN REPORTED TO LIMIT DEBATE IN GENEVA ON DEFENSE SYSTEMS
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has instructed American arms officials in Geneva not to negotiate or even discuss limits on defensive systems that would be more restrictive than the Administration's new interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials said today.

headline: Announcements Expected on Two Note Sales
abstract: LEAD: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills. The bill auctions were delayed until today because of the Presidents' Day holiday yesterday.

headline: PATENTS; Cooling A Nuclear Reactor
abstract: LEAD: EQUIPMENT designed to collect and cool the core elements of a nuclear reactor in case of overheating has been invented for the Department of Energy.

headline: Ditto Westchester
abstract: LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S development as a major economic center for the region continued unabated in the last half of 1986.

headline: Japan Vehicle Output Off
abstract: LEAD: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses declined for the fourth consecutive month in January, dropping 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today, linking the sluggish production to a slump in domestic sales. The association said that 936,916 vehicles were produced last month.

headline: Japan's Economy Slow
abstract: LEAD: Japan's economy is likely to stay sluggish in coming months as the high value of the yen dampens business, according to Government figures issued today. The leading economic indicator for December was 50, up from 41.7 in November. Above 50 implies a pickup; below 50 implies a slowdown.

headline: THE VATICAN ON BIRTH SCIENCE; REPRODUCTIVE HELP: WIDESPREAD AND UNREGULATED
abstract: LEAD: The reproductive technologies condemned by the Roman Catholic Church yesterday have spread widely as accepted medical practice in the United States, approved by many ethics committees and largely unregulated by the Government.

headline: China Shows Growth of 9%
abstract: LEAD: Industrial growth in China in 1986 declined to just over 9 percent, from a runaway 18 percent in 1985, thanks to better control of the economy, Chinese officials said today.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Arizona Public Service Co. is offering $150 million of Baa-2/BBB+ rated 9 percent first-mortgage bonds due 2017, at 99, to yield 9.10 percent, through the First Boston Corporation. Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds yield 1.46 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bond due 2016.

headline: I.M.F.-LIKE PACT SEEN FOR BRAZIL
abstract: LEAD: Regional bankers and others familiar with the Brazilian debt crisis said yesterday that they expected a compromise to emerge under which Brazil would agree to a package of reforms similar to an International Monetary Fund economic program. In return, the banks would issue new loans and restructure old ones.

headline: For Immigrants, a Rough Road
abstract: LEAD: FOR years, the prevailing wisdom on how immigrants fare in the labor market has been based on the notion that assimilation is a key, even determining, factor. Drawing mainly on 1970 Census data, studies concluded that while earnings of new immigrants were lower than those of comparably situated native workers, earnings of immigrants who had been here for more than a decade exceeded those of native workers of the same age, education and so on.

headline: Battle Reported in Sahara
abstract: LEAD: Polisario guerrillas marked the 11th anniversary of their self-styled republic today and said 213 Moroccans had been killed in a battle in the Western Sahara on Wednesday. A Polisario communique also said 83 Moroccans were taken prisoner, the Algerian press agency reported. Both the Moroccan Government and the Polisario, an Algerian-backed independence movement, claimed victory in the five-hour battle.

headline: HUNGARY'S PASSION: KEEPING UP WITH THE LASZLOS
abstract: LEAD: When the Rev. Antal Kuklay came here 14 years ago, his house, part of a former monastery, was the only two-story building in the village. The fine, yellow 18th-century mansion in the rounded and curled Central European baroque style looked down on the peasant homes that stretch in neat rows along the straight main street and behind.

headline: WHEN THE FOCUS TURNS TO FINANCE
abstract: LEAD: THE problem with a CD-ROM-stored data base, as I mentioned last week, is that while it is fine for someone delving into history, it will not do for up-to-the-minute information like stock quotations or just-breaking news stories. For that kind of timely data, one's computer needs access by modem to an on-line data base.

headline: Atari, Commodore Settle
abstract: LEAD: The Atari Corporation and Commodore International Ltd. said that all pending litigation between the two personal computer companies had been settled. Atari had sued the Amiga Corporation, which was later acquired by Commodore, for breach of contract in a deal to develop a new computer. It subsequently sued Commodore in Federal court for patent infringement.

headline: TED BATES PROMOTES 2 TO CREATIVE POSITIONS
abstract: LEAD: Ted Bates Advertising, a Saatchi & Saatchi subsidiary, has promoted Gordon Fenton, 45, and Robert L. Froelich, 49, executive vice presidents, to co-chief creative directors.

headline: English Is Property Of Aerospace Company
abstract: LEAD: According to a brochure from ROI Systems Inc., a Minneapolis-based company that develops manufacturing systems for its clients, ROI's Manage 2000 manufacturing resources planning system is easy to use because of its ''English-like query language.''

headline: TOWER PANEL CRITICISMS REJECTED BY WEINBERGER
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today rejected criticism of himself in the Tower Commmission report as ''totally unsupported by any evidence.''

headline: CHINA VOWS CURB ON FREE DISCUSSION
abstract: LEAD: After the replacement of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader, China's intellectuals were warned today that the recent atmosphere of freer expression and discussion would be sharply curtailed.

headline: AIDS Curbs in Prague
abstract: LEAD: The youth newspaper Mlada Fronta reported today that 27 people infected with the AIDS virus have been told to make pledges regarding their sexual conduct, including a promise to use condoms. The article did not say who had required the promises or what action would be taken if anyone refused to sign or violated a pledge.

headline: Hambrecht Aide Plans Expansion
abstract: LEAD: As head of his own small investment banking company, John A. Fisher was the architect of many of the mergers and acquisitions of California's premium wineries. His deals included the purchases of Ridge Vineyard Inc. and Chateau St. Jean by Japan's Otsuka Pharmaceutical Ltd. and Suntory Ltd., respectively.

headline: STOPPING THE HIGH-TECH GIVEAWAY
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Reagan Administration opposition forced Fujitsu Ltd. to drop its plans to buy control of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation last week, Fujitsu and Fairchild executives immediately made it clear that their relationship was not dead. The two companies now plan to enter into a series of technology-exchange and development programs and joint manufacturing projects that will enable the companies to make and sell each other's products.

headline: CHRYSLER SETS SPLIT, PAYOUT
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation declared a 3-for-2 stock split today and raised its cash dividend by 7 percent.

headline: STOCK STRENGTH PREDICTED...
abstract: LEAD: On Aug. 13, 1982, with the nation stumbling out of a recession, the Federal Reserve Board used its vast powers over interest rates to try to bring the economy out of its slump, and in doing so touched off the Great Bull Market of the 1980's.

headline: SOVIET EMIGRATION OF JEWS IS HIGHEST IN LAST FIVE YEARS
abstract: LEAD: More than 400 Soviet Jews have so far received permission to emigrate in March, the highest monthly figure since the end of 1981, Western diplomats and Soviet officials said today.

headline: Moscow Sets Grain Goal
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has set a 1987 grain harvest target of 232 million metric tons, which would be the country's second- largest yield ever, the official news agency Tass said today. Agricultural experts at Western embassies said it was the first time in recent years that the Soviet Union had published an annual grain target in advance of the harvest, although it provides five-year-plan targets.

headline: New Emigrant Owners Are Tenacious Battlers
abstract: LEAD: In the Manhattan real estate business, the Milstein brothers are known as tenacious battlers with scores of skirmishes and lawsuits under their belt. Now they are going into the savings bank business, with the purchase last week of the Emigrant Savings Bank.

headline: REAGAN'S REMARKS SEEM TO ILLUSTRATE HOW A GANG CAN FOIL A SUPERPOWER
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration, which has made fighting terrorism such a visible priority, now finds itself with no attractive options in the face of the kidnappings of three Americans in Beirut over the weekend.

headline: 2 SENIOR EXECUTIVES SWAPPING JOBS AT USG
abstract: LEAD: The USG Corporation of Chicago put some finishing touches on a sweeping management reorganization yesterday when it announced that two senior executives would be essentially swapping jobs and responsibilities.

headline: WYSE WINS SEALY
abstract: LEAD: The Ohio Mattress Company has assigned its $5 million Sealy Mattress account to the Cleveland office of Wyse Advertising, which already had $2 million in billings from the company. The former agency was Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Chicago, which did not lie down on the job.

headline: 2 CHURCHES AGREE ON SALVATION ISSUE
abstract: LEAD: A joint Anglican-Roman Catholic group says it has resolved one of the major doctrinal disputes that gave rise to the Protestant Reformation.

headline: Prince Edward Quits The Royal Marines
abstract: LEAD: Prince Edward, Queen Elizabeth's youngest son and fifth in line to the British throne, quit the Royal Marines today, breaking a century-old tradition of princes serving tours of duty in the armed forces.

headline: ISRAELI INDICTED IN POLLARD CASE GIVES UP HIS POST
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Air Force officer accused of recruiting an American intelligence analyst as a spy announced tonight that he was giving up his recent military promotion because of the problems it had caused between Israel and the United States.

headline: New York State Offers Securities
abstract: LEAD: New York State is offering $78 million of securities with yields ranging from 3.50 percent for an issue due in six months to 4.70 percent in 1992 and 5.50 percent in 1997, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: SOME FEARS OF COMPLACENCY
abstract: LEAD: Strong economic data in February were the catalyst for some analysts to raise their forecasts for business activity and for interest rates, but those warnings have been largely ignored in the bond market, where prices have been stable enough to revive memories of the pre-1979 ''good old days'' when a quartrer-point change was a notable event.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD: In percent           Passbook Savings   5.50        At savings institutions               Tax-Exempt Bonds   6.54        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   5.57        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.42        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   10.01        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average

headline: EX-DEFENSE MINISTER URGES FILIPINOS TO REJECT DRAFT CHARTER
abstract: LEAD: Juan Ponce Enrile, who was dismissed in November as Defense Minister, said today that President Corazon C. Aquino's Government was a dictatorship, and he urged voters to reject a draft constitution.

headline: PROS AND CONS OF LIVING TRUST
abstract: LEAD: EUGENE SCHWARTZ, a retired teacher in Scarsdale, N.Y., has been thinking recently about establishing a revocable living trust.

headline: G.M. Plans Cuts in Flint
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said 800 of the 3,900 workers at its engine plant in Flint, Mich., would be laid off indefinitely as part of a production change. A G.M. spokesman said the layoffs at the plant, which builds engines for Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Cadillacs, were the result of a change in production from V-6 engines for rear-drive cars, to new front-drive

headline: R.J. Reynolds Talks
abstract: LEAD: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company is holding discussions with potential buyers for its smoking tobacco and little-cigar businesses, company officials said. ''These products now account for less than 1 percent of Reynolds Tobacco's total sales,'' said Gerald H. Long, the company's president and chief executive.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Travelers Corporation yesterday began offering $200 million of 7 1/4 percent notes due in 1997 at 99.625 to yield 7.679 percent. The underwriters are led by Dillon, Read & Company.

headline: A.M.C. Reports A Profit Again
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation today reported its first quarterly profit in two years: $20 million, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $938.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1986, in contrast to a loss of $6.7 million on sales of $1.1 billion a year earlier.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. named Steven D. Goldstein executive vice president and general manager of the new service establishment division of the Consumer Card Group USA.

headline: U.S. Envoy Denies Discussing Any Arms Shipments to Iran
abstract: LEAD: Maxwell M. Rabb, the Ambassador to Italy, denied in a New York courtroom yesterday that he had discussed arms shipments to Iran with a defendant in a criminal case.

headline: J.A.L.-Boeing Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said Japan Air Lines had ordered three 747-300 jetliners and four 767-300's, and had upgraded an earlier order in a deal totaling $575 million. The orders include the substitution of two 767-300's for two previously ordered 767-200 models of the wide-body twinjet. The lengthened 767's are to be delivered between next September and June of next year, while one 747 is for delivery in December and the other two next year.

headline: LAW ON EMIGRATION IN EFFECT IN SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: American officials remain concerned that recent steps by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to liberalize some elements of Soviet society may not touch restrictions on emigration, a major obstacle in relations between the two countries.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: LEAD: An article last Sunday about portfolio insurance misstated the current affiliations of Hayne Leland and Mark Rubinstein. They are professors of finance at the University of California, Berkeley Business School.

headline: U.S. Seeking Agreement to Use Air Base in Zaire
abstract: LEAD: The Defense Department is seeking an agreement with Zaire that would allow the United States to use an air base to support a wide range of activities in central and southern Africa, a Pentagon official said today.

headline: Japanese Agency Sells Notes in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Export-Import Bank of Japan is offering in the United States capital market a $100 million issue of 10-year guaranteed notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Forbes Magazine Quits Publishers Association
abstract: LEAD: Forbes magazine resigned from the Magazine Publishers Association last month, according to a source close to that publication.

headline: PLAN FOR FARM LOANS STUDIED
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to bring more money to the nation's farming sector, the Federal Government and industry groups are studying a plan that would enable small agricultural banks to sell billions of dollars in farm mortgages to Wall Street investors, according to officials and bankers.

headline: INVESTING; THE ADRENALIN BEHIND DRUG STOCKS
abstract: LEAD: THE talk about the drug stocks these days sounds remarkably similar to the debate over the prospects of the stock market in general. Those who own the drug stocks cite the falling dollar and the companies' growth prospects as evidence that share prices will rise, while those who are avoiding the group consider the stocks overpriced and mere beneficiaries of the flood of cash that has helped to drive up the market in general.

headline: Higher Auto Deficit With Japan Seen
abstract: LEAD: The chairmen of America's Big Three auto makers have told the Reagan Administration they expect America's automotive trade deficit with Japan to be larger this year than in 1986 despite a substantial decline of the dollar against the yen.

headline: TRIAL IN PRAGUE: FIVE JAZZ FANS VS. STATE POWER
abstract: LEAD: Five jazz enthusiasts who are advocates of cultural freedom were brought to court today, two of them in handcuffs, for directing a club of 5,000 jazz fans that the Government had ordered disbanded.

headline: CHILD DAY CARE PROFITS MOUNT
abstract: LEAD: OVER the last several years, with investors spotting the earnings prospects of child day care centers, the stocks of several of these companies have soared. Lately, however, there has been more play in the stock market in general, and investors are wondering if the day care stocks are settling down for a nap.

headline: KEY SENATOR DOUBTS ARMS-HOSTAGE DEAL WAS REAGAN'S GOAL
abstract: LEAD: Senator David Boren, the new Democratic chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said here today that he believed President Reagan did not intend to trade arms to Iran for hostages.

headline: ACCORD WITH EUROPE ON TRADE SEEMS NEAR
abstract: LEAD: American and European negotiators are close to an agreement that should keep a damaging trans-Atlantic trade war from breaking out this weekend, officials of both sides said today.

headline: Chicago Magazine Names Publisher
abstract: LEAD: Roger Tremblay, 38, the former associate publisher, advertising director and a vice president of Texas Monthly, will be moving the old bones to Chicago to take the publisher's chair at Chicago magazine.

headline: East Germans Oust American
abstract: LEAD: A 69-year-old American held by East Germany for protesting atop the Berlin Wall has been expelled and sent to the West, a United States spokesman said Friday. The American, John Runnings of Seattle, had been held in East Germany for three months.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Debt

headline: State Taxes, an Uneven Load: Connecticut
abstract: LEAD: For taxpayers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is riddled with reductions and eliminations of long-cherished tax breaks, and for many in the three-state region unforeseen consequences await.

headline: THE JEANS SHOOPE ADN BUSY BUTIKS OF VACI STREET
abstract: LEAD: Janos Kadar, for 30 years the leader of the Communist Party, is so proud of Vaci Street that last year he took his guest, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for a walk along it to show him the smiling face of Hungarian consumerism.

headline: EX-PRESIDENT OF LEBANON SURVIVES A CAR-BOMBING
abstract: LEAD: Four people were killed and more than 30 were wounded today as former President Camille Chamoun survived an assassination attempt in East Beirut.

headline: Levine Gets 2-Year Jail Term
abstract: LEAD: Dennis B. Levine, the former investment banker whose arrest last May led to the unraveling of the most serious insider-trader scandal in Wall Street history, was sentenced here today to two years in a Federal prison and ordered to pay $362,000 in fines.

headline: ICAHN CONFIRMS S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the takeover specialist who is chairman of Trans World Airlines, acknowledged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether he had violated securities laws.

headline: Running First Women's Bank Is Now a Man's Job
abstract: LEAD: MARTIN SIMON is not a woman.

headline: THAIS SAID TO BAR LAOTIAN REFUGEES
abstract: LEAD: With refugees arriving at nearly all of Thailand's borders, the Thai authorities appear to be toughening policies on Laotians, now the largest refugee group in the country.

headline: Signature Magazine Plans to Cut Rate Base
abstract: LEAD: Signature magazine, which was to go to a circulation rate base of 925,000, from 840,000, with its March issue under its old owner, the Citicorp Diners Club, is instead being cut back to 750,000 with the February issue under its new owner, Conde Nast Publications. That was announced yesterday by Ron Galotti,

headline: SRYIAN ASSURANCE TO IRAN REPORTED
abstract: LEAD: A senior Iranian official has reported receiving assurances from Syria that its troops in Lebanon have no intention of disarming Moslem militants loyal to Teheran, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

headline: PEOPLE
abstract: LEAD: Thomas Rost has joined Hal Riney & Partners, New York, as senior vice president, creative director.

headline: Canada Stand On U.S. Corn
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Import Tribunal upheld a countervailing duty on American corn imports today.

headline: Private French TV Franchise Sold
abstract: LEAD: The French press magnate Robert Hersant and the Italian television producer Silvio Berlusconi have won the franchise to run France's private television Channel Five. The Hersant-Berlusconi bid was one of two for the network. The other was from Sir James Goldsmith, publisher of the Express magazine group.

headline: COMPUTER SHAKEOUT AWAITED
abstract: LEAD: For a little more than two years, computers for scientific and technical users have been the hottest sector in the industry, sending manufacturers scrambling to keep up with demand. Though sales are still soaring, the manufacturers' ranks have so swelled that industry leaders and analysts alike say a shakeout is inevitable.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy  Japan's six chip makers were asked to honor an agreement with the U.S. The request by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry follows charges by U.S. trade officials that Japanese companies are continuing to ''dump'' computer chips - selling them below the cost of production - despite the agreement reached last July 31.

headline: ECUADOR GENERAL REPORTED IN HIDING
abstract: LEAD: With the political climate in Ecuador still tense, the rebellious air force general whose freedom was gained when commandos took the country's President hostage has gone into hiding.

headline: Hong Kong Stocks
abstract: LEAD: Hong Kong share prices ended 1986 at a record high, and analysts predicted further gains in 1987. The Hang Seng index, the main market index, rose more than 8 points, to 2,568.30, on the last day of 1986, leaving it more than 800 points above the 1985 finish. Brokers said that prices were buoyed by demand from small investors and big investment funds, which were encouraged by low local interest rates and a weak Hong Kong dollar, a factor that aids the colony's exports.

headline: NEW ORDERS CLIMB 4.1% AS MILITARY GOODS JUMP
abstract: LEAD: New orders to factories, spurred by an extraordinary demand for military equipment, climbed 4.1 percent in November, the biggest increase in two years, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Changes at Top At Shearson
abstract: LEAD: Jeffrey B. Lane, chief operating officer at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. since 1983, will add the title of president, the firm said yesterday.

headline: PERSONAL FINANCE
abstract: LEAD: THE Administration made a big deal out of eliminating tax loopholes with the Tax Reform Act of 1986, but nonetheless the new law, which it pushed for so hard, left a few loopholes - or tax incentives, as proponents prefer to call them.

headline: SHULTZ IS HOPEFUL ON IRAN TIES
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Iran and the United States might be able to build a relationship around their common interest in countering Soviet influence.

headline: CANADA IS NOT PLACATED BY REAGAN ON ACID RAIN
abstract: LEAD: When the Reagan Administration announced an increase in funds last week for research into acid rain, the approving voices in Canada were quickly drowned out.

headline: U.N. Report Estimates Iran Executed 7,000
abstract: LEAD: A United Nations report issued here today estimates that 7,000 people, most of them opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Government, were executed in Iran after the ouster of the Shah in 1979. It charged that torture and summary executions remained widespread.

headline: Utility Bonds Set For San Antonio
abstract: LEAD: San Antonio is tentatively offering $393 million refunding revenue bonds for the municipally owned gas and electric system through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. A maximum yield of 7.11 percent is offered for 7 percent bonds, due in 2012, at a price of 98 3/4.

headline: CANADIAN INQUIRY CRITICIZES TIMES REPORT ON JOSEF MENGELE
abstract: LEAD: The Government inquiry into the presence of Nazi war criminals in Canada today criticized a report in The New York Times in January 1985 that said that Josef Mengele, accused of complicity in 400,000 deaths at the Auschwitz concentration camp, was reported to have made an application in Buenos Aires in 1962 for a visa to enter

headline: ACROSS AMERICA, THE FISH ARE JUMPIN'
abstract: LEAD: DURING Steve Connolly's early days in the seafood business back in the late 1940's, he was accustomed to getting the brush-off.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS HAS GAIN
abstract: LEAD: Two of the nation's leading financial services concerns, the American Express Company and the Morgan Stanley Group, yesterday announced higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1986.

headline: S.E.C. Report On Dow Fall
abstract: LEAD: A report released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission said that program trading was not to blame for the rapid fall of the stock market on Sept. 11 and 12, 1986, though it might have accelerated it.

headline: 3M Deal Gives Stock a Bounce
abstract: LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company sent its stock surging early yesterday when it said it would be announcing a ''major positive business transaction.'' But the stock fell back with the news of the deal, which was relatively small by Wall Street standards.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''When will we see a real correction? Only when the perception of the market changes.''  - Monte Gordon, research director, Dreyfus Corporation, on the surging Dow.

headline: IRAN PANELS TO START IMMUNITY PROCESS THIS WEEK
abstract: LEAD: The special Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair will begin a process this week of granting some witnesses limited immunity from prosecution to compel their testimony, the chief counsel for the Senate committee said today.

headline: FOREIGNERS BUTTRESS THE RALLY
abstract: LEAD: Heavy foreign buying of American stocks, which set records last year and has contributed to the recent surge in prices on Wall Street, is expected to continue for months to come. Investment analysts believe that foreigners remain bullish, especially in Asia, despite the fears of many American investors that stocks are due for a tumble.

headline: SENATE UNIT BACKS HALT IN REBEL AID IN NICARAGUA NOW
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to halt funds for the Nicaraguan rebels in the first major test in the new Congress of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Central America.

headline: Home State Bank Trial
abstract: LEAD: Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, testified today that he was not responsible for some questionable deals with a Florida securities company whose closing led to the 1985 collapse of the thrift institution. Mr. Warner, a former United States ambassador to Switzerland, testified for the first time in his trial on charges stemming from the 1985 collapse of Home State, which helped touch off a statewide crisis among privately insured Ohio savings and loans.

headline: FLEET TO BUY NORSTAR FOR $1.3 BILLION
abstract: LEAD: In another large merger in the banking industry, the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., said yesterday that it would acquire the Norstar Bancorporation of Albany.

headline: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS DELAY ON IRAN-CONTRA FINDING
abstract: LEAD: A senior Justice Department official said today that a document that is believed to have disclosed the first link between Iranian arms shipments and support for Nicaraguan rebels contained no obvious indication that a crime had been committed.

headline: The U.N. Today: Feb. 12, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Special Committee on U.N. Charter - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Some Rises In Yields
abstract: LEAD: Yields on bank money market accounts were unchanged for the week ended yesterday, while the yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds moved slightly higher.

headline: AUSTRALIA WHEAT FARMERS REAP BITTER FEELINGS
abstract: LEAD: Donald McGauchie, a third-generation Australian wheat farmer, raced damaging summer rain as he harvested this season's crop on the sun-bleached plains here. But it is not the rain that is the cause of most of his displeasure these days: it is the United States.

headline: INVESTING; STILL A COSTLY TO BUY COINS
abstract: LEAD: How are the gold and silver American Eagle bullion coins, which were quickly snapped up last fall when they made their debut, doing now?

headline: Adjusting Retirement Plans
abstract: LEAD: PHOEBE FOX, a freelance designer-stylist in New York, is spending a lot of time reevaluating her retirement plan these days in light of the new tax law.

headline: No Room in Outer Space For Private Launchers
abstract: LEAD: THE outlook for the economy in 1987 looks all-too-familiar: another sluggish year with worries about too much debt and too little growth to drive the unemployment rate much below today's 6.9 percent.
