headline: GORBACHEV PUSH TO WIN CONTROL IN UKRAINE SEEN
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has encountered opposition in recent weeks trying to gain control of the Communist Party in the Ukraine, Soviet officials and Western diplomats said today.

headline: U.S. Warning On the Yen
abstract: LEAD: A senior United States trade official warned today that the yen would continue to rise unless Japan removed trade barriers.

headline: ENDING ALTMAN'S LAZY DAYS
abstract: LEAD: LAST year, when the two C.P.A.'s planning to buy B. Altman & Company's retail stores took their first close look at the 121-year-old department store chain, they went into a state of shock. The merchandise mix, the huge numbers of non-sales employees, even the amount of office equipment in use, all seemed more attuned to a company seeking a tax loss than one looking for a profit.

headline: DENG TELLS MUGABE THE OPEN-DOOR POLICY WILL BE PRESSED BY CHINA
abstract: LEAD: The strain of the Chinese political crisis spilled into the domain of the economy today with calls both for increased openness to the outside world and for greater economic centralization.

headline: DOLLAR DROPS TO 148.40 YEN IN TOKYO
abstract: LEAD: The dollar plunged to an all-time postwar low against the Japanese yen this morning, trading at 148.40 yen in the morning session. As the afternoon session opened at 2 P.M., the dollar was being traded at 149.10 yen.

headline: Offer of Trade Is Off, Lebanon Captors Say
abstract: LEAD: A Moslem group that holds three Americans educators and an Indian colleague hostage said in a statement today that it had suspended the possibility of trading them for 400 Arab prisoners in Israel.

headline: South Korea Is Urged To Free 3 Journalists
abstract: LEAD: Amnesty International and the Committee to Protect Journalists have issued appeals for the release of three South Korean journalists who were arrested last month for exposing a purported Government campaign to censor the press.

headline: MURDOCH HOLDINGS ISSUE IN AUSTRALIA
abstract: LEAD: The overnight transformation of Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspaper holdings into a national chain with two-thirds of the country's circulation has raised concerns here about the concentration of so many newspapers in the control of one individual.

headline: BRITISH PARTIES ENGAGED IN A NEW COMPETITION
abstract: LEAD: Sometime this year, unless every political pundit here is mistaken, the British Government will call a general election, sending the parties out to do battle armed with their conflicting ideologies, exhortations and promises. But in recent weeks, Britain's two big parties have been engaged in a competition of a different sort - selling holiday gifts to the party faithful.

headline: REAGAN ANNOUNCES NEW U.S. PROPOSAL ON MID-RANGE ARMS
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan announced today that American negotiators would begin offering a treaty draft on medium-range weapons in Geneva on Wednesday.

headline: I TOO AM ISRAELI, ONE ARAB DECLARES (IN HEBREW)
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli Arab has written a novel in the Hebrew language, and it has set the Israeli literary world on its ear.

headline: Norfolk Considers Acquiring Piedmont
abstract: LEAD: In a disclosure that many analysts found puzzling, the Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it was considering the acquisition of Piedmont Airlines. Such a merger, if it occurred, would be the first between a railroad and an airline in the United States.

headline: AIDS DANGER: AFRICA SEEMS OF TWO MINDS
abstract: LEAD: One week, health authorities here completed a pioneering comic book designed to warn Central Africans in simple language about the danger of AIDS.

headline: Chase to Close 21 Branches
abstract: LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would close 21 of its 230 branches in the New York metropolitan area.

headline: The In Crowd Is Watching Apple
abstract: LEAD: I.B.M. watching, long a leading sport in Silicon Valley, consists in large measure of following Big Blue's every move with an eye toward making a few million dollars here or there by producing cloned or compatible products. The International Business Machines Corporation, meanwhile, zigzags through the marketplace trying to avoid giving the competition any clues concerning the destiny of computing.

headline: A YEAR OF MISTAKES AND WARNINGS IGNORED IN IRAN DEAL, REPORT SAYS
abstract: LEAD: For more than a year, the Reagan Administration repeatedly ignored internal warnings that its arms sales to Iran were based on faulty intelligence, dependent upon unreliable middlemen and likely to fall far short of White House goals, according to a staff report prepared for the Senate Intelligence

headline: A 'MATURE' WAY TO PLAY CABLE
abstract: LEAD: Cable television is a maturing industry, but that may actually be good news for the its profitability - and for investors.

headline: HAITIANS VOTE ON PROPOSED CONSTITUTION
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Haitians voted today for a new constitution that promises freedom from the tyrannies that have prevailed in this Caribbean country through most of its history.

headline: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
abstract: LEAD:         *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **    *3*DUCOMMUN INC (AMEX)       Qtr to Dec 31   1986   1985                     Sales   107,342,000   108,728,000              Net loss   18,688,000   b18,577,000              Yr sales   455,179,000   417,034,000              Net loss   19,213,000   b19,685,000              b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $279,000 and $555,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses on the sale of discontinued operations of $14,636,000 for the quarter and $15,867,000 for the year.

headline: Terrorists in Rome Kill 3 and Steal $900,000
abstract: LEAD: In a clockwork assault that authorities said bore the handwriting of terror organizations, a postal van was robbed in a residential neighborhood here today, and three police guards were slain by assailants who made off with $900,000.

headline: AC&R's New TV Spot For Beautiful Fragrance
abstract: LEAD: The attractive woman is first seen entering an airline terminal, then aboard a commercial jet, then in a convertible auto zipping along a highway in the Western desert. Suddenly, the picture in this television commercial goes from vibrant color to sepia and the woman is out of the car and transformed into a bride of a century ago.

headline: 'THE COMPANY' AS BIG BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: ON 15 flights early last year, the Southern Air Transport Company's big-bellied aircraft took 406 tons of cargo into El Salvador's Ilopango military airport, the principal transshipment point for Nicaraguan insurgents. Southern Air, a charter airline based in Miami, is a risk carrier, charging premium rates to fly to hot spots that large scheduled airlines will not go near.

headline: Roving Robot Move Into Industry
abstract: LEAD: THE mobile robot installed last month at the Orlando, Fla., semiconductor plant of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is unlikely to remind anyone of ballistic missiles or jet aircraft, its technological forebears. Scooter, as A.T.&T. calls the robot, rolls along at a top speed of less than one mile an hour, carries 30 pounds of semiconductor wafers between processing stations, and stops short when it bumps into a toe or other obstruction.

headline: Icahn Setback on USAir Bid Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn may have overreached in his effort to acquire the USAir Group and may find it difficult to end it without paying a price financially and legally, some analysts and sources close to the takeover effort said yesterday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: REAL ESTATE LATCHES ON TO 'ZEROS'
abstract: LEAD: GREEN ACRES MALL, in Valley Stream, L.I., is as popular with investors as it is with shoppers. Last August, the Equitable Life Assurance Society sold its 90 percent interest in the mall to the public. At a time when tax changes and overbuilding were depressing the real estate market, the EQK Green Acres limited partnership raised nearly $93 million for a complete sellout.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1987  Companies

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: A PRIVATE EYE'S VIEW; WHY WALL STREET IS RIFE WITH CRIME
abstract: LEAD: The new series of arrests and guilty pleas on various insider trading charges last week left a lot of people wondering how hard the securities industry is concentrating on security.

headline: The U.N. Today: Feb. 27, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY

headline: SUBPOENAS FOR KIDDER, GOLDMAN
abstract: LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company have been subpoenaed by the United States Attorney as the Government widens its investigation of Wall Street's takeover practices, sources with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

headline: Shuttle Accords Avert a Showdown
abstract: LEAD: In reaching settlements with the families of four astronauts killed in the Challenger disaster, the Justice Department and Morton Thiokol Inc. appear to have avoided, at least for now, engaging in a court dispute between the Government and one of its chief contractors.

headline: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: Reaction in Jerusalem; Israelis Say Panel Portrayed Their Role as Secondary to U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Israeli officials contended tonight that the Tower Commission had played down the Israeli role in the Iranian arms deal as secondary to that of the United States.

headline: K-Car Package Set by Chrysler
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has an America version of its K-cars waiting in case the American Motors Corporation does not reach an agreement with labor that would let it build Chrysler's Omni and Horizon models, the Automotive News has reported. Members of the United Automobile Workers at A.M.C.'s Kenosha, Wis., plant on Saturday refused to reopen their contract to negotiate changes that A.M.C.

headline: 10 Die in Brazil Bus Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Nineteen people were killed and 28 others, many of them women and children, were injured when a truck crashed into a tree and plunged four yards over a precipice in the southern Brazilian state of Parana, the highway patrol said today.

headline: COMPUTERS THAT DOUBLE AS TURNTABLES
abstract: LEAD: TO a computer, a radio show is only so many hundreds of thousands of bits of data. And a growing number of studios are introducing computers that transmit that data, in the form of sound. The result is that some disk jockeys who gave up records for tape are spinning disks again - floppy ones.

headline: Italian Extremist Held By Venezuelan Police
abstract: LEAD: The Venezuelan police said today that they had captured Stefano delle Chiaie, a right-wing Italian extremist sought most recently in the bombing of the Bologna, Italy, train station that left 85 people dead and more than 200 wounded in 1980.

headline: KUWAIT ARRESTS 11 IN OILFIELD BLASTS
abstract: LEAD: The Kuwaiti authorities said today that they had arrested 11 men for bombing the emirate's oil installations on the eve of the Islamic summit conference held here this week.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: Halco Mining Inc., Pittsburgh, a supplier of bauxite, appointed John W.G. Gilby president and chief executive, succeeding Michael Jaoul, who is retiring.

headline: Mid-March Auto Sales Showed a Decline of 4%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars fell 4 percent in the middle of March, compared with the the 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: Educational Bonds For Penn Offered
abstract: LEAD: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Facilities Authority is offering $128.56 million of refunding bonds on behalf of the University of Pennsylvania through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. A maximum yield of 6.741 percent is offered for 6 5/8 percent bonds due in 2017 at a price of 98 1/2.

headline: U.S. Cruise Missile Tested
abstract: LEAD: The United States successfully tested an unarmed cruise missile over northern Canada today in the second test within a week, the Canadian Defense Department said. There were no problems, and there were none in a flight last Tuesday that prompted renewed protests from groups opposed to the tests, a Department spokesman, Maj.

headline: Market Place; Single-Country Funds in Vogue
abstract: LEAD: THE lure of investing in Asia has helped to send shares of two closed-end, single-country funds - Korea Fund and Taiwan Fund - to record highs.

headline: French Selling Phone Group
abstract: LEAD: The French Finance Ministry put the state-owned telephone equipment maker, Cie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, on the block today, as part of the conservative Government's sweeping privatization program.

headline: 5 Seized in Paris Arms Raid
abstract: LEAD: Security agents arrested five people of Tunisian origin and seized arms, explosives and ammunition in a raid Saturday night, the Interior Ministry said today. It was not known if the arrests were connected to terrorist activities. A ministry statement said two machine guns, ammunition and ''a large stock of explosives'' were seized.

headline: SPECIAL COUNSEL TO EMPANEL IRAN ARMS JURY TODAY
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra arms affair will empanel a grand jury Wednesday, according to Federal law enforcement officials.

headline: Insurance Broker Case Is Settled
abstract: LEAD: Two former executives of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the insurance broker, settled Federal charges that they had falsified company records to hide millions of dollars in bond trading losses. Marsh & McLennan also signed a consent decree and agreed to establish new accounting and control procedures.

headline: Heck's May Seek New Buyout Offer
abstract: LEAD: Heck's Inc., a discount department store chain in the Southeast and Middle Atlantic states, said it might restructure or put itself up for sale. The company had previously announced the termination of a $125 million merger agreement with the Toussie-Viner Group, which cited weaker performance by Heck's in the final months of 1986.

headline: LIFE IN SUN, UNCLOUDED BY APARTHEID'S TURMOIL
abstract: LEAD: Joleen Lasker, a social worker, and her husband spent a year scouting the world for a new home. Like thousands of other white South Africans, the Laskers ended their quest in Australia, a country she found similar to her birthplace but devoid of its strife.

headline: Talking Deals; Merger Games, Play-by-Play
abstract: LEAD: CORPORATE takeovers have become a spectator sport. The business world follows these predatory dealings today with the same fascination shown professional football games, as the press provides play-by-play accounts and dazzling descriptions of tactics and personalities.

headline: PLAN TO LIMIT DUAL TRADING SPURS SPIRITED DEBATE
abstract: LEAD: Last week's decision by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to propose that dual trading be limited in its chaotic Standard & Poor's 500 stock index futures pit was met with a mixture of derision and support by Wall Street traders and legislators in Washington.

headline: Coca-Cola Sales Set for Moscow
abstract: LEAD: Soviet citizens will be able to buy Coca-Cola beginning this year under an agreement that will also increase the production of juice and other nonalcoholic drinks, according to the Government newspaper Izvestia . Izvestia said that Coca-Cola would probably be on sale in Moscow, Kiev and other selected Soviet cities by

headline: Hughes-Baker Deal Close to Completion
abstract: LEAD: The turbulent merger between the Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation neared completion today as Hughes said that its board voted Tuesday night to approve a modified Justice Department consent decree.

headline: IRAQI HINTS AT HEAVY LOSS OF JETS
abstract: LEAD: Iraq said today that it had repelled two Iranian attacks on the southern war front and asserted that the two-week-old Iranian offensive faced final defeat. An Iranian leader said victory for Teheran's troops was in sight.

headline: CHAIRMAN OF GUINNESS WITHDRAWS FROM POST
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, announced tonight that he was stepping down until a British Government investigation of the brewing company was completed.

headline: GOLDEN NUGGET
abstract: LEAD: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had completed the previously announced purchase of the Golden Nugget Casino Hotel in Atlantic City from Golden Nugget Inc. of Los Vegas, Nev., for $440 million. Bally said the acquisition would make it the leading gaming company, with two casino hotels in Atlantic City and two in Nevada.

headline: FUND MANAGERS EXPECT FURTHER GAIN FOR STOCKS
abstract: LEAD: After two days of surging stock prices, Wall Street professionals said yesterday that they remained optimistic about yet-higher prices in 1987. But they repeatedly stressed the prospect of a trading environment marked by wide price swings.

headline: AFGHAN VISIT SHOWS DAMAGE OF A CONTINUING WAR
abstract: LEAD: The wind-swept graves that punctuate the barren hills outside this provincial capital, as well as the helicopters roaring overhead and the tanks that share the dusty highway with camels and oxen, belie the Government's contention that this area has been pacified.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE TOWER COMMISSION'S REPORT  PART III: Arms Transfers To Iran
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the report of the President's Special Review Board, which was made public yesterday in Washington:

headline: U.S.-LATIN LOAN FIGHT INTENSIFIES
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration and the debtor nations of Latin America are embroiled in a bitter dispute over who should control billions of dollars of loans to the region from Western governments.

headline: Manager Confident On McDonnell Jet
abstract: LEAD: Since becoming program manager for the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's MD-11 aircraft project in December 1984, Robert C. Hornburg has spent most of his time nursing the tri-jet passenger liner through its protracted and difficult gestation. Now, like a relieved parent, Mr. Hornburg speaks enthusiastically about the future of the aircraft, production of which was authorized by the company's board last

headline: AMR, RULING OUT BID, STUDIES PAN AM ASSETS
abstract: LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it had no intention of making a bid for Pan American World Airways Inc. but that it would be interested in considering acquiring assets of the carrier if it put them on the market.

headline: TIMOTHY L. TABOR
abstract: LEAD: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street. But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

headline: 85% U.S. STAKE IN CONRAIL SOLD FOR $1.6 BILLION
abstract: LEAD: After a decade of Federal stewardship, the Consolidated Rail Corporation, made up of the bankrupt ruins of several of the Northeast's largest freight railroads, was sold to private investors yesterday.

headline: PARADYNE PLEADS GUILTY, SETTLING FRAUD CHARGES
abstract: LEAD: The Paradyne Corporation pleaded guilty today and was fined $1 million for scheming to defraud the Social Security Administration to obtain a $115 million computer contract.

headline: ORDERS FALL 4% AT U.S. FACTORIES
abstract: LEAD: Orders received by American factories in January fell 4 percent, the steepest one-month decline in almost seven years, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said the change in the tax law was part of the reason.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL, IN POLAND, SEES RELATIONS IMPROVING
abstract: LEAD: WARSAW, Jan. 31 -

headline: MINING EL DORADO AT 45 BELOW
abstract: LEAD: When John Zigarlick Jr. arrived at this remote spot 65 miles below the Arctic Circle recently, he dined on beef stroganoff and strawberries in the mine cafeteria before heading off to the racquetball court for an evening game.

headline: B.P. Head Sees Bid As a Housecleaning
abstract: LEAD: Sir Peter Walters, the 56-year-old chairman of the British Petroleum Company, described his company's $7.4 billion offer last Thursday for the 45 percent of the Cleveland-based Standard Oil Company it does not already own almost as a bit of corporate housecleaning.

headline: LAST CHANCE TO SET UP I.R.A. UNDER OLD RULE
abstract: LEAD: Come April 15, another annual tradition will largely be relegated to tax history: the rush to earn a last-minute tax deduction by putting money into an Individual Retirement Account.

headline: IRANIAN TELLS OF REBUFF TO U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The President of Iran said today that the Foreign Ministry had rebuffed a final effort by the Reagan Administration to maintain contacts with his Government.

headline: BRAZILIAN LOAN REQUEST IS EXPECTED
abstract: LEAD: Following a slump in its trade surplus and foreign exchange reserves, Brazil is now planning to seek between $2 billion and $3 billion in ''new money'' from its creditors, as part of upcoming negotiations to restructure foreign debt, according to officials in Brasilia.

headline: ETHIOPIA'S POST-FAMINE GOAL: SELF-SUFFICIENCY
abstract: LEAD: From freshets to downpours, spring rains have soaked deep into the black soil around here, gradually washing away fears of a return of the drought and famine that ravaged Ethiopia from 1984 to 1986.

headline: NIPPON WIELDS POWER AT HOME AND ABROAD
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street is no stranger to the Nippon Life Insurance Company, the latest Japanese financial institution to show a taste for investing in a big-name American securities firm. Nippon, Japan's largest life insurance company, has been investing heavily in United States Treasury bonds, equities and real estate in recent years.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 17, 1987
abstract: LEAD: Markets

headline: THE NEW C.E.O.
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: MANILA STRIVES TO TURN CORNER
abstract: LEAD: After three years of painful and destabilizing recession, the Philippine economy is showing signs of recovery, perhaps even an impending boom, economists and diplomats here say.

headline: The U.N. Today: Jan. 22, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Drafting Committee for Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. And 3 P.M.

headline: MOSCOW MAGAZINE IS LEADER IN NEW OPENNESS
abstract: LEAD: The article in the Soviet illustrated weekly magazine Ogonyok was a masterpiece of bare-knuckled brevity.

headline: THAILAND PRESSING OUSTER OF LAOTIANS
abstract: LEAD: A year after shutting down several reception centers for Vietnamese boat people, and less than three months after closing the Cambodian refugee camp at Khao I Dang, the Thai authorities appear to have turned their attention to the 84,000 or more Laotians in crowded Mekong Valley and other Thai-Lao border camps.

headline: G.I. JOE GOES HIGH-TECH
abstract: LEAD: CAN Star Wars technology find success with the help of G.I. Joe? Makers of two of the hottest toys sold in America will find out later this year when they introduce the result of one of the more unusual tie-ups in product marketing.

headline: A NEWS CHAIN'S FAMILY FIGHT
abstract: LEAD: Freedom Newspapers Inc., the nation's 14th-largest chain by circulation, was born of dissension. R. C. Hoiles, a scrappy newsman from Ohio, founded Freedom in the early 1930's, a few years after a quarrel with a brother led him to break up their small newspaper partnership and strike out on his own.

headline: BOMB KILLS 2 ON BUS IN NORTHERN SPAIN
abstract: LEAD: A remote-controlled bomb blew up a military bus in the northern city of Zaragoza today, killing 2 people and wounding 41 others, the police said.

headline: Power Out in Johannesburg
abstract: LEAD: A power failure plunged Johannesburg and the black township of Soweto into darkness for two hours tonight. South African officials blamed human error. Police vehicles, sirens wailing, rushed through the streets but there were no reports of disturbances. Hennie Harmse, manager of the Johannesburg Electricity Supply Commission, said: ''It was an operating error.

headline: DENG'S CRUSHING OF PROTEST IS DESCRIBED
abstract: LEAD: One day after several thousand university students held a protest for democracy here Jan. 1, Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, ordered the suppression of any further demonstrations, Chinese sources said today.

headline: GLOBAL PUSH BY PHILIPS BEGINS IN U.S.
abstract: LEAD: There is a special twist to the usual story of corporate belt-tightening at N.V. Philips, Europe's largest electronics company.

headline: NORTH MENTIONED AT BAIL HEARING
abstract: LEAD: A New York arms dealer told Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, through an intermediary, of his plan to sell airplane parts to Iran last summer, his lawyer told a Federal judge yesterday.

headline: 3 Top Executives Quit Lorimar Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said yesterday that three top executives of its Karl-Lorimar Home Video unit had resigned after the parent company discovered that the executives had a financial interest in one of the unit's subcontractors.

headline: U.S. IS PRESSING NEW ABM VIEW IN THE GENEVA ARMS NEGOTIATIONS
abstract: LEAD: American negotiators have been telling Soviet officials in Geneva that Washington's new, broader interpretation of the 1972 ABM treaty is justified, officials said today.

headline: Cannon Group Sells Film Archive
abstract: LEAD: The Cannon Group said today that it had agreed to sell its Screen Entertainment film library to the new studio venture headed by Jerry Weintraub, the former chairman of the United Artists Corporation.

headline: ENERGY PRICES UP A BIT; TECHNICAL FACTORS CITED
abstract: LEAD: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products advanced slightly in dull trading yesterday. But analysts attributed the recovery to technical factors and said it was still unclear whether the market's descent had been arrested, or whether this was only a pause before a further decline.

headline: FARM CREDIT CRISIS: BAILOUT DEBATE NEAR
abstract: LEAD: The United States Farm Credit System is expected to report a 1986 loss of $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion, virtually assuring that a Federal rescue will be needed this year, according to Government officials. The report is to be issued Wednesday.

headline: U.S. PRODS SEOUL RIVALS TO SETTLE RIFT
abstract: LEAD: The United States has begun a vigorous campaign to nudge South Korea's rival political parties toward a compromise that would lead to a more democratic government.

headline: '97 Notes Issued By Bear Stearns
abstract: LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday offered $100 million of 8 1/8 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 8.15 percent, or 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

headline: TEXAS BANK'S SHARES CLIMB
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the First City Bancorporation of Texas jumped $1.50 a share, to $6.625 today, spurred by rumors that a Japanese bank was negotiating to make a large infusion of capital into the troubled financial institution.

headline: Dome Fights Swiss Action
abstract: LEAD: Dome Petroleum, the Canadian oil and gas giant threatened with bankruptcy, has several options in defending itself against Swiss creditors who took court action last week to recover their money, the company said. ''But we're not about to deal our hand in public,'' a Dome spokesman, David Annesley, said on

headline: Tool Orders Down 16% Last Year
abstract: LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 2.6 percent in December from November, but orders for all of 1986 dropped 16 percent compared to 1985, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

headline: Only Short-Term Issues This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the regular weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills, but government securities dealers are looking ahead to a heavy supply of notes and bonds next week.

headline: CAMBODIAN-REFUGEE ABUSE REPORTED
abstract: LEAD: More than 250,000 Cambodians, many of them survivors of the Khmer Rouge era and victims of an eight-year-old war against the Vietnamese who ousted it, continue to be vulnerable to abuse in refugee camps in Thailand, according to the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.

headline: Time May Invest In Turner System
abstract: LEAD: Time Inc. said it was interested in joining the investment group putting money into Turner Broadcasting System Inc. to help insure the survival of Cable News Network, the 24-hour television news service. No terms were disclosed and the negotiations were said to be under way.

headline: DOW RISES 5.76 IN CALMER TRADING
abstract: LEAD: With an assist from Mother Nature and the cooperation of the stock index futures markets, Wall Street yesterday returned to a more normal trading volume and less volatility in stock prices.

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT HITS $19.2 BILLION, A MONTHLY RECORD
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit soared to a record $19.2 billion in November, a startling setback following three months of improvement, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: 3 ARE WOUNDED IN JOHANNESBURG BLAST
abstract: LEAD: An explosion apparently caused by a bomb went off today outside a 31-story office building in central Johannesburg. The police said three black women were wounded, one of them seriously.

headline: U.S. RETICENCE ON DOLLAR SEEN AS PART OF PLAN
abstract: LEAD: By withholding any promises to help his Japanese counterpart cope with the falling dollar, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has demonstrated his evolving strategy to force America's most powerful allies to run their economies his way, analysts said today.

headline: Mission Liquidation Plea
abstract: LEAD: The California Insurance Commissioner asked the Superior Court today to order the liquidation of the Mission Insurance Company and its subsidiaries.

headline: DOW SURGES 36.36, TO RECORD 2,284.80
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rallied broadly to record levels yesterday as an explosive rise in technology and oil issues helped Wall Street get over the ''triple witching hour'' blues.

headline: SLASH TIES, APARTHEID FOES URGE
abstract: LEAD: Pressure is growing on American companies to completely sever business ties with South Africa - not just hand over local operations to South Africans.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization            Jan. 2   Dec. 26   Jan. 3       1987   1986   1986       Gasoline production, daily   7.0   6.9   6.7        Distillate production, daily   3.0   3.1   3.2        Gasoline stocks   238.2   232.7   227.8        Distillate stocks   153.3   152.7   143.9        Crude imports, daily   4.0   4.2   3.2        Product imports, daily   2.1   2.4   2.0        Crude stocks   322.6   327.6   323.6        Crude production, daily   8.4   8.4   9.0        Refinery utilization (%)   85.1   82.7   80.4

headline: U.S. SAYS A SECOND AMERICAN IS BEING HELD IN IRAN
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials said today that Iran has been holding two American citizens on criminal charges and that both have been denied all diplomatic access in the months since their arrests.

headline: DEFENSE AIDE REJECTS CONCEPT OF A WORLD FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
abstract: LEAD: A senior Pentagon official today called suggestions that the world could some day be free of nuclear weapons an absurd folly. President Reagan has often said a nuclear-free world is his goal.

headline: A.M.C. MAY BUILD JEEPS AT NEW SITE
abstract: LEAD: The American Motors Corporation said that it planned to build its new Jeep at an unspecified ''alternative location,'' following a breakdown in contract talks with United Automobile Workers union locals in Wisconsin. An A.M.C. spokesman said that, as a result of the union's rejection of contract concessions, the company would not build its new Jeep ZJ sports utility vehicle at its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant.

headline: G.M. TO BUY BACK 20% OF STOCK
abstract: LEAD: In a decisive step to restore its reputation on Wall Street, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would purchase up to 20 percent of its common stock by the end of 1990.

headline: DOLLAR'S PLUNGE UNCHECKED
abstract: LEAD: The dollar was battered again yesterday in foreign-exchange markets, closing well below Friday's levels in spite of new signs that West Germany and Japan might be about to cut their interest rates.

headline: Advertising; Optimistic Outlook For 1987
abstract: LEAD: AMONG top agency leaders interviewed yesterday about prospects of the coming year there was a feeling not of desperation after a bad year at home but rather one of mild optimism.

headline: FRANCE CURBS SEX MAGAZINES, STIRRING NEW POLITICL DISPUTE
abstract: LEAD: France's conservative Government stirred a new political storm today by effectively banning several sexually oriented magazines, including the French edition of Penthouse and a magazine aimed at male homosexuals.

headline: Heating Costs Decline
abstract: LEAD: Milder than normal weather over the North Central states helped Americans save $300 million on heating costs in January, the Government said today. January temperatures ranged from 1 degree to 6 degrees Fahrenheit above normal in the upper Midwest and northern Plains region. That helped cut the average heating bill in the region by between $13 and $22, according to the Climate Assessment and Information Services Center, a Federal agency.

headline: Gains Are Modest For Nasdaq Index
abstract: LEAD: After a bull market of more than four years, it might be expected that the over-the-counter stocks would be frothing, but their moderate gains in 1986 failed to keep pace with those in other markets.

headline: 'Super' TV Slot - For $40,000!
abstract: LEAD: You are going to find it hard to believe, but you can still get a one-minute commercial time slot during a Super Bowl telecast for only $40,000.

headline: INVESTING
abstract: LEAD: SINCE 1983, the Standard & Poor's 500 index has shamed many money managers. For each of the last four years, the majority of them has failed to do better than the popularly followed index. Corporate executives who hire money managers to run their pension funds, said Byron R. Wien, investment strategist at Morgan, Stanley & Company, ''have lost confidence in the profession.

headline: OFFER TO BUY ROBINS IS DROPPED
abstract: LEAD: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to buy the A. H. Robins Company and to assume the huge legal liabilities of Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device.

headline: Weight Watchers Unit Chooses Butner Agency
abstract: LEAD: Lawrence Butner Advertising, specialists in the use of broadcast and cable advertising for direct marketing, has just been tapped by Weight Watchers magazine to handle its first such pitch for subscribers.

headline: PARIS VOWS TO FIGHT TERROR TENACIOUSLY DESPITE NEW THREAT
abstract: LEAD: France pledged itself to fight terrorism ''with tenacity and firmness'' today, a day after a Lebanese terrorist organization threatened to kill a French hostage it is holding within 48 hours.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO WEIGH 'DIVIDED SPOUSE' EMIGRATION
abstract: LEAD: The Government is reconsidering several previously rejected emigration requests from Soviet citizens married to Americans, two of the Americans said today.

headline: REFORM JUDAISM ASSAILED IN ISRAEL
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Interior Minister, Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz, publicly criticized Reform Judaism today, saying it would lead Israel to ''assimilation and destruction.''

headline: CITICORP GAINS 25.9% IN QUARTER
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp yesterday reported a healthy 25.9 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, to $306 million, from $243 million. It was buoyed by strong profits from its consumer and business banking operations, which more than offset flat results in its investment bank.

headline: RED, WHITE AND BLUE IS OUT
abstract: LEAD: Madison Avenue, which if nothing else strives to stay in tune with the nation's moods, is abandoning the warm, patriotic themes that were widely used in advertising for several years.

headline: BEIJING EXPELS AMERICAN REPORTER FOR FRENCH NEWS AGENCY
abstract: LEAD: An American reporter working for the French news service here was barred from China today for accepting what the Government called ''intelligence'' from a Chinese student.

headline: Ford Widening 6-Year Warranty
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the Ford Motor Company said the company's six-year and 60,000-mile powertrain warranty would be extended to light trucks and vans as well as cars. The warranty is retroactive to the beginning of the 1987 model year. ''The warranty war is over,'' said Louis E. Lataif, Ford's vice president for sales.

headline: Two Issues By Sallie Mae
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering two issues of fixed-rate notes totaling $525 million. Both issues are priced at par.

headline: The U.N. Today: March 30, 1987
abstract: LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY  Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: NEW HORIZONS FOR COLUMBUS'S TOWN
abstract: LEAD: Paride Batini is a longshoreman, a man of rough hands and weathered face from the gray edge of Genoa harbor. Roberto D'Alessandro is an executive, a man of fitted blue striped shirts and white collars, the kind who uses pointers and table-top maps to explain how he plans to change Genoa's ancient port.

headline: Shedding Light on 'The Rock'
abstract: LEAD: A YEAR and a half ago Prudential introduced its first corporate ad campaign that was intended to project its new image: that of a financial services corporation with a life insurance base.

headline: Murray Ohio Chief Quits
abstract: LEAD: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, maker of mowers and bicycles, said yesterday that Richard W. Sappenfield had resigned as president, chief executive and a director in differences over the ''future strategic direction of the company.'' William M. Hannon, the chairman, whose grandfather founded the company, was appointed interim chief executive.

headline: Teledyne Plans To Pay Dividend
abstract: LEAD: Teledyne Inc., which produces electronic and aviation control systems, announced that it would pay a quarterly dividend - the first in its 26 year history.

headline: Leading Greek Junta Member Is Found Hanged in His Cell
abstract: LEAD: A leading member of the military junta that ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974 was found hanged in his prison cell today, police officials said.

headline: CAPITAL GAINS AND NEW LAW
abstract: LEAD: MANY individuals are changing their attitude about investing for capital gains this year as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. But not Gertrude Friedman, a New York City teacher.

headline: Shamrock Reports $42.2 Million Loss
abstract: LEAD: A day after announcing a restructuring intended to fend off a takeover bid, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today it lost $42.2 million in the fourth quarter. The loss compared with a profit of $28.7 million in the 1985 quarter.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: A Washington dispatch Feb. 7 on a letter from Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, to President Reagan about the consequences of a failure to consult with Congress on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty incorrectly quoted from the letter. Mr. Nunn wrote that a failure to consult would lead to a ''constitutional confrontation of profound dimensions.

headline: USX Price Rise
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation said that it would increase prices of certain carbon and high-strength, low-alloy plate steel. USX said customers with special needs involving quantity or dimensions would face increases of $10 to $15 a ton, beginning April 5. USX said its base price for such steel remains unchanged at $380 a ton.

headline: Egyptian Oil Price Cut
abstract: LEAD: Egypt is cutting the export price of its crude oil benchmark Suez and Ras Bahar 35 cents, to $17.25 a barrel, Hammad Ayoub, of the Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation, said today.

headline: FEWER REDUCTIONS SEEN IN DEBT RATINGS IN 1987
abstract: LEAD: Analysts at the Standard & Poor's Corporation expect reductions in corporate debt ratings this year to be less widespread than in 1986 and 1985.

headline: 7.32% Yield Is Set By Knight-Ridder
abstract: LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. is offering $160 million of 7 1/4 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.70 to yield 7.32 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Chrysler Extension
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would extend indefinitely the cut-rate financing program that had been scheduled to end today. The program offers financing as low as 3.9 percent for 24-month loans, or cash allowances of as much as $1,000. The program applies to 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt E, DL and Premier models; Plymouth Reliants, and Dodge Aries, pickup trucks and Ramcharge sport utility vehicles.

headline: ECUADOR MAY HALT INTEREST PAYMENTS
abstract: LEAD: As it attempts to recover from an earthquake, Ecuador appeared close yesterday to suspending all interest payments on its $8.2 billion foreign debt.

headline: OTTAWA WILL ACT ON NAZIS IN CANADA
abstract: LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney is expected to announce decisions soon on how it intends to deal with Nazi war criminals in Canada. The issue has generated bitter feelings between the country's Jewish population and some Eastern European groups, particularly Ukrainians.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S TALK AT PARTY PARLEY
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech today to the Communist Party's Central Committee, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

headline: WHY MARKETS ARE CONFIDENT
abstract: LEAD: WHILE there are some similarities today to the worldwide crisis that led to the Great Depression of the 1930's, especially those involving the international debt crisis, there are important differences that should enable us to avoid another economic holocaust. The most crucial of these differences is that there is widespread understanding of what caused the last depression and how to use that knowledge to prevent it from happening again.

headline: C.I.A.'S REPORT REVIVES SOVIET-GROWTH DEBATES
abstract: LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the Soviet economy significantly improved last year, putting the agency at odds with some Western specialists who say the Soviet Union has modified statistical procedures to conceal economic problems.

headline: U.S. TRIES TO EASE ISRAELI ANNOYANCE ON IRAN DISCLOSURE
abstract: LEAD: The United States has assured Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that the White House's disclosure last week of documents describing Israel's role in the decision to sell arms to Iran was not intended as a criticism of Israel's actions, a White House official said today.

headline: QADDAFI IN A WARNING TO U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said in an interview broadcast yesterday that he was willing to permit Soviet nuclear missiles to be based in Libya.

headline: GERMAN TRAVEL UP
abstract: LEAD: Economic prosperity and a strong currency are inducing more West Germans to travel abroad, according to a report released today by Dresdner Bank. West Germans spent more than 4 percent of their income abroad last year.

headline: US Sprint Rate Cut
abstract: LEAD: The US Sprint Communications Company, responding to lower long-distance telephone rates recently announced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that it too would lower its rates. The Sprint reductions on long-distance services would be 9 percent for residential consumers, 13 percent for businesses, effective Feb.

headline: U.S. Wheat Subsidy Set
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration today approved the subsidized sale of up to one million metric tons of wheat to China.

headline: NEW LAWS ALLOW MORE TO WORK AFTER AGE 70
abstract: LEAD: Marian Johnston, a 71-year-old word-processing secretary at Bradley Hospital in Riverside, R.I., is happy about the new Federal law that bans mandatory retirement because of age. ''I don't know what I would have done if they hadn't hired me last August,'' she said.

headline: ROCK STARS DELIVER ANTI-DRUG MESSAGES
abstract: LEAD: In addition to the enormous flow of anti-drug advertising starting to come from the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug Free America, there are also all the messages being supplied to the various media by the Advertising Council and by a group called Rock Against Drugs. The latter organization introduced its first campaign last November and tonight is beginning

headline: Banking Is Becoming A Specialty Item
abstract: LEAD: MARK A. HOLOD, for seven years a real-estate manager for Pepsico, woke up one day last December to discover that he was a banker.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 7, 1987
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Glemp Is Invited to Moscow; He Cites Too Busy a Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, said today that he had been invited to attend a peace symposium in Moscow next month, but had declined because of a crowded calendar.

headline: Dynamics Fighters
abstract: LEAD: The Government of Greece signed a contract for the purchase of 40 F-16 fighter planes from the General Dynamics Corporation. The first four aircraft, each costing $940 million, will be delivered in January 1989.

headline: High Costs, Low Prices Seen Ahead for USX
abstract: LEAD: To relight its furnaces, the USX Corporation, which has reached a tentative contract settlement with the United Steelworkers of America to end a six-month work stoppage, will sustain a large cash drain, industry analysts predicted yesterday.

headline: INVESTING; Odyssey Stalks Another Prize
abstract: LEAD: Warwick Insurance Managers Inc. ranks small among property and casualty and workers' compensation insurers - about $31 million in net premiums written in 1986. But the Morristown, N.J., company has attracted a big-name group of New York investors. In recent months, Odyssey Partners has bought about 7.4 percent of Warwick's 3.8 million shares, which trade over-the-counter.

headline: A SLACK TIME FOR TAKEOVERS
abstract: LEAD: ''You and I,'' the Wall Street arbitrager said last week to the takeover reporter, ''are out of business.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year        Yesterday   Day   Ago       PRIME RATE   7.50   7.50   9.50        DISCOUNT RATE    * 5.50   5.50   7.50        FEDERAL FUNDS    * 5.94   6.20   7.69        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS    * 5.63   5.58   7.01        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS    * 5.64   5.59   7.08        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.05   7.04   8.78        30-YR. TREAS.

headline: A CBS Issue Of $400 Million
abstract: LEAD: CBS Inc. is issuing $400 million of convertible debt, the proceeds of which are to be used as working capital and for acquisitions in television. The issue, which is due April 7, 2002, has a coupon of 5 percent and is priced at par, according to Morgan Stanley Ltd., the lead manager.

headline: Foley's-Sanger Merger Planned
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. said that it was merging its two Texas store divisions, Foley's in Houston and Sanger Harris in Dallas, into one 37-store operation. The combined division, which will have sales of about $1.1 billion and be Federated's largest division, will be based in Houston and all stores will bear the

headline: JUDGE BARS TACTIC IN WAR CRIME CASE
abstract: LEAD: The defense lawyer in Israel's trial of a war crimes suspect from a Nazi camp questioned today whether ''wishful thinking'' might have motivated the accusations of survivors of the Treblinka death camp.

headline: Women's Group Names Matrix Award Winners
abstract: LEAD: New York Women in Communications last week released its 17th annual list of winners of its Matrix Awards, to be presented April 6 at a Waldorf-Astoria luncheon.

headline: Advertising; Corporate Name Changes Set Mark
abstract: LEAD: Largely because of increased merger and acquisition activity last year, corporate name changes reached a new high, according to Anspach Grossman Portugal, which describes itself as ''identity consultants.''

headline: Interest Rates Rise Broadly
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose and prices fell across a broad front in the credit markets yesterday, as eagerly awaited unemployment figures proved disappointing to dealers and traders.

headline: David Deutsch Makes Point for the Homeless
abstract: LEAD: With dramatic effect, David Deutsch Associates has juxtaposed a classified ad for a Sutton Place condo with the photograph of a ragged man asleep on a plank, to create a poster aimed at raising funds for a shelter for the homeless.

headline: B.J.K.& E. Picks Up Vigoro Industries
abstract: LEAD: Vigoro Industries, which has been fertilizing gardens for the last century, has shifted its $4 million account to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Chicago from Adamson Advertising, St. Louis, which had been handling it for the last year.

headline: BOTHA CAMPAIGNS IN CRITICS' BASTION
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha has embarked on an election campaign with an excursion into enemy territory and a flurry of charges about the source of his opponents' funds.

headline: 2 IN IRAN AFFAIR PREPARE DEFENSES CITING PATRIOTISM
abstract: LEAD: Two of the principal figures facing possible indictment in the Iran-contra affair are preparing defense strategies stressing that they were patriots carrying out President Reagan's policies, according to their friends and associates.

headline: Tax Loophole In New Law
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury Department and some Senate tax writers agreed today that a loophole in the new tax law should be closed because it could cost as much as $20 billion in lost revenues over the next five years. When the provision was approved last year, Congressional experts estimated the revenue loss at only $300 million.

headline: Binghams
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  I was saddened to read your story about the Binghams (''The Binghams, After the Fall,'' Dec. 21), not by their plight - for they are strangers to me - but by what has happened to one of my favorite newspapers, The Louisville Courier-Journal.

headline: CHAIRMAN OF USAIR IS STUDY IN CAUTION
abstract: LEAD: About a year after airline deregulation had gone into effect, Edwin I. Colodny, the chairman of the USAir Group, was asked whether he thought the airline should rush into new markets as other carriers were doing. ''We had an itch to expand - but we put a lot of anti-itch powder on it,'' was his response.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA BLAMES U.S. FOR ISRAELI DECISION
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's Foreign Minister has blamed the United States for Israel's decision to ban new military contracts with Pretoria.

headline: Norfolk Southern Chief Extends Tour of Duty
abstract: LEAD: Robert B. Claytor was to have retired Dec. 31 as chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, one of the nation's largest railroads. But circumstances forced him to stay on for a while more, and his last days in command are proving to be busy ones.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: STUDENTS IN BEIJING, DEFYING POLICE WARNINGS, STAGE A MASS PROTEST
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of college students, defying a Government ban, converged on the central square here on New Year's Day in a demonstration for democracy.

headline: Physician of Soviet Leaders Is Made the Health Minister
abstract: LEAD: Yevgeny I. Chazov, personal physician to Kremlin leaders, has been made Soviet Minister of Public Health, the Soviet press has reported.

headline: IRAQ SAYS THE ATTACK FAILED
abstract: LEAD: Iran asserted today that its troops had advanced ''deep inside enemy lines'' in heavy fighting, to within 400 yards of an oil refinery just south of the major southern Iraqi city of Basra.

headline: Goodyear Sale To AZP Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Suncor Development Company, a unit of AZP Group Inc., said it had bought the assets of Goodyear Farms, Litchfield Park from the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for $221 million. Goodyear said the move was part of its restructuring plan.

headline: Some Nations Giving Addicts Clean Needles
abstract: LEAD: Parked next to a canal not far from the famed Rijksmuseum here is a burgundy bus equipped with a condom dispensing machine as well as trays of small plastic vials containing Methadone, the heroin substitute used in the treatment of drug addiction, and hundreds of syringes intended for people who have not overcome the habit.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES FELL IN JANUARY
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new homes fell 6.8 percent in January, reflecting the end of a tax-related buying spree, while the median price of a new home topped $100,000 for the first time in history, the Government reported today.

abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year    In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago                          Previous   Year        In Percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago        PRIME RATE   7.50   7.50   9.50        DISCOUNT RATE   5.50   5.50   7.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.00   6.07   7.89        3-MO. headline: The U.N Today: Jan. 16 , 1987
abstract: LEAD: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Status of Women -6 P.M.

headline: U.S. EXPERTS TO MANAGE AILING LIBERIA ECONOMY
abstract: LEAD: The United States is going to send 17 financial experts to Liberia with authority to manage that country's debt-ridden economy, State Department officials said today.

headline: P.L.O. AIDE OUSTED BY JORDAN BACK FOR TALKS ON ARAB FUND
abstract: LEAD: A top leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, expelled seven months ago in a rift with King Hussein, is back in the Jordanian capital for official talks.

headline: STUDENTS STRIKE AT MEXICO SCHOOL
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of students at the National Autonomous University of Mexico went on strike here today, confronting the Government with a political problem and halting normal activity at the largest university in Latin America.

headline: Careers; Electronic Servicing Managers
abstract: LEAD: SERVICING computers, office automation systems, telecommunications equipment and other electronic wizardry is a fast-growing business.

headline: Prospect of Sanctions Worries the Japanese
abstract: LEAD: Japanese officials and semiconductor industry representatives expressed concern today over reports that the United States would announce sanctions against Japan for failing to comply with a semiconductor agreement. But they said they had received no official word of the decision.

headline: BEGIN, SILENT, BAFFLES ISRAEL IN RETIREMENT
abstract: LEAD: On Aug. 30, 1983, a tired and depressed Prime Minister Menachem Begin turned to his Cabinet colleagues and said with a sigh, ''I cannot go on any longer.''

headline: Minister Quits In Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's Planning Minister, Joao Sayad, a key figure in the Government's anti-inflation efforts, resigned today, a spokesman for President Jose Sarney said.

headline: THE RAIN FALLS, THE BAMBOO BLOOMS, HOPES WILT
abstract: LEAD: March was not an auspicious month for the farmer U Chit Maung and his family.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Debt American Brands Inc. is issuing $:50 million of 9 1/2 percent Eurobonds due 1994 at 99 3/4, through Morgan Grenfell & Co. Ltd.

headline: SHULTZ IN AID PLEA
abstract: LEAD: Adm. William C. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned here today that the American people would stop supporting the Nicaraguan rebels unless they performed better.

headline: 7 PRO-PALESTINIANS HELD BY F.B.I. IN LOS ANGELES
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the arrest of seven supporters of a militant Palestinian group that has been under investigation in the United States.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 19, 1987
abstract: LEAD: International Report

headline: U.N. SOLDIER KILLEB BY ISRAELIS
abstract: LEAD: An Irish soldier in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was killed Saturday by Israeli tank fire, the force's commander said today.

headline: Insider-Case Sentencing
abstract: LEAD: Randall D. Cecola, a former junior analyst at a Wall Street investment bank, received a five-year suspended sentence yesterday and was put on probation for six years for his role in an insider-trading ring.

headline: A LEVERAGED MACY'S WAITS FOR THE REWARDS
abstract: LEAD: IN early 1985, Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, the nation's fourth-largest department store chain, found himself increasingly preoccupied with two problems. Some of his most talented executives were restless; a few were leaving for better-paying jobs with more authority at other retailers.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., said it had reached an agreement to sell its linotype group to Commerce Bank A.G. of West Germany.

headline: Medical Tests Reported For Marcos in Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Ferdinand E. Marcos was scheduled to enter a Honolulu hospital today to determine whether he is fit to appear before a Federal grand jury in Virginia, according to Reagan Administration officials.

headline: Strategist's Top Deal Is Rexnord Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Jeffrey Steiner, chairman and chief executive of Banner Industries, a diversified manufacturer in Cleveland, has taken the final steps to acquire Rexnord Inc. for about $525 million. The move is the biggest financial maneuver taken by Mr. Steiner, who is 50, since he came to Banner in 1984.

headline: FIERCER FIGHT TO SELL BATTERIES
abstract: LEAD: There's hardly anything drabber and more basic than a battery. But now that another competitor has entered the rapidly expanding market, battery makers are emphasizing gold and copper - as well as rebates, coupons and some new technology - to try to insure that their brand goes into the watches, toys, radios and other electronic gear that have made batteries a big business.

headline: A MODEST BANK MAKES THE BIG LEAGUES
abstract: LEAD: AT the First Union Corporation, colleagues of Edward E. Crutchfield Jr. still talk about the time in 1968 when Mr. Crutchfield tackled - and solved - some serious problems in the bank's credit card operations. Then just 26 years old, he kept the back office operation open 24 hours a day and brought in a cot to sleep on.

headline: TRADERS' GRIM READING OF A LARGELY SYMBOLIC ACT
abstract: LEAD: The rout in the financial markets touched off by President Reagan's Friday announcement of trade sanctions against Japan suggests a grim reading by the world's traders of a largely symbolic act.

headline: Gillette Describes Possible Spinoffs
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company will spin off a computer supply concern, sell real estate properties and shed its oil and gas holdings as part of a previously announced restructuring, Milton Glass, vice president and treasurer, said at a meeting of Houston financial analysts. The company, best known for shaving and other personal care products, said last month it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $190 million to restructure itself in the aftermath of a costly takeover battle against Ronald O.

headline: Bonn to Sell VEBA Stake
abstract: LEAD: The West German Government, confident of support for its economic policies just a week before a general election, announced today that it would sell off its 25.6 percent stake in the giant industrial group VEBA in March. The state hopes to receive about 3 billion marks, or $1.7 billion, from the sale to the public of its holding in VEBA, an energy and chemicals company.

headline: TIGHTENED RULES SEEN FOR FERRIES
abstract: LEAD: A Government minister said today that Britain was considering moves to tighten operating procedures on its ferries.

headline: Consumer Spending Plunges 2%
abstract: LEAD: Consumer spending plunged a record 2 percent in January as Americans put away their pocketbooks after an auto-buying spree, the Government reported today. Personal incomes were unchanged.

headline: PICKENS OFFERS $2 BILLION FOR ALL OF SHAMROCK
abstract: LEAD: An investor group led by T. Boone Pickens stepped up today its efforts to acquire the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, making a $2.06 billion cash offer for all the shares of the oil and gas company.

headline: SPIELVOGEL ADVERTISING PRAISE FROM HYUNDAI
abstract: LEAD: Carl Spielvogel, whose agency, Backer & Spielvogel, serves the record-breaking Korean-made Hyundai Excel automobile, got an extremely complimentary letter from Hyundai that he is going to share with the world.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1987
abstract: LEAD: Markets

headline: Black & Decker Move
abstract: LEAD: Black & Decker of Hunt Valley, Md., has moved its $10 million power tool account to Leo Burnett, Chicago. Since last spring, the company's advertising had been done on a project basis by McCann-Erickson and Lewis, Gilman, Kynett, Philadelphia.

headline: Anchor Shares Are in Demand
abstract: LEAD: Demand for stock in Anchor Savings Bank has been strong enough among customers, employees and residents of its market area that the bank will not need to make a public stock offering through securities dealers.

headline: Zapata Posts a Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Zapata Corporation, an offshore drilling rig operator and commercial fishing concern, said that it had a loss of $159.8 million for the quarter ended Sept. 30 on revenue of $60.9 million. It cited an ''unprecedented downturn in the energy industry.'' Zapata said its bank lenders had agreed to extend until Feb.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Co., a subsidiary of the Boston Company, named Timothy L. Vaill president.

headline: Phone Rate Cuts Vowed
abstract: LEAD: Two of the long-distance competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company say they will respond later this month to the 11.2 percent rate cut A.T.& T. put in place today.

headline: Icahn May End Bid for USAir
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn is expected to drop his unsolicited bid for USAir, an industry source said yesterday, because he believes USAir has offered too much to buy Piedmont Aviation Inc.

headline: Advertising; Lorimar Seeking Poppe
abstract: LEAD: LORIMAR-TELEPICTURES, the corporate parent of Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt and USAdvertising, is negotiating to buy Poppe Tyson, an advertising agency owned by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lorimar confirmed Friday.

headline: Signature Gets New Identity
abstract: LEAD: Signature, created 31 years ago as a magazine for Diners Club members, is getting a new identity next September from its new owner, Conde Nast Publications. It will become Fodor's Traveler.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Adelphia Cable Communications, Coudersport, Pa., to Mullin Advertising, Prides Crossing, Mass.

headline: Coffee Quota Talks
abstract: LEAD: Major coffee consuming nations said today that they were ready to join producers in talks about ways of steadying dramatically reduced world coffee prices through a system of export quotas. Coffee prices surged in reaction to a report that the International Coffee Organization would successfully negotiate new export quotas.

headline: BEIRUT CLERIC APPEALS FOR THE LIFE OF FRENCHMAN HELD BY TERRORISTS
abstract: LEAD: Lebanon's leading Shiite Moslem cleric appealed today for the life of a French hostage who is awaiting execution under a terrorist ''death sentence.''

headline: CHINA EDITORIALS HINT PROTESTS HAVE REACHED LIMIT
abstract: LEAD: A major editorial in the official paper of the Chinese Communist Party today attacked the spread of ''bourgeois liberalism,'' a formula that in the past has marked the beginning of sweeping campaigns in China against intellectual freedom and free expression.

headline: SALVADOR AIR RAID REPORTED IN TOWN
abstract: LEAD: The Salvadoran Air Force killed seven civilians in bombing and strafing runs near an isolated peasant village last week, according to accounts from local inhabitants and a videotape of the bombed site.

headline: CHEMICAL UP 4.9%; CONTINENTAL GAINS
abstract: LEAD: The Chemical New York Corporation, reporting its second consecutive quarter of disappointing results, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose just 4.9 percent, to $102.4 million, from $97.6 million.

headline: Payout Outlook At Bell Spinoffs
abstract: LEAD: THE stock market does not offer many safe bets, but it seems a virtual certainty that all seven regional Bell telephone companies are going to raise their cash dividends again this year.

headline: Rainier Stock Rise Prompts Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a surge in the Rainier Bancorporation's stock price before the Security Pacific Corporation announced on Feb. 24 that it would acquire Rainier, according to a lawyer for a law firm involved in the deal. Edward Lange, a partner in Davis Wright & Jones, said his firm had agreed to give the names and addresses of its lawyers and employees to the S.E.C.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA BARS TIMES CORRESPONDENTS
abstract: LEAD: The South African authorities have refused to reconsider an order to the Johannesburg bureau chief of The New York Times to leave the country before Sunday. They have also refused a visa to his designated successor.

headline: NEW LIFE AWAITS BUILDING SAVED IN HEART OF NEWARK
abstract: LEAD: For more than 15 years Gateway Plaza, the office complex in downtown Newark owned by the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America, has stood as a symbol of the revival of the city's business district.

headline: Advertising; 'Celebrity' Campus Magazine
abstract: LEAD: IT might be that Michael Weiss, 25-year-old entrepreneur, has struck upon a winning idea for a campus publication: Make national campus ''celebrities'' out of certain students.

headline: A CRISIS MOOD GRIPS FRANCE, HIT BY STRIKES
abstract: LEAD: A mood of disquiet and fears of violence gripped France today as a succession of public-sector strikes continued to cripple the national railroad, the Paris subway and bus systems and the state-run power company.

headline: Taft to Negotiate With Group on Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Taft Broadcasting Company said it would negotiate with an investor group led by its vice chairman, Dudley S. Taft, which recently raised the price of its offer to buy the company to $1.38 billion. The television and cable system operator based here also said it had authorized Goldman, Sachs & Company, its financial adviser, to explore other acquisition bids.

headline: NEW OUTBREAK OF FIGHTING SHAKES BEIRUT
abstract: LEAD: Four separate gunbattles raged in Beirut today in one of the worst days of violence in the Lebanese capital in months.

headline: African Meeting on Oil
abstract: LEAD: Buoyed by higher prices, oil ministers from nine African countries will meet here Monday to formally begin a new forum aimed at improving cooperation and coordinating policy among African oil producers, the Nigerian oil minister's office said today. The African Petroleum Producers Association, organized by Nigeria, OPEC's largest African producer, combines four OPEC members, Nigeria, Libya, Algeria and Gabon, with five non-members, Angola, Benin, Cameroon, Congo and Egypt.

headline: Censorship Threat Reported Against Journalists in Kenya
abstract: LEAD: A senior official of Kenya's sole political party was quoted today as saying the party might soon begin censoring foreign journalists' reports.

headline: IRAQ ASCRIBES A KEY DEFEAT IN '86 TO MISINFORMATION FROM THE U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A leading Iraqi official has asserted that misleading intelligence information provided by the United States led last year to a major Iraqi defeat in the war with Iran.

headline: Greek Junta Backers March
abstract: LEAD: More than 4,000 backers of Greece's military dictatorship of 1967-74 marched through Athens today demanding the immediate release of 17 former officers serving prison terms. The protest followed a memorial service at Athens Cathedral for a junta leader, Gen. Odysseas Angelis, 75 years old, who committed suicide by hanging himself in his jail cell last week.

headline: Shamrock Debt Rating Studied
abstract: LEAD: Ratings on $1.1 billion of Diamond Shamrock Corporation debt is under review for possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

headline: A NEW COMPUTER GIVES TANDY A LIFT
abstract: LEAD: If the Tandy Corporation could get enough parts, work would never stop at its new plant here that assembles the company's new, low-price copy of International Business Machines' XT personal computer. As it is, the plant is busy churning out Tandy's surprisingly successful 1000 SX model 16 hours a day, five days a week.

headline: Tenneco Offers 9 3/8% Debentures
abstract: LEAD: Tenneco Inc. yesterday offered $350 million of 9 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The size of the sale was increased from $250 million. The debentures are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P.

headline: Grey's Karp Is Named Chief Creative Officer
abstract: LEAD: Richard M. Karp, 57, executive vice president and co-creative director of Grey Advertising with Richard R. Kiernan since 1979, has been promoted to chief creative officer.

headline: A CHANGE IN BOND PORTFOLIOS
abstract: LEAD: The lack of volatility in bond prices and the uncertain outlook for interest rates have limited speculative trading in recent weeks, but they have not inhibited officials at many large corporations, who are proceeding with major adjustments in the bond investments of their pension funds.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD:  Battle Mountain Gold Co., Houston, named Karl E. Elers to the newly created position of executive vice president, and a director.

headline: Advertising; Commercials' Cost Cut
abstract: LEAD: The in-house television commercial production facility established last April by the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, has cut the average cost of commercials by 10 percent or $13,400, according to the agency. The unit is called Starlight Productions.

headline: IF ANGRY WITH ANTIGUA, THEY CAN ALWAYS PHONE
abstract: LEAD: The telephone arrived on this out-of-the-way Caribbean island 10 months ago and already some people are discussing the virtues of push button over rotary dial.

headline: DUTIES CUT FOR HUTTON CHAIRMAN
abstract: LEAD: E. F. Hutton Group Inc., parent of one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, said yesterday that its chairman, Robert Fomon, had relinquished his role in the day-to-day management of the company. Mr. Fomon will continue as chairman, Hutton said.

headline: NEW RISKS IN MILITARY DEALS
abstract: LEAD: At the Lockheed Corporation's Rye Canyon research complex in the mountains 30 miles north of here, technicians are busy completing a $58 million state-of-the-art flight simulator capable of creating a stunningly realistic environment for testing cockpit designs.

headline: B.J.K.&E. Health Unit Names a Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Robert J. Leverte, 50, has been named chairman of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Health Care, of which he was already chief executive.

headline: 2 Occidental Units to Cut Workers
abstract: LEAD: Two Occidental Petroleum Corporation subsidiaries will reduce their exploration and production work force by 450 worldwide as a result of consolidation, company officials said. The terminations will affect the Occidental Oil and Gas Corporation operation in Bakersfield, Calif., and the Cities Service Oil and Gas Corporation activities in Denver, Jackson, Miss., and Midland,

headline: Markets, Banks Closed
abstract: LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. Government offices, most banks and many businesses are also closed.

headline: FIRST GROUP OF THE CONTRAS COMPLETES FLORIDA TRAINING
abstract: LEAD: The first group of Nicaraguan rebel commanders trained in Florida by the United States military has returned to Central America and training of a second group has already begun, according to rebel and American officials.

headline: Mexico Officials Irked By U.S. Aide's Speech
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of Mexican-American talks in Washington, Mexican officials say they are angry about remarks by an Assistant Secretary of State.

headline: VYING TO ENHANCE THE MACINTOSH
abstract: LEAD: A few years ago, three engineers took out second mortgages on their homes and formed a company to make circuit boards that plugged into an I.B.M. personal computer, increasing the machine's memory and capability. The company, AST Research Inc., now has annual revenues of $170 million.

headline: RUSSIANS ROUGH UP PROTEST GROUP RALLYING 4TH TIME FOR A DISSIDENT
abstract: LEAD: Demonstrators protesting on behalf of an imprisoned Jewish dissident today were shoved and punched by plainclothesmen in the roughest crackdown on dissent in Moscow in more than a year.

headline: STRONG DEMAND GREETS OKLAHOMA DAM BONDS
abstract: LEAD: Strong demand yesterday for a $1.1 billion bond offering by the Grand River Dam Authority of Oklahoma enabled underwriters at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to reduce yields of the long-term bonds by about a tenth of a percentage point from levels proposed earlier in the week.

headline: U.S. Acquisition Sought by Veba
abstract: LEAD: Veba A.G., the energy and chemicals group that is West Germany's second-largest company, is looking for an acquisition in the United States, Rudolf von Bennigsen-Foerder, the concern's chairman, said. Bennigsen-Foerder told the weekly Welt am Sonntag in an interview that Veba needed to expand its chemical division, but the company faced difficulties making acquisitions in West Germany.

headline: Can RICO Help?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:  Prof. Robert Blakey asserts that if Congress had passed the reform of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) proposed last session, financier Ivan Boesky would no longer have been subject to a treble-damage RICO civil action (''The Public's Secret Weapon vs.

headline: How You Can Survive A Corporate Upheaval
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE a corporate takeover, merger or downsizing, most employees can take steps to improve their chances of survival inside their company or in the job market. The important thing, said David Smith, managing director of the New York office of Korn/Ferry International, an executive-search firm, is ''to heed warnings and come up with options to a number of 'what if' scenarios.

headline: WHITE HOUSE, IN NEW PUSH, URGES SUPPORT FOR CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: The White House moved to reassert its control over the legislative and foreign policy agendas today by beginning a strong push for continued United States aid for the Nicaraguan insurgents.

headline: Witco Increases Debenture Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Witco Corporation is offering $140 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at a price of par through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Because of strong investor demand, the size of the offering was increased from the initial $100 million.

headline: LUFTHANSA TO BUY AIRBUS A340
abstract: LEAD: Lufthansa German Airlines said today that it would buy 15 A340 jets from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, and take an option on another 15 planes. The deal is considered a breakthrough for the jet, which will compete with a new McDonnell Douglas wide-bodied airliner.

headline: A JOB CRUNCH JOLTS JAPAN
abstract: LEAD: HIDEAKI NARA, 38 years old and out of work, sat in the unemployment office of this northern industrial city and stared at a card describing a job at a textile factory. The job would require him to move away from Muroran, where Mr. Nara lives with and supports his parents, and it would pay him less than he received as a welder with the steel company Nippon

headline: AN UPTURN IN YIELDS
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, reviving speculation about a general upward trend in interest rates.

headline: Gillette Consolidates Personal Care Agencies
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company's Personal Care division has consolidated its ad agencies, a move that has been good for N. W. Ayer and bad for Young & Rubicam.

abstract: LEAD: Markets

headline: SHAREHOLDER DISCONTENT HELPS LAWYER THRIVE
abstract: LEAD: Shareholders with a gripe against management can fire off an urgent cable to Philadelphia, care of ''Whitehat.'' The nom de guerre belongs to Richard J. Greenfield, an attorney who has built a thriving practice representing the little guy against big business.
